HEADLINE: Champions of the Elk Plan for Its Comeback; 
Group Wants to Establish Catskill Herd

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU

 BODY:
In his red pickup truck, Dave Messics navigated the dark, bumpy road in a remote part of the Allegheny Mountains in Pennsylvania to a hillside shrouded in mist. Before cutting the engine, he cautioned his out-of-town guests that there might not be anything to see at daybreak.
 Just then, a shrill whistle blasted the air, followed by loud, unseemly grunts. Mr. Messics, binoculars in hand, jumped out to join the people lined up by the roadside for a glimpse of the main attraction: a herd of wild elk. 
 "Well, I feel like a weight is off my shoulders," he said. "We saw the elk and heard them bugle. I've had some days I drive around for hours without finding one." 
Mr. Messics, the director of Northeast field operations for the Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation, is leading an effort to reintroduce wild elk, like those in the Alleghenies, to the Catskills. The original herds disappeared more than a century ago because of unregulated hunting and a loss of habitat from logging and farming. Now some residents, business owners and town officials see the elk's return as a way to promote tourism in a struggling area once famed for its summer resorts.
But others, including farmers and wildlife advocates, point to conflicts between humans and the thriving deer population of more than one million. Last year alone in New York, there were 9,253 reported motor vehicle collisions involving deer, and 1,409 complaints about crop and property damage from deer, according to state records.
These opponents argue that the elk -- which are three to four times the size of deer -- would only cause more car collisions, devour more fields and gardens and spread more infectious diseases. "It's absolutely idiotic and dangerous," said Phil Sullivan, a retired electronics consultant in Woodstock, N.Y. "It's bad enough to hit a deer. If you hit an 800-pound elk, you're going to be very badly injured."
The elk foundation, a group based in Montana, has campaigned to return wild elk to rural areas where they once roamed. Since 1995, it has spent $2.6 million to reintroduce the elk in Wisconsin, Kentucky, Tennessee, North Carolina and Ontario. Another $1.5 million has been used to buy 6,203 acres to expand elk habitats in Pennsylvania, Arkansas, Michigan and Minnesota.
In New York, the foundation has spent more than $250,000 to promote a plan to release as many as 100 wild elk somewhere in the Catskills in the next five years. It has commissioned a feasibility study by wildlife experts, made nearly 200 presentations to local government and community groups, and last August, held four public meetings in the Catskills that drew about 600 people.
Wally John, a West Shokan, N.Y., resident who heads the foundation's 100-member Catskills chapter, said the elk would bring tourism dollars to local businesses and fill a gap in the ecosystem. "Elk were here when Henry Hudson sailed up the river," he said.
But Peter Constantakes, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Conservation, said state environmental officials have raised concerns about not only the biological and social impacts of reintroducing the elk, but also the expense of managing another wildlife species in a state where bald eagles, peregrine falcons and river otters have all been reintroduced in the last 30 years. The department is expected to begin reviewing the elk plan in January. 
Some wildlife advocates like Anne Muller, president of Wildlife Watch in New Paltz, N.Y., have accused the elk foundation of wanting to bring back the elk simply so that its members could eventually hunt them. "We're in the peculiar position of having to advocate against the reintroduction of elk," she said. "For the sake of the species and the individual animals who will suffer."
Though the elk foundation's 130,000 members include many hunters, Mr. Messics and others said the goal of their elk campaign was simply to return the animals to their native habitats. "It's a trend to reintroduce once-native species," Mr. Messics said. "Whether you're talking about bald eagles or bobcats, there's a real push to restore wildlife populations where they once were, where they no longer are."
The Pennsylvania elk herd has grown steadily since the late 1980's as wildlife groups like the elk foundation have invigorated the restoration effort and raised money to buy land for the elk habitat. The current herd of about 700 is descended from 177 Rocky Mountain elk that were released by the state game commission from 1913 to 1926.
Though the elk often wander across roads and onto private property, wildlife and tourism officials say the herd has not caused significant problems and has proven over all to be a sound, economic investment. Thousands of tourists trek annually to Benezette, a township of 220 in central Pennsylvania, to see the wild elk. This week, the Pennsylvania Game Commission held its first elk hunt in 65 years after choosing 30 hunters at random from 52,000 applicants.
Many local businesses depend on the elk tourism year-round. At the Benezette Hotel, elk antlers hang on a wall and the most popular menu item is a glorified hamburger known as the "bugle burger." The hotel sells about 50 a week. "We're going to do better than McDonald's one of these days," said the owner, Mark Moorehead. "I wouldn't be here if it wasn't for the elk, because there's nothing else here."
Another resident, Donald Wood, began offering elk tours by horseback eight years ago, and has introduced hundreds of visitors from as far away as Australia and England to elk-watching. At $15 an hour per rider, he makes enough to give up his logging job during the busiest months of September and October.
"I see more people now in one week than I used to see all year," he said. "Sometimes it gets on my nerves, but mostly I'm glad there's that much enthusiasm."
But others complain that the elk have ruined their once-peaceful neighborhoods. They say the wild herd has not only trampled gardens and left unsightly droppings everywhere but also attracted thousands of people who park outside their houses at daybreak and jam the narrow roads. "It's like living in an amusement park," muttered one woman as she passed by a crowd of elk-watchers.
Lisa Huff, a native of Benezette, said there were mixed feelings about elk tourism because of all the inconveniences that come with it. "If you have an elk in your front yard, you can have 300 people there," she said. "They just aren't used to that here."
On a chilly fall morning, a dozen elk-watchers trained their cameras and binoculars on a single elk with towering antlers less than a hundred feet away. As the elk threw its head back, the cameras erupted with noisy clicks. The elk barely glanced over.
The elk-watchers, though, were more excited.
Larry and Nancy Griffith drove 130 miles from Burgettstown, Pa., to follow the elk herd for the weekend. They peppered Mr. Messics with questions about the elk plan in the Catskills, and wished him luck. "You get them down there, and you'll probably see us," Mr. Griffith said. "I'd love to have them down our way, too."
As they set off once again in search of elk, Mrs. Griffith called out, "I hope you see a big one."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Germany: Porsche Net Income Rises 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Porsche A.G. said that its net income rose 29 percent in the fiscal year ended July 31 as sales of its 911 Turbo and Boxster sports cars increased. Net income rose to 270.5 million euros ($239 million) in the year from 210 million euros a year earlier. 
Sales rose 22 percent to 4.44 billion euros ($3.92 billion). Porsche is increasing profit and sales, as are its competitors, Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. and DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Mercedes-Benz unit, even amid economic slowdowns in their biggest markets, the United States and Germany. The company's pretax profit margin was 12 percent in fiscal 2001, about the same as the year earlier. Porsche said it would pay a dividend of 2.54 euros a common share and 2.6 euros for each preferred share. Its shares closed up 0.8 percent at 393.30 euros.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Closing In

BIN LADEN AIDE REPORTED KILLED -- One of Osama bin Laden's most trusted lieutenants, Muhammad Atef, has reportedly been killed in a bombing raid, American officials said. His death, they said, would be an important success in a global campaign that has curtailed Al Qaeda's ability to mount large-scale terrorist operations. A1

CRUCIAL LEADER -- Muhammad Atef held a unique place in Osama bin Laden's hierarchy, officials say: He helped organize Al Qaeda's terror activities and was a member of the group's ruling council. He also was an in-law of Mr. bin Laden. B4

Clues in the Ruins

EVIDENCE -- A flight simulator program, a list of flight schools in the United States and documents describing chemical, biological and nuclear warfare and referring to Al Qaeda were found in two houses in Kabul. A1

SKEPTICISM -- A document on building nuclear weapons found in a house in Kabul might be based on a scientific parody published 22 years ago. B4

On the Ground

THE BATTLE -- The Taliban's top leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was reported to be ready to abandon his stronghold of Kandahar, as American commandos in southern Afghanistan engaged in their most intensive ground combat to date. A1

SIEGE -- Northern Alliance fighters who have encircled the besieged city of Kunduz paused briefly to celebrate the start of Ramadan, but their commanders said they would be moving ahead -- perhaps within 24 hours -- to attack the city where they have as many as 20,000 Taliban fighters surrounded. B3

AID WORKERS -- Two American aid workers who spent weeks in a women's prison in Kabul said they played cards and exercised to fight off boredom, but were generally treated well by the Taliban. B3

Airline Safety

FOR HIRE -- Congress passed an aviation security bill that President Bush plans to sign on Monday. Now the struggle begins to hire and train 28,000 new federal employees to screen passengers and baggage at all airports within 12 months. A1

THE WORKERS -- Airport screeners for private companies say Congress's decision to federalize their job is not a bad idea -- if the government rehires them at higher wages. B6

The Economy

CONGRESS -- The two parties managed to paper over their differences to reach a deal on airport security. But they have not even begun negotiations on an economic stimulus plan that might help bring about a faster recovery. B6

Trouble, Old and New

ANOTHER ANTHRAX LETTER -- Investigators searching through unopened mail sent to Capitol Hill discovered another letter that contained anthrax. The letter was addressed to Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat. The F.B.I. said the letter, postmarked Oct. 9, was similar to three other anthrax-laced letters sent to Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, NBC News and The New York Post. A1

THE BUREAU -- Confirming that a Yemeni fugitive may have planned to be among the Sept. 11 hijackers, the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said there might be others still alive who intended to commandeer airplanes that day and join in the suicide attacks. B5

MILLENNIUM PLOT -- An Algerian man living in Vancouver, British Columbia, has been charged with assisting in a terrorist plot tied to the 2000 millennium celebrations. B5

COPING WITH LOSS -- The grandmother of a Navy reservist killed in the attack on the Pentagon asks how anyone could hate strangers. B5

UNITED NATIONS -- The annual round of speeches in the General Assembly, delayed by the terror attacks, drew to a close with almost every nation joining in to condemn terrorism. B5

IN BERLIN -- Chancellor Gerhard Schroder won a vote of confidence in the Parliament for the participation of German troops in the war in Afghanistan, but in so doing, he appeared to badly wound his relationship with his junior coalition partner, the Greens. A10

Mood of the Country

SECURITY BREACH -- Hartsfield International in Atlanta was evacuated for four hours after a man ran past security guards and disappeared into a secure area. The evacuation caused backups at airports from coast to coast. Hours later, the police arrested a 32-year-old Georgia man who told them he had ran to retrieve his camera bag. B7

THE INDUSTRY -- Some airlines executives said that already suffering carriers might be forced to absorb the cost of Congress's plan for improving aviation security. B7

CYBER TERROR -- The Bush administration is considering the creation of a secure government communications network separate from the Internet that would be less vulnerable to cyber attacks. B7

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
PROFITS INCREASE BY 68% FOR KRISPY KREME DOUGHNUTS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Profits in Krispy Kreme Doughnuts's fiscal third-quarter rose 68 percent as the company opened stores and consumers ate more doughnuts. Net income rose to $6.48 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 28, from $3.85 million, or 7 cents, in the year-earlier period. 
Revenue rose 28 percent, to $99.8 million, the company said yesterday. Krispy Kreme added 10 stores in California, Pennsylvania and other states, bringing the total number of stores to 198 at the end of the quarter. Krispy Kreme's sales were not hurt by a decline in consumer spending as much as other retailers' were because comfort foods like doughnuts are appealing when the economy slows, analysts said. Krispy Kreme is based in Winston-Salem, N.C.

HEADLINE: Pressing Greens, German Leader Wins Historic Vote on Sending Troops to Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 16 

 BODY:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, won his game of chicken today with his junior coalition partner, the Greens, forcing them to support the government in a confidence vote over German participation in the war in Afghanistan.
 On one level, the vote was crucial, even historic, because it gave Parliament's approval to the deployment beyond Europe of German troops in a combat role for the first time since 1945 -- even if few of them are expected to be asked to fight. On another level, however, the narrowness of the margin showed how far this German government has still to travel to become the reliable foreign-policy partner that Mr. Schroder wants it to be. 
 Mr. Schroder won the vote of confidence with 336 votes, only 2 more than the simple majority that he needed, after four Green Party legislators opposed to the war reluctantly reversed themselves and backed the coalition. One Social Democrat who opposed the deployment decided to quit his party and vote independent.
Mr. Schroder's coalition with the Greens, which survives for now, looks badly wounded. He won, but he did so by forcing the Greens to sacrifice principle for power and appear to be hypocrites.
A Green Party congress next weekend could still break the government apart. Much of the party is opposed to the war in Afghanistan and angry about the compromises that power, and Mr. Schroder, have forced upon them.
The coalition could also limp along until elections next year. But many Greens worry that they may not do well enough in those elections to remain in Parliament.
"I'm delighted to be able to continue to do my work for Germany," Mr. Schroder told a news conference after the vote. "This decision shows that when things get serious, this coalition sticks together."
Mr. Schroder and his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, a Green, see Germany's support for the United States in the war against terrorism as a test of their generation, whose liberal politics were forged in anti-Vietnam War protests and the mood of revolution that swept western Europe in 1968. Speaking in the debate today, Mr. Schroder said: "Through this contribution the united and sovereign Germany meets its growing responsibility in the world."
But the conservative leader Edmund Stoiber of Bavaria, a likely challenger to Mr. Schroder in the next elections, said: "The seeds of destruction have been planted in this coalition." Michael Glos, another conservative, told Mr. Schroder, "If you break someone's spine, you can't expect them to support you further down the road."
The agony of the Greens was palpable, with the eight members opposed to the deployment deciding to split their votes to keep the coalition alive. One key Greens deputy, Hans-Christian Strobele, who voted no, said: "This was an enormous decision, almost a martyrdom," adding: "I'm in the schizophrenic situation that I voted 'no,' but was satisfied with the result." 
Gregor Gysi of the Party of Democratic Socialists, the former East German Communist Party, which has come against the war, was sarcastic about the Greens. They voted for the war, he said, "because of their fear of losing their little mandate."
Wolfgang Gerhardt of the liberal Free Democrats -- the party to which Mr. Schroder might turn for a new coalition if and when his partnership with the Greens falls apart -- said the Greens had no realistic alternative to the military campaign. "Applying psychotherapeutic cures to terrorists will not suffice," he said.
Mr. Fischer, the Green foreign minister, had threatened to resign if his party voted against deployment. "This coalition has decisively renewed the republic," he said in the debate. 
But the Green leaders are much more centrist than ordinary party members, up to 70 percent of whom oppose the war as the wrong response to terrorism and are deeply skeptical of what they consider American imperialism, both military and cultural. The grass roots will be heard from at next weekend's party congress.
Today's ballot was complicated, because Mr. Schroder made it a vote of confidence in his government, only the fourth time that a postwar German chancellor had done so. He could have easily won a simple vote on deployment with the support of the opposition -- the conservatives, and the Free Democrats.
But Mr. Schroder understood late last week that to win a vote on such a fundamental issue without a majority in the ruling coalition would damage him badly. For a good strategist, he seemed to fumble. Initial efforts to twist elbows failed, forcing him to hold this vote of confidence and compelling the Greens to choose between opposition and power.
By law, the German lower house, or Bundestag, must approve the deployment of German troops abroad.
Mr. Schroder needed every vote, and Thursday night, he tried to reassure himself that Nina Hauer, a legislator due to give birth, would be present. Rubbing her stomach, Mr. Schroder joked: "If the baby comes, it will mean we have one vote more." Ms. Hauer asked a fellow deputy, a gynecologist, to sit next to her.
Should the coalition with the Greens fail, Mr. Schroder has "more options," as he said today. He could form a new coalition with the Free Democrats or ask for early elections.
His support for the United States and the war has increased his popularity inside the country, and the conservative opposition, the Christian Democrats, are in a leadership battle. An election about Germany's role in the world would suit Mr. Schroder better than one focused on the declining domestic economy, which is slipping into recession, and the unemployment rate, which continues to rise.
But Mr. Schroder is also concerned that Washington not widen the war, which would cause him significant political problems. Asked on television tonight about a war beyond Afghanistan, Mr. Schroder said, "Britain, France, Germany and others agree with each other that this would be wrong to do."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Warnaco Executive Is Fired Without Severance Pay
Linda J. Wachner, once among the highest-paid, highest-profile business women in the nation, was fired without severance as chief executive of the Warnaco Group.
 A hard-charging boss, Ms. Warnaco nevertheless wowed Wall Street in the 1990's by transforming a medium-sized bra manufacturer into a $2.25 billion-a-year powerhouse with brand names like Calvin Klein Jeans and Speedo swimsuits. But her abrasive style also helped sink the company. Page A1. 

28,000 Job Openings in Air Safety
Federal officials began struggling with the immense challenge of hiring and training 28,000 new federal employees to screen passengers and baggage at all airports within 12 months. The new federal work force is required under an aviation security bill that passed both houses of Congress. A1.

Deal Reached on Wireless Licenses
The Federal Communications Commission reached a deal to transfer ownership of $16 billion worth of disputed mobile phone licenses to some of the nation's biggest wireless carriers, while providing a windfall for the bankrupt NextWave Telecom. C2.

Hewlett's Son Set to Fight Merger
The son of the co-founder of Hewlett-Packard, Walter Hewlett, has taken formal steps with federal regulators that will allow him to lobby shareholders to fight the planned $23 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer. C2.

Bush Seeks Safer Communications
The Bush administration is considering creation of a secure government communications network separate from the Internet that would be less vulnerable to cyber-attacks and efforts to disrupt critical federal activities. B7.

I.M.F. Preparing Loan for Turkey
The head of the International Monetary Fund said that he would recommend a new loan for Turkey to bridge a $10 billion financing gap, leaving the nation close to an unprecedented third I.M.F. rescue in a year. C3.

Inflation Low and Industry Sluggish
Economic reports showed low inflation and sluggish output at the nation's factories. The Labor Department said consumer prices fell 0.3 percent in October as energy prices posted their biggest decline in more than 15 years. The Federal Reserve said industrial output fell for the 13th consecutive month, the longest such stretch since the Great Depression. C4.

The Struggles of the Asian Economy
Singapore and Taiwan, their economies heavily reliant on exports, reported economic contractions that were among the worst in decades, while policy makers in Japan, mired in its fourth recession in 10 years, are at an impasse about how to revive the economy there. The developments reflect the difficulties facing the economy in Asia. C3.

Aluminum Merger Talks Reach Snag
Merger talks between Alcoa and WMC Limited, a major miner of nickel and other minerals in Australia, have become knotted over a series of issues, particularly the price, and may not produce a deal for some time. C3.

Insurers Encounter Price Bazaar
It was a seller's market at the annual conference of the National Association of Independent Insurers and the companies that sell reinsurance, the policies that insure the risks taken on by retail insurance sellers, were raising prices and setting the pattern for how much American businesses will be paying for insurance. C2.

Bristol-Myers Squibb to Cut Jobs
Bristol-Myers Squibb is cutting about 1,000 jobs, including 350 in New Jersey. C4.

HEADLINE: New Udalls Rising in West Could Clash for Congress 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 16 

 BODY:
For generations, the Udall name has permeated Western politics, to the point that the family was compared to the Kennedys on the East Coast. Whether the comparison is valid hardly matters. But two more Udalls are emerging to keep the debate going.
 With the 2000 census giving Arizona two new Congressional seats for a total of eight, a growing field for the new First District has drawn the interest of Stephen G. Udall, a longtime county prosecutor, a Democrat, and his distant cousin, Chris Udall, a Republican, who is the field director for Representative J. D. Hayworth, a four-term Republican from the current Sixth District. 
 Neither Udall nor any other candidate has officially entered the race. But the cousins said in separate interviews on Thursday that they were leaning toward running, which sets up a delectable possibility: Should they survive their respective party primaries next September, they could become the first members of the same family to oppose each other for a Congressional seat. 
Several Congressional historians, including Donald R. Kennon, chief historian of the Capitol Historical Society, and Donald Ritchie, associate Senate historian, said they knew of no other general election in which relatives from opposing parties ran for the same seat in Congress.
Unique or not, the prospect of an all-Udall showdown offers the possibility that their election battle could become the cleanest Congressional campaign in the country next year.
"I'm not going to go negative -- Steve is a great cousin," said Chris Udall, echoing the sentiments of his cousin, who said, "Chris is a very nice guy."
The cousins grew up about 30 miles apart on the rural reaches of eastern Arizona -- Stephen, who is 59 and married with three grown children, in St. John's, and Chris, who is 39 and single, in Eagar. They said they did not know each other well, but they share a rich political heritage, tracing it back to David King Udall, a Mormon pioneer of the mid-1800's who reached Kanab, Utah, and was later sent by church leaders to St. John's, where he served in the territorial legislature.
Every generation of Udalls since has produced politicians, judges and other public servants, Republicans and Democrats. Most notable were the brothers Stewart L. Udall, a three-term Democratic Congressman from Arizona who was interior secretary in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, and Morris K. Udall, a Democrat who took over Stewart's House seat and held it through 1990. Morris Udall ran for president in 1976.
Currently, three other family members are serving in Congress, all of them cousins: Representative Tom Udall, a two-term Democrat from New Mexico, who is Stewart's son; Representative Mark Udall, a two-term Democrat from Colorado, who is Morris's son, and Senator Gordon H. Smith, a first-term Republican from Oregon whose mother was a Udall.
Stewart Udall, 81, lives in Santa Fe, N.M., where he writes books. Morris Udall died in 1998 at the age of 76.
Stephen and Chris Udall, both the sons of ranchers, said their interest in a Congressional campaign came about, in part, by the shape of the First District in the newly drawn Congressional map, configured by a nonpartisan Redistricting Commission created by voters last November. Under the plan, none of Arizona's current six representatives will have to run against another, leaving the two new districts, the First and Seventh, open for newcomers. 
With nearly half the state's square mileage, the district includes the small cities of Flagstaff and Prescott but is overwhelmingly rural, giving ranchers and farmers the opportunity for the first time in decades of having a voice in Congress that would not beholden to urban interests. Each of Arizona's current six districts includes a part of the Phoenix metropolitan area.
"We have fought so hard to get a rural district," said Stephen Udall, who has won seven consecutive four-year terms as the prosecutor in Apache County, in northeast Arizona. "Our problems are so different from those in Phoenix."
Chris Udall, an economist by training, concurred. "In my travels, I hear a lot about the 'State of Maricopa,' " he said, referring to the huge county that includes Phoenix. "People in rural areas feel their issues get drowned out."
Despite their party affiliations, the cousins' politics are similar, which is not unusual in a rural western district where solutions account for a lot more than rhetoric. Stephen Udall called himself a moderate Democrat; Chris Udall called himself a middle-of-the-road Republican. Both cited the need for more jobs and greater access to good health care as the district's most pressing needs. Both applauded the Bush administration's handling of the war in Afghanistan, and both said they would oppose efforts to pass more gun-control laws.
One major difference is their positions on abortion. Stephen Udall said he supported abortion rights and would oppose efforts to overturn Roe v. Wade. Chris Udall described himself as "pro life."
The Udalls seem so closely aligned on issues that a race between them would seem more likely to turn on personality, appearance or a campaign style that both promised would remain upbeat and respectful.
"Udalls have certainly had their political differences," said Chris Udall, "but civility runs in the family."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chris Udall, left, a Republican, could possibly face his cousin, Stephen G. Udall, a Democrat, in a race for a new Arizona Congressional seat. (Jeff Topping for The New York Times) Map of Arizona highlighting First Congressional District: A new Arizona district covers nearly half the state's square miles.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: FLIGHT SAFETY LEGISLATION; 
U.S. Now Faces Big Task to Fill Air-Safety Jobs

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 

 BODY:
Federal officials began struggling today with the immense challenge of hiring and training 28,000 new federal employees to screen passengers and baggage at all airports within 12 months.
 The new federal work force is required under an aviation security bill passed by Congress today, by voice vote in the Senate and then by a vote of 410 to 9 in the House. All the no votes were cast by Republicans. Mr. Bush plans to sign the measure on Monday. 
 In an interview tonight, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta said he did not have a detailed plan or timetable for hiring screeners or carrying out other aspects of the legislation. 
"We will throw out the net as far and as wide as we can to come up with a work force," said Mr. Mineta, whose department will be in charge of security at 423 commercial airports across the country. 
"About three weeks ago," Mr. Mineta said, "we started to put together a broad outline of all the tasks that have to be done. But nothing has been refined to the point of saying that on Nov. 26, for example, we will advertise job fairs in 27 communities."
Mr. Mineta was a Democratic member of Congress from California for 20 years and is well regarded on Capitol Hill. But he faces a huge challenge. Federal officials said they could not immediately think of any exact precedents for the hiring of so many full-time workers by the government in such a short time.
The Transportation Department will set the salaries and will specify the health and pension benefits for screeners.
The chief Senate sponsor of the legislation, Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, said the government would be able to attract well-qualified people because it would pay screeners $30,000 to $35,000 a year, compared with wages of $15,000 now paid by some private companies.
Under the bill, the federal government must recruit, hire, train, test and deploy 28,000 screeners within a year. After three years with federal employees, airports can seek permission from the government to use private screeners or local law enforcement officers to do the work, though federal officials do not expect many airports to take that option.
Other provisions of the bill call for the inspection of all checked baggage, the reinforcement of cockpit doors and a significant increase in the number of sky marshals. 
Although President Bush said he would sign the bill, the large increase in federal hiring goes against the smaller-government philosophy he and House Republicans have advocated.
A united Senate, pushing for the screeners to be federal workers, was able to prevail in negotiations with the House on Thursday. Continuing security problems at airports and polls showing strong public support strengthened the Senate's hand.
"As a conservative," said Representative Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, "I was loath to support any wanton expansion of the federal government. But we are giving the president the flexible program he has requested. We are exempting these federal employees from Civil Service Act requirements and creating a system that, on the eve of one of our most important and most traveled family holidays, will send a strong message of confidence to the American people."
Members of Congress said the bill, the Aviation and Transportation Security Act, would go far toward preventing a repetition of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. In addition, they said, the bill will help revive the economy by restoring public confidence in the safety of air travel.
Senator Hollings said: "Congress has made its decision. Now let the administration, the president, enforce it." 
Mr. Hollings said the government faced "a very difficult task" in carrying out the bill's provisions. But he said it could be done if Mr. Bush appointed a "hard charger" to lead transportation security.
Senator Hollings put the administration on notice. "We're going to keep their feet to the fire," he said, to make sure air travelers see tangible improvements in security.
Mr. Mineta said that before hiring federal screeners, he would send federal law enforcement officers to all airports to monitor the work of private security companies under contract with the airlines. Mr. Mineta said there would soon be a federal law enforcement officer at each of the 740 screening checkpoints at the 423 commercial airports.
Beth Moten, legislative director of the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents 600,000 federal workers, said: "It will take a little time for the government to do the background checks, but it's not an insurmountable task at all. The pay scale for screeners will be quite decent."
The new screeners will have to be United States citizens, will not have the right to strike and can be dismissed from their jobs if they do not meet performance standards.
"Present employees of screening companies are eligible to apply for the new jobs if they are U.S. citizens," Mr. Mineta said. At some airports, more than half of the screeners are not United States citizens.
Transportation Department officials said they did not have detailed plans for hiring screeners because, until today, they were unsure whether their agency or the Justice Department would be in charge of the new work force. The Justice Department would have been responsible under the bill passed unanimously by the Senate on Oct. 11. 
The federal government has 1.8 million civilian employees. The number of people hired varies: 109,000 in 1988, 40,000 in 1994 and 52,000 in 1999. By any measure, the new federal work force will be a large one.
The government's task may be made easier by the fact that the economy is weak and unemployment has been rising. When the Federal Aviation Administration held job fairs to hire security agents in four cities last week, it got 2,500 applications for 225 temporary jobs.
"There's clearly a market out there," said Scott Brenner, a spokesman for the aviation agency. "Of course, I don't know how many of these folks are qualified."
Representative Greg Ganske, Republican of Iowa, said, "With the downturn in the economy, I suspect there will be an awful lot of people applying for these jobs."
Janice R. Lachance, who was director of the Office of Personnel Management under President Bill Clinton, was asked if it was possible for the government to hire 28,000 screeners in 12 months, and she said: "Absolutely. You are starting with a work force that has experience with this. I assume they have a desire and would be encouraged to apply.
"You have to develop new standards that will meet today's public safety challenge," Ms. Lachance added. "Once you get the standards in place, it's a matter of logistics -- doing the appropriate background checks, processing applications, doing interviews, checking references."
The most difficult element of the hiring process will be the background investigations, which could take 30 to 45 days for each applicant, Ms. Lachance said. 
But when nearly 11,500 members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization went on strike against the federal government in 1981 and were dismissed by President Ronald Reagan, a large training requirement posed an even greater hurdle. A reduced level of flights was maintained by using 5,000 strikers, more than 3,000 supervisors and as many as 500 retirees and controllers borrowed from the military. In addition, nearly 1,200 new controllers were trained within nine months.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 16, 2001; 
Setback for Al Qaeda, Vote for Air Safety, Money for New York

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
Their bombing may not have hit the big prey, but American officials say it will have to do for now. They said airstrikes in Kabul were believed to have killed Muhammad Atef, one of Osama bin Laden's most trusted aides and a man believed to have helped plan the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In short, the Americans say the bin Laden terror network, Al Qaeda, is hurting, though it remains a decided threat.
 BIG LOSS FOR AL QAEDA -- If Mr. Atef, a former Egyptian policeman, is indeed dead, Mr. bin Laden has lost an important strategist who had been at his side throughout the last decade, when Al Qaeda became a much-feared, far-flung operation. One senior American official in law enforcement predicted that the network would fragment. But that did not mean it would disappear, he said, for it has cells around the world. 
 As for Mr. bin Laden, he was still presumed to be in Afghanistan, exact whereabouts unknown. Either he or his lieutenants had abandoned a couple of houses in Kabul before they could get rid of evidence of Al Qaeda's training methods and planning. Among the items left behind were a flight simulator computer program, a list of American flight schools and documents describing unconventional weapons.
There were also 18 antitank missiles in one house, which belonged to the Taliban government. The Taliban, in retreat all week, were barely holding on. With American ground troops in action, the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was said to be on the verge of giving up Kandahar, his last major city.
ANOTHER TAINTED LETTER -- On the anthrax front, a threat that seems to have receded, investigators sifting through tons of unopened mail on Capitol Hill found a new letter apparently tainted with bacteria. Postmarked Oct. 9 in Trenton, it was sent to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, and resembled letters mailed to Senator Tom Daschle, NBC News and The New York Post. 
No one is known to have been sickened by the Leahy letter. For federal agents, its discovery reinforced suspicions that they are dealing with a domestic terrorist, possibly a loner with scientific know-how.
TIGHTENING AIRPORT SECURITY -- As expected, a long-awaited bill to improve aviation security breezed through both houses of Congress and is likely to be signed by President Bush on Monday, just before the peak traveling season. Democrats got what they wanted: making federal employees of 28,000 airport workers who will screen baggage and passengers. The saving grace for Republicans was an agreement that after three years airports could seek government permission to turn to private security companies.
Now, as they say, comes the hard part. The Transportation Department has 12 months to find those 28,000 people. But where? One obvious place to start is the pool of airport screeners already working for private contractors. The problem is that many are not United States citizens, as the bill requires. Perhaps more to the point, the questionable competence of those workers and their companies was what led to this legislation. There could be rough sledding ahead, some on Capitol Hill said, although others counted on relatively high salaries -- $35,000 a year or so has been mentioned, about double the going rate -- to attract plenty of qualified people at a time when jobs are scarce.
The debate over the aviation bill showed that Democrats and Republicans are as divided as ever over the role of government. They managed to gloss over ideological differences in the name of improved airport security. But they have gone nowhere -- and the White House has done little to prod them -- when it comes to giving the stalled economy a kick-start. The parties' positions are almost theologically held, the Republicans having full faith in the restorative powers of tax cuts, the Democrats believing in new government spending. If they do not come to agreement soon, some economists warned, a troubled 2001 could give way to a dismal 2002.
$2 BILLION MORE FOR NEW YORK -- New York at least got a boost when the White House agreed to give it an extra $2 billion, on top of a previous $9.2 billion, for its post-Sept. 11 recovery. Right after the terrorist attacks, Mr. Bush promised $20 billion in federal aid, but then disagreements arose over the pace of payments. Members of Congress from New York doubt the fervor of "I <heart> New York" sentiment in Washington, and so they have pressed, with only partial success, for the money to be paid up front. HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; 
This Land Was His Land

BYLINE:  By Perri Klass; Perri Klass is a pediatrican and the author of "Love and Modern Medicine."

 BODY:
 WOODY GUTHRIE
Poet of the People.
Written and illustrated
by Bonnie Christensen.
Unpaged. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. (All ages)
 THE story of Woody Guthrie's life and music, as told in this beautiful book, is in large part the story of the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl years, World War II and the union struggles, and the songs and ballads of those times. In evocative illustrations that resemble woodcuts, familiar "Grapes of Wrath" images -- dust-ravaged prairies, overloaded cars heading west, labor camps -- are illuminated and ornamented with the words of the song "This Land Is Your Land," which is treated as both an anthem and a call to action.
Born in 1912, Guthrie grew up with a series of family tragedies: a sister who died; a father who left; a mother whose odd behavior, called a "nervous disorder," turned out to be the onset of the debilitating and ultimately fatal Huntington's chorea, the same illness that eventually killed Guthrie in 1967. And there were also the national hardships of poverty, economic depression and war. But this is also, as Bonnie Christensen's subtitle, "Poet of the People," suggests, a story of populist hope, social change and the power of folk music. 
Christensen's palette, rich but muted grays and browns and greens, still allows for the uplifting beauty of the light shining through the window as the child Woody's mother plays the piano to him. Again, in one final image, the light of the horizon offers hope and promise as the man with the guitar strapped to his back walks off across the fields: 
When the sun come shining, then I was strolling 
In wheat fields waving, and dust clouds rolling; 
The voice was chanting as the fog was lifting: 
This land was made for you and me. 
At its best, Christensen's prose recalls Guthrie's own words, whether in his songs or in his autobiography, "Bound for Glory," with plain prairie cadences and the unabashed populist politics of "Union Maid." Her book is remarkably successful in evoking its era and its hero, that traveling man with the guitar on his back.
"This Land Is Your Land" is often treated as a happy, simple school song. Parents who want to take their children through and beyond the most familiar lyrics will find more complex stories and ideas here: the life and times of one very specific songwriter, the natural and political landscape that produced and informed this most American of poets -- and a full set of lyrics to "This Land," incorporating celebration and struggle, hymn and protest song.

HEADLINE: Pass the Raw Seal 

BYLINE:  By Elizabeth Royte; Elizabeth Royte is the author of "The Tapir's Morning Bath: Mysteries of the Tropical Rain Forest and the Scientists Who Are Trying to Solve Them."

 BODY:
 THIS COLD HEAVEN
Seven Seasons in Greenland.
By Gretel Ehrlich.
Illustrated. 377 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $27.50.
 Starting in 1910, the Danish-Inuit explorer Knud Rasmussen made seven major expeditions through Greenland and the polar north. While he mapped and botanized, he also collected the folklore of the native Inuit. Rasmussen traveled by dog sled and entered Eskimo villages quietly. He listened carefully, and he slowly won the confidence of his study subjects.
Eighty-five years later, the writer and poet Gretel Ehrlich traveled through Greenland with a similar modus operandi. On her first visit, she sought solace: she reports that ever since an accident -- she was struck by lightning -- she's felt euphoric above
76 degrees north latitude. Immediately smitten by the Inuit and their frozen landscape, she set herself a task: to learn how these people lived, how ice had shaped their minds and their society. "This Cold Heaven" chronicles her extended journeys through Greenland over seven seasons.
The Inuit, who as a people speak the same language in Alaska, across the Northwest Territories and into Greenland, have lived largely the same way for 16,000 years. They crossed the Bering Land Bridge from Siberia as early as 30,000 years ago and wandered slowly east across the continent, reaching Greenland 5,000 years ago. Ehrlich arrived to find the northern Inuit still wearing skins, traveling by dog sled and hunting daily to feed themselves.
But this cold-adapted subsistence culture was in a period of unsettling transition. In Canada, Inuit were racing snowmobiles across the ice; many Greenlanders felt the temptation. Global warming was melting the icecaps, which made winter hunting unreliable. In the south, hunters had started fishing. Wives worked in town to pay bills. "That's how life gets its burdens and becomes broken," a hunter tells Ehrlich. "Then, pretty soon, no one remembers how to live the other way."
Of Greenland's four seasons -- one dark, one light and two twilight -- Ehrlich came to embrace the winter, when seas freeze into highways of ice, and traveling, hunting and storytelling resume. Darkness does wonderful things for the imagination, and the Inuit live in a world alive with mountain dwarfs, seagoing giants, naked spirits and foxes that mate with women.
"The landscape itself, with its shifting and melting ice, its mirages, glaciers and drifting icebergs, is less a description of desolation than an ode to the beauty of impermanence," Ehrlich writes. Trained as a filmmaker, she's supremely sensitive to nuances of light and makes much of polar opposites: day and night, light and dark, liquid and solid, wakefulness and sleep. The metaphors flow, some beautifully -- The Arctic's continuously shifting planes of light and dark were like knives thrown in a drawer" -- and some alarmingly: a rock formation resembles "fluted vaginas cut in half by ice." Sometimes, but not often enough, Ehrlich combines her poetic intensity with scientific information on optical cells, hormones, circadian rhythms and the movement of icebergs.
There's a touch of Joan Didion's neurasthenia in Ehrlich, but her high-maintenance head is balanced by a remarkably low-maintenance body. In the classic explorers' tradition, Ehrlich skips meals and sleep without complaint. She forgoes vegetables and bathing. She arrives in villages with no place to stay. She sleeps in a room where the snow does not melt. She lives for a month in one set of clothing.
The only drawback to her stoicism is that she doesn't let us know what much of this feels like. On one hunting trip, she sleeps on a "bare skull of ice with only a skin and a few slats of wood between us and its cold brain." It's a nice image, but was she cold?
Ehrlich alternates chapters on her own perambulations with retellings of Rasmussen's. In broad, concise strokes, she describes the hardships he endured in pursuit of ethnographic data and fresh meat. She presents that era's human sacrifice, cannibalism, child selling, wife swapping and trans-species eroticism as mere concessions to the vagaries of tribal life in a cold climate.
Rasmussen's hunting parties often faced starvation. They'd slaughter a musk ox, gorge on raw meat, then 10 days later find themselves hungry enough to eat rabbit droppings and lichen. Rasmussen falls through the ice and refuses dry clothing. His men sleep on bare snow. They drift for days on ever-diminishing ice floes.
Compelled to experience all things Inuit (Arctic bathing, raw seal, squalor, romance on the runners), Ehrlich shoves her fur-trimmed mitts under the lash ropes of dog sleds and glides off into the big darkness. Her companions are polar Leatherstockings, rough-and-ready hunters with meteorological stations and maps -- of glaciers, open water, animal migrations -- in their heads.
Like Rasmussen, she falls through the ice (the scenes are thrilling), and she experiences acute hunger. But after bringing readers so far, Ehrlich now lets us down. We learn she's eaten nearly nothing for two days. Finally, a seal is shot; some of it is eaten, and the dogs
are fed. Still, stomachs growl, the group moves on. "All evening we traveled in the storm. At tea, there was no view, no coastline, no islands ahead, no ceiling, no floor. We ate sandwiches, a candy bar and a few cookies."
The reader reels. Did our travelers pass a deli? A magic dwarf who caters? She cries wolf again: after losing her luggage, she describes herself as "shorn of property," but she's soon camping with some "dehydrated food that I'd brought from America." Too often, Ehrlich tells only half the story. While she is living in town, she writes, her house stinks because the frozen toilet "has not been emptied for days." Well, why not? And how? When we learn that a zucchini costs $5, it's like discovering gold. Perhaps fearing that such mundane details would detract from her heroic portrayal, Ehrlich generally steers clear of them.
The most emotionally affecting of Ehrlich's threads is the story of her attachment to a 6-year-old girl on the tiny island of Illorsuit. Ehrlich and Marie Louisa spend sun-blinded days together, in silence or in a laughing garble of Greenlandic, Danish and English that neither understands. And yet they understand each other perfectly. The girl's mother is an alcoholic, and her father worries about her education. In love with the raven-haired Marie Louisa, Ehrlich offers to take her away -- to rescue her. Bad weather separates them for years; the scenes of leave-taking are heart-rending.
Marie Louisa's story is emblematic of choices modern Inuit must make: to remain in traditional villages (which lack proper schools) and practice the ancient survival arts, or to greet the modern world armed with an education, the better to avoid the unemployment, alcoholism and violence that infect larger towns.
Ehrlich passes quickly over these social ills. Like many a seeker, she comes to reject the values of her home and to embrace, uncritically, the Other. As presented here, the Inuit who live in the old ways exist on some higher plane, in communion with the spirits, land, water, animals. In contrast, Ehrlich says she comes from a place "where greed supplants regeneration, litigation supplants intimacy, and envy supplants aspiration."
SHE tries to cross over. Living on Illorsuit, she sleeps when sleep comes, eats when food appears. She tears up her calendar and laughs at the clock on the wall, stuck for 15 years at 12:24. Ehrlich wants readers to believe she succumbed to a dreamy sort of stop-time, but she gives herself away. A boat picks her up after a month. How did she know when it would come? She tells us she waited on the beach until 7 p.m. The fact is meant to reveal that she's transcended impatience, but it raises instead the question: how did she know the hour?
These are petty complaints, but Ehrlich's habit of withholding wears the reader out. "This Cold Heaven" suffers from a lack of information about its author. We don't know where she comes from, in the psychological sense, so it's difficult to get a bead on where she's going, or how her experiences change her. Why is she drawn back to Greenland? What do the Inuit make of this woman traveling solo? What does she make of herself?
Ehrlich has written a stunning portrait of a people and the landscape that shaped them. Her story has great emotional and physical sweep, and one shares her sense of loss at leaving this peculiarly fascinating place. "For seven years I used the island as a looking glass: part window, part mirror," she writes. It's a pity we can't learn what she saw of herself in that glass.

LENGTH: 1060 words

HEADLINE: THE CLOSE READER; 
Eulogy for a Little Magazine

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
Lingua Franca was not a magazine to sink your savings into. The initial pitch had the feel of self-parody -- The American Lawyer for academics! -- with the twist that instead of hunting for scandal in courtrooms and law firms, Lingua Franca writers were going to track it down in graduate seminars and faculty lounges. But Lingua Franca's founder, a former professor of French named Jeffrey Kittay, refused to see that his premise was ridiculous. He maintained that university politics and scholarly debate, written about in the right way, could make for good copy, not just for academics but for everybody. His magazine proved his point with such force that after 10 years it had become the standard against which most other intellectual journalism was measured. 
 But though Lingua Franca was beloved and much talked about and imitated, it never succeeded in the way that matters most -- financially. Last month, it lost its main backer and folded. Magazines like Lingua Franca are often accused of being too smart for a broader audience, but that isn't their problem. Many mass-market publications are smart too; they just use their brainpower to synthesize a wider range of material. The problem with little magazines is that they're little. Their limited subject matter consigns them to audiences so small no one can make money off them. 
 Big magazines make their money on advertising, but advertisers aren't interested in little-magazine-size audiences. Little magazines need to make money from circulation, and because the only known way to attract and retain subscribers is through direct mail solicitation, which is costly -- at least $50 per new subscriber -- they are stuck with a big, inescapable fixed expense. That expense, more than any other, is what did Lingua Franca in.
Smallness has its advantages, though. I worked at Lingua Franca for three years, and my first day there I discovered that the founding editor had quit a few days before, leaving behind a junior editor who had been about to go on leave and me. Neither of us had the slightest idea how to put out a magazine. We committed Lingua Franca's resources to overambitious pieces, leaving ourselves with nothing to publish half the time. We poked fun at our audience, too naive to worry about the letters that would, and did, come in. I have no doubt that we sometimes came off as highhanded and bratty. We worked twice as hard as we would have had to work had we made fewer mistakes. And yet somehow the magazine was a critical success, as it had been before we ran it. 
The moral of this story is not that my co-editor and I were granted a rare opportunity to make fools of ourselves, though we were and would wish the same for every aspiring editor. The moral is that the magazine was probably the better for our inexperience -- edgier, weirder, less likely to take the official line on things. Knowing what we know now, I doubt we could come up with the same kind of magazine. Our successor at Lingua Franca, Alexander Star, was younger and had less experience than we, and under his tenure the magazine became even better. 
It should come as no surprise that at any given moment, much of the innovation in journalism bubbles up from little magazines staffed and edited largely by people who are just starting out and don't know what they're doing. The same is true of the theater, of the technology industry, of comics and cartoons, even of government; most federal policies began as experiments at the state and local levels. 
When we talk about little magazines -- The New Republic, The Washington Monthly, The Sciences, The Weekly Standard, Lingua Franca, Slate.com, Salon, Granta, The Forward -- we tend to speak of them in the pious tones usually reserved for do-gooders. They serve an important public function. They contribute to the national discourse. They do all that, of course, but so does Vanity Fair. That's not why they matter. Little magazines have influence -- and deserve to have it -- only to the degree that they're surprising and amusing and provocative, and they are those things to the degree that they strive and struggle and tackle their missions in ways no established and more solidly financed publication would bother with. 
Friends and admirers have been telling Kittay what a blow the closing of Lingua Franca is, since there is no longer a place to read what had evolved into the trademark Lingua Franca story -- the long and serious, though often witty, narrative of literary or scientific or philosophical controversy. What they say is true, and sad. Even sadder is the thought of all the up-and-comers, who might have scrapped the Lingua Franca formula for something better, being swallowed up instead by large academic or journalistic institutions, where they won't have nearly the same latitude, or at least not until they're older.
How will little magazines survive? Traditionally, they have patrons: people or, more rarely, corporations who bet against hope that this one time, this particular magazine will make it. That quixotic impulse seems unlikely to flourish in our throttled economy. The future may lie with foundations, although most of these have a bureaucratic horror of controversy that is deadly to reporting and criticism. Sometimes I indulge the fantasy that the answer is to be found in the public sector -- that in some distant rosy future, government will see that the little magazine is as essential to the nation's intellectual health as the arts are to its cultural health, and start a no-strings-attached national endowment for young journalists working at marginal publications. But that form of financing has its drawbacks, too, since government-supported reporters may be loath to carp at their benefactor. 
For the time being, in any case, we're stuck with the rich. Let us pray for their continued magnanimity, and remind them that they could lose more and gain less with many other, equally prestigious, quasi-vanity investments. After all, if it's posterity they're after, they should consider all the little magazines -- Harper's, The Nation, The New Republic, The Atlantic Monthly -- that were launched more than a century ago, rarely, if ever, turned a profit, yet became the great and established, if still little-ish, magazines of the present, outlasting almost every more lucrative publication along the way.

HEADLINE: ESSAY; 
Beyond the Khyber Pass

BYLINE:  By John Sifton; John Sifton is a human rights lawyer who has worked in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

 BODY:
 REAPING THE WHIRLWIND
The Taliban Movement in Afghanistan.
By Michael Griffin.
283 pp. Sterling, Va.:
Pluto Press. $27.50.

TALIBAN
Militant Islam, Oil and Fundamentalism
in Central Asia.
By Ahmed Rashid.
274 pp. New Haven:
Nota Bene/Yale University Press.
Paper, $14.95.

AFGHANISTAN'S ENDLESS WAR
State Failure, Regional Politics,
and the Rise of the Taliban.
By Larry P. Goodson.
264 pp. Seattle:
University of Washington Press.
Cloth, $35. Paper, $22.50.

AFGHANISTAN
By Chris Steele-Perkins.
127 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.:
Trafalgar Square Publishing. $50.

THE SEARCH FOR PEACE
IN AFGHANISTAN
From Buffer State to Failed State.
By Barnett R. Rubin.
190 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $40.
It is not easy to explain America to Afghans: football, Hollywood, shopping malls. I tried myself this summer on the request of some Taliban officials in Kabul, who invited me to lunch and then asked me, "What is your country like?" 
Where to begin? I described the subway in New York City, the mayor, highways, big fields of corn in Iowa, but I think my words fell short, to the disappointment of my hosts. There are just so many complexities in any culture: an infinite number of details to cover (a little history, some life on the street, biographies of principal political actors). How do you sum up one nation to another? 
Now America wants to know all about Afghanistan and its complexities. From television and newspapers we are learning of the Northern Alliance, rivalries among ethnic groups like the Pashtun, Tajiks and Uzbeks, refugees in Pakistan, rebel commanders being executed, a former Afghan king who lives in Italy. Bombs are falling astray and killing civilians who live in mud huts with animals. It looks like the Middle Ages. Who are these people? Everyone wants to understand how Afghanistan came to be what it is today, and who the Afghan people really are. Is understanding even possible? 
The answer is yes. Actually, there are many good books available about Afghanistan, several of them published in the last 5 to 10 years. Two of the most recent are among the most enlightening in the current situation. The rise of the Taliban is the focus of Michael Griffin's "Reaping the Whirlwind: The Taliban Movement in Afghanistan" and Ahmed Rashid's "Taliban: Militant Islam, Oil and Fundamentalism in Central Asia"; published last year, Rashid's book has become a best seller in paperback. 
Both books cover events from the fall of the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul in 1992 through the Taliban's key victories in 1998, which drove opposition forces into the mountainous northeast of the country. And both are filled with the dramatic moments, ironies and political intrigues that color the Taliban's rise. We read about idiosyncratic former mujahedeen commanders like Ahmed Shah Massoud of the Northern Alliance, the legendary fighter who won over many Western journalists with his good looks, charm and apparent humble piety and who was assassinated on Sept. 9 (in an attack believed to be carried out by agents of Osama bin Laden). We hear all about the Taliban's erstwhile supporters: the Pakistani intelligence services, regional smugglers, drug kingpins, well-financed Islamic extremist organizations, Osama bin Laden and reportedly even two oil companies interested in building pipelines in Afghanistan. 
Rashid, a Pakistani journalist, devotes an entire chapter to bin Laden, including the story of the C.I.A.'s failed attempts to capture him in 1997, before the American Embassy bombings in East Africa. This material is especially valuable to anyone interested in learning about bin Laden's early involvement with Afghanistan and his connection to the Taliban. But the book contains much more than this. It offers a detailed account of the Taliban movement's growth, not as a historical inevitability or accident but as a preventable and resistible rise. Rashid describes how the movement evolved from its early years and became more involved with Al Qaeda, bin Laden's organization. He outlines the military and political specifics of the Taliban conquest and examines the Taliban phenomenon -- its assault on women, its connections with the drug trade and its relationship with non-Afghan Islamic warriors who fought in Afghanistan against the Soviets. While he portrays some of the "dirty hands" involved in the Taliban ascendance, he offers no exculpation for the movement itself: Rashid clearly condemns the Taliban leaders for all their cruelty, shortsightedness and irrationality. 
Griffin also supplies the important facts, but emphasizes different elements of the story. We read more about America's efforts against bin Laden, and the reaction from bin Laden and the Taliban after President Bill Clinton launched air strikes against his network in 1998. We get the tale of how the Taliban approached Washington early in 1999 (specifically, the State Department's new assistant secretary for South Asia, Karl Inderfurth) for advice on "dealing with their guest," and we hear about the mostly unknown efforts of two members of Congress, Dana Rohrabacher and Benjamin Gilman, to uncover what they thought might be unsavory skulduggery by rogue elements in the United States Embassy in Pakistan. Where this speculation goes, though, no one knows. An independently run foreign policy out of Islamabad? Or possible secret cooperation between the Clinton administration and the Taliban for unknown purposes? Griffin raises the possibility, but offers no new evidence. He seems reluctant to investigate, as though skeptical that the American government has the capacity for such underhanded dealings. But such skepticism (if that's what it is) seems naive. 
In both Rashid's and Griffin's books, there is humor, tragedy and banality. Griffin writes about the craze for the movie "Titanic" that gripped the residents of Kabul during 2000, much to the Taliban's dismay (one wonders whether Kabulis appreciated the irony of embracing this sentimental tale of a doomed ship). Rashid describes the imposition of the now infamous Taliban restrictions in Afghanistan, including an account of the bizarre punishments designed for various offenses -- for men convicted of sodomy, the "previously unheard of 'Islamic' punishment of having a wall toppled over them." We hear from Griffin about the detention in Kabul of a 71-year-old American aid worker, Mary MacMakin, for "spying and spreading anti-Taliban propaganda." In fact, MacMakin founded a set of women's sewing and income-generating projects in Pakistan and Kabul. (I bought a doll from one of her projects in Peshawar this summer, complete with a little burqa that goes over it. Widely known as totally fearless, MacMakin was still in Pakistan after the air strikes in Afghanistan began on Oct. 7. I saw her bicycling home one night on the streets of Peshawar, even as other expatriates like myself were safely ensconced in guarded compounds.)
Rashid's book ends in mid-1999, before the coup in Pakistan that gave Gen. Pervez Musharraf the power he is currently employing in cooperation with the United States against the Taliban. Griffin's book runs on to tell the tale of that coup in late 1999, including the incongruous image of General Musharraf on a golf course near Colombo, Sri Lanka, getting a satellite phone call informing him that he's been canned by Pakistan's then president, Nawaz Sharif, which prompted him to return home and overthrow the government. Griffin's book ends in late 2000, just after the attack on the American destroyer Cole in Yemen. 
Which book is better? Both Griffin and Rashid write well. Of the two, however, Rashid is the superior storyteller, most likely because of his deep familiarity with the region (he has long covered Afghanistan for several Pakistani and British newspapers and magazines) and his firsthand experience interviewing many of the subjects of the book; he also offers some interesting appendixes, including the text of Taliban decrees on women. Griffin admits he has visited the region for a total of only six months, and that his account offers only an "outsider's version of events," a collation of "hundreds of local and international reports" on Afghanistan that might serve as an "aide-memoire for a future generation of Afghan historians." His humility is appreciated, but it should be noted that he writes engagingly, and his footnotes and sourcing will indeed prove useful. 
Less vivid than these books but more comprehensive is Larry P. Goodson's "Afghanistan's Endless War: State Failure, Regional Politics, and the Rise of the Taliban," a comprehensive history of Afghan politics in the 20th century, highlighting the events leading up to the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan (which effectively instigated American involvement in the region). As Goodson makes clear, modern Afghanistan has experienced almost every type of society known to exist: constitutional monarchy, democratic experiment, quasi-fascist autocracy, military occupation, anarchy and finally radical religious theocracy. This is a story worth recounting in any context, but especially tragic to consider while the nation is being bombed by the world's sole superpower. 
Goodson's intention is to offer a "single work" analyzing the "factors that have historically been most influential in Afghanistan (ethnicity, state-versus-society struggles, Islamic ideology, economy) and the way in which Afghanistan today influences a dramatically changed region." It's useful reading for anyone who wants a guide to the overall economic, social, cultural and political situation at the present moment. 
For a more visceral understanding of Afghanistan, it might be best to abandon the written word altogether and turn to an excellent new book of photography, "Afghanistan," by Chris Steele-Perkins. His pictures offer an uncannily accurate representation of life in Afghanistan, with all its suffering: beggar women in torn and dirty burqas, men with legs lost to mines, the resilient children of Kabul running in the streets. Turning the pages a few weeks ago, not long after I returned from Afghanistan, I thought, "This is it: this is exactly what it looks like." 
Still, none of the preceding books on its own is sufficient to address the most important issue that faces Afghanistan now: its future. The outcome will be influenced heavily by the characters waiting in the wings to take power from the Taliban. To get a proper bearing on all these actors, one must turn to an earlier book that, while not a captivating tale of recent Afghan history, is nevertheless an indispensable source for understanding Afghanistan's future. That book is Barnett R. Rubin's "Search for Peace in Afghanistan: From Buffer State to Failed State" (1995). 
Rubin may be one of the most knowledgeable people in America about Afghanistan -- certainly he understands its past and present politics better than almost anyone in the Bush administration. (For example, the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, revealed her ignorance about the region in June 2000 when, as an adviser to the Bush campaign, she suggested without explanation that Iran and the Taliban were somehow in cahoots, despite the fact that Iran has supported anti-Taliban forces for more than five years and almost declared war on the Taliban in 1998). 
Rubin has been around the Afghanistan scene for well over a decade, and has interviewed scores of important political actors involved in the region: United States and United Nations representatives, Taliban foreign ministers, representatives of the Afghan diaspora. He knows how efforts to build peace and stability in Afghanistan have repeatedly failed: from 1988, when a United Nations-mediated agreement heralded a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan but arranged no real future Afghan government, to the period from 1992 to 1994, when the United Nations failed (albeit without any serious American or Russian support) to help secure a peace among warring Afghan parties, effectively setting the stage for Taliban ascendance. Bloody hands are everywhere: Presidents Ronald Reagan, George Bush and Bill Clinton; various career diplomats in the State Department; Pakistan's rulers and Afghan leaders who refused to make concessions that would allow peace.
Rubin clearly rejects the put-all-the-blame-in-one-place thinking that often clouds analysis of why Afghanistan descended into the chaos that it is in today. As he notes, it is impossible to stop blaming once the blame starts to roll. He writes, dryly, that if the United States had not initially aided certain mujahedeen parties over others, later problems in the peace negotiations would not have occurred, but then, if the Soviet Union had not supported the Afghan Communist Party and intervened militarily, "the United States might not have devoted such resources to building up an Islamist resistance." He goes on: if Pakistan had not rebuffed certain Afghan political moves in the 1960's and 1970's, Afghan rulers would not have turned to the Soviet Union, "and so on, back to Genghis Khan and beyond. Such arguments lead everywhere and nowhere." The better course is to stop blaming, and appreciate the lesson that fixing failed states can only be accomplished through "sustained cooperative effort" by the international community. This is a valuable lesson that the United States must heed in the coming years.

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine; Pg. 18
