HEADLINE: ON THE VERGE; 
A Landscape in Peril

BYLINE:  By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan, who writes for The Times from Seattle, is the author of "Lasso the Wind: Away to the New West" (Vintage).

 BODY:
Well before German marks and drachmas began showing up at the City Market in Moab, before Lycra became the second skin of nearly every visitor, even before cell phones became tourists' essential companions, the novelist and wilderness defender Edward Abbey wrote about the enduring paradox of Utah's canyon country: it is "the least inhabited, least developed, least improved, least civilized, most arid, most hostile, most lonesome, most grim bleak barren desolate and savage quarter of the state of Utah -- the best part by far."
 A dozen years after Abbey's death, the "savage quarter" is anything but lonesome, though it may still be best part of Utah. Carved by the Colorado River and fine-sculptured by a frisky wind, the high, dry land of southeast Utah has become one of the foremost playgrounds for people on fat tires, four tires, rubber rafts and all manner of transport in between. 
 A shout still falls away in the white light of a desert afternoon. Stars still press through the inky bowl of a night sky. And the canyons, arches, spires and sandstone monuments are as immutable as ever in their demonstration of the slow clock of geologic time. But there is a sense around Moab that these natural wonders have too quickly become commodities, and that those who want to play among the canyons cannot do so all at once. 
Moabites complain that their town and surrounding country, dubbed the mountain-biking capital of the world, have been "Aspenized." I'm not exactly sure what that term means, but having heard it thrown around the West in conjunction with words usually reserved for people who start forest fires, I know it's not a good thing.
On the famous Slickrock Trail, just a pedal push outside Moab, mountain bikes are tire to tire -- more than 100,000 cyclists a year. All-terrain vehicles have torn up much of the fragile crust of the open land and eroded many of the back roads. Hyper-recreating tourists, park rangers say, are having the same effect on the terrain that mining and excessive grazing once did. Federal land managers have tried to keep campgrounds from becoming outdoor garbage dumps, and to teach people that what holds the canyon country together is a living skin that, once torn, can cause the ground to unravel. Still, as Bill Stevens, a Bureau of Land Management recreation specialist in Moab, says, "everything seems to be getting just a little out of hand."
The base elements of the canyon country -- sun, stone, wind, a wilderness of eroded rock and mazes -- used to repel people. It was a place for pygmy rattlesnakes, scorpions and howl-at-the-moon spiritualists. Abbey's book "Desert Solitaire" was based on two seasons spent near Moab, but now the title seems oxymoronic. Moab was a half-dead mining village with a couple of hard-edged taverns inhabited by men with chiggers in their beards. Old-timers, people who have lived in Moab since the days when Kokopelli was still a flute-playing legend and not real estate development, say a person could fall asleep in the middle of Main Street and not worry about a car coming by for hours.
What this area always had going for it was a surfeit of magnificent scenery -- Canyonlands National Park, southwest of town, Arches National Park, to the north, and more than two million acres of open terrain run by the Bureau of Land Management.
The Anasazi, of course, were all over the Colorado Plateau, leaving their closed-up stone apartments, their rock art of legless anthropomorphs and their pottery with its zigzags to eternity for later generations to puzzle over and interpret. Another group of inhabitants, Mormon settlers in the 1870's, named their town Moab after the biblical kingdom that was just short of the Promised Land. And short it remained, as a succession of ranchers and farmers tried to scratch a living out of the red dirt. The cold war gave a boost to uranium mining, transforming Moab into a boom town in the 1950's. But, as with all mining bubbles, the bust soon followed, and Moab settled into a slouch toward the grave.
A couple of John Wayne films, "Rio Grande" and "The Comancheros," and a biblical epic in which Wayne had a bit part, "The Greatest Story Ever Told," were filmed around Moab. It looked -- and felt -- empty and, at times, haunting.
Then, about 15 years ago, the canyon country was rediscovered, in frenzied fashion. Visitors to Arches National Park more than tripled in 20 years, from 269,489 in 1979 to 869,980 in 1999, and grew sixfold in Canyonlands during the same period, to 446,527. And the Bureau of Land Management property, once confined to lonely rockhounds, a handful of desert cowboys and a few petroglyph buffs, are now visited by more than a million people a year, in the estimate of federal officials in Utah, who say accurate counts are hard to come by.
In the early stages of the tourist boom, visitors came out of archaeological curiosity, or to roam and search for solitude. The canyon country is anything but linear, and it's not easy to read. Distances are deceptive. Temperatures can fall as much as 50 degrees from late afternoon to midnight. Humans can get swallowed in labyrinths of sandpapered rock. Afternoon thunderstorms can turn trickles into torrents, flooding canyons and stranding hikers. There are plenty of old mining roads all over the canyon country, but most of them are not marked. But the rewards for the visitor were, and still are, a sense of discovery and adventure in one of the last places in the continental United States to be fully mapped and charted.
Then came the toys, motorized and pedal powered, and, before long, Moab was mobbed, a town of barely 6,000 people with almost 2,000 hotel rooms. Mountain bikes did to Moab what surfboards did to remote beaches on Maui; the little town started to show up on lists of the best places for mountain biking and four-wheeling. Europeans, in particular, took to the odd-shaped features and pastel colors of the land.
Biking and Jeep clubs held jamborees, parties and field trips for masses of people. The shoulder seasons stretched into the winter. Spring-break keggers, built around daddy's Jeep and bonfires on public land, became a regular cause for a ranger's headache. All of this was good for an economy that had undergone a near-death experience, but the people who run the public lands saw it differently.
For one thing, the rangers know that the wrinkled topography of the canyon country is not a simple desert with a grand river running through it. The ground is alive and held together by a cryptobiotic crust, a thin tangle of lichens, bacteria, mosses and other components. Jeep and bike trails lead to its destruction. Park managers have tried to get people to stay on the maintained roads, but it has been a hit-or-miss effort. And once people get into the red rock maze, and get lost, they want immediate help.
"We get these cell phone calls all the time from people in their Jeeps who say, 'I'm lost and you need to come help me, but I can't tell you where I am,' " Stevens says.
Land managers worry that arches that predate the arrival of the first humans on the continent could be chipped or marred by the most recent visitors, or that the innumerable Anasazi sites in the south could be vandalized. Increasingly, the rangers have had to referee conflicts between the different groups scrambling for their piece of the canyon country -- hikers versus bikers, horseback riders versus four-wheelers, target shooters versus bird-watchers -- as new extreme sports are invented. The latest craze around Moab is base jumping, in which people with parachutes fall from the tops of tall spires and cliffs. The life insurance industry is not crazy about it.
Park rangers, whose dual mandate is to provide recreational ground for the public and to preserve it for future generations, have placed limits on back-country permits to certain areas, trying to funnel visitors into well-maintained campgrounds and encouraging them to follow desert etiquette on the fragile land. They report some success, and also say that visitor traffic has started to level off. But the people who run the Bureau of Land Management acreage -- with a small staff and few guidelines -- say they are dealing with something close to recreational anarchy.
Moab, like other golden settings in the West, may now be expanding from a tourist economy to real estate. Plans are well under way to develop 150 condominiums, a 225-room lodge and 110 houses on two-acre sites in a development called Cloudrock. It won't be long, some fear, until the local people become props -- as they are in Aspen, Colo., and Jackson Hole, Wyo. -- bused into town from distant places where housing is more affordable.
But many visitors are already moving on to the "next Moab," the other canyon country hamlets where espresso huts and bike-rental shops have sprouted overnight, places like Blanding, Monticello, Mexican Hat and Bluff. Within a few years, all will most likely lose their anonymity.
Abbey's biggest fear, as he celebrated this formerly underappreciated patch of America, was that people would run their motorized vehicles through places he considered holy. After all, he wrote, you can't drive a car into church.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 5; Column 1; Travel Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1514 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Airports Becoming No-Buy Zones 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD; MATTHEW L. WALD is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
TRAVELERS who order a sandwich at Au Bon Pain at Pittsburgh International Airport may find that the bread looks as if it were hacked apart with a blunt instrument. It was. Security officials have taken away all the knives because the restaurant is inside the security perimeter, and workers behind the counter now have nothing sharper than a spreader, a metal disk originally designed for slathering mayonnaise or mustard on bread.
 At San Francisco International Airport, passengers can still buy a golf club at the shop in the terminal, but a putter is now a potential weapon, according to the Federal Aviation Administration, so it must be sent as checked baggage. At Reagan Washington National Airport, people making a day trip to Washington, arriving early and leaving late, will still see a row of fancy shops with enticing displays, but most will be closed. The airport used to insist that they open 7 a.m. to 9 p.m.; now they are open 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. 
 And at La Guardia Airport, if the line to clear security is long enough, a Wendy's employee will take your food order as you stand waiting, and deliver your hamburger and fries in time for you to eat them before you reach the security checkpoint. 
Those are some of the effects on the airports of the Sept. 11 hijackings. The obvious commercial victims have been airlines and hotels, but airports are suffering, too. And worse is to come if the airports do not smooth out security problems and passengers do not return in their former numbers, according to airport executives and others. The upscale retailing that many airports have tried hard to nurture in recent years is mostly still in place, but largely because airports have forgiven some of the rent for September and October. That has saved many of the airport stores from closings and layoffs, although many employees have had their hours cut back. 
By most accounts, retailers are taking a harder hit than airlines, at least in percentage terms. Passenger loads are down at least 20 percent at most airports, but retail sales are off 40 percent in some places.
Lost sales and forgiven rents are two reasons that airports have been hemorrhaging money lately, and there are others -- parking lots are half empty, payments for landing fees are down, and, with fewer travelers, there is less revenue from the passenger facility charge, the $3 or so that many airports tack on to airline tickets to pay for improvements. The surcharges they collect on car rentals are down, too.
"From the survey work we've done, we think airports will lose $2 billion to $3 billion in revenue over the course of the next year," said Todd Hauptli, a spokesman for the American Association of Airport Executives and the Airports Council International. Total revenue for all United States commercial airports was about $12.3 billion last year. In addition, his group estimates that airports will spend about $1 billion in the next year for new security equipment and extra security personnel.
All of this means that airports eventually will have to make big changes or get big subsidies. "Some airports are going to turn around and charge costs back to their major tenants, the carriers, but it's a pretty open question about the ability of carriers to meet those costs," Mr. Hauptli said.
There is an ultimate source of funds, though. "In the end, in air transportation, everything ultimately goes back to the passenger," he said. "That's how we fund the system." That could mean new surcharges or higher fares. It has not happened yet, but travelers already can notice changes.
One is in the nature of goods for sale. At the Brookstone store at Reagan Airport one afternoon recently, the manager, Dennis McNeil, leaned his elbows on the back of a big leather massage chair, a Brookstone staple, and played with a new item, a hand-held Tetris computer game. Mr. McNeil pointed to a display of similar games, including chess and backgammon, which he said had replaced barbecue forks and similar sharp objects. Most of the shopping at National is outside the secure areas, but a passenger who bought something that is now contraband would not be able to carry it onto the plane, so the store has stopped selling such items. Sewing kits and scissors are also out. But a suitcase with casters with a separate pocket for a laptop is selling well, Mr. McNeil said, because of the new limit on carry-ons.
Merchants at Reagan have been especially hard hit because the airport was closed for more than three weeks after Sept. 11, until new security arrangements could be established. Now, people who use Reagan Airport, directly across the Potomac River from the heart of the District of Columbia, argue that it is the safest airport in the country. But with the airlines' strictly limiting the number of carry-ons, people are less apt to shop. And in contrast to the casual past, hardly anyone who has made it through the security checkpoint comes out again to the main shopping area.
The electronic games, $15 to $30 each, are selling well, though. "People have been getting here two hours early, checking in in five minutes, and have to have something to do," Mr. McNeil said.
Reagan Airport lost $400,000 a day for the three weeks it was closed and is still losing substantial revenues, said Tara Hamilton, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority, which also operates Dulles. Even before Sept. 11, traffic was down because high-tech businesses, a big factor in northern Virginia, were in financial trouble, she said. 
But before Sept. 11, the airport dispatched about 5,000 taxis a day, she said; now it is a little over half that.
Even upscale retailers are feeling the pinch, particularly with the absence of the "meeters and greeters," who are no longer allowed past security. 
In fact, around the country, gleaming new terminals, some of which look like shopping malls that happen to have boarding gates nearby, now seem to belong to another era. "After Sept. 11, the security footprint isn't quite matching the shoe," said Paul P. Bollinger Jr., a vice president at HNTB, an architecture, planning and engineering company in Alexandria, Va., that does work for airports around the country.
In December 2000, San Francisco International opened a 2.5-million-square-foot terminal with great fanfare. On Aug. 20 of this year, a press release boasted of the airport's "one-of-a-kind culinary, cultural and shopping experiences." Those still beckon, but many of them are open only to people with tickets; the meeters and greeters who come to see a passenger off or pick one up cannot get near many of the shops. And those who can get in often aren't buying, partly because of the uncertain economy. "People traveling today don't know whether they are going to have jobs next month," said Ron V. Wilson, an airport spokesman.
Retail rents at many airports are based on a percentage of sales, with minimum guarantees; San Francisco, like other airports, has reduced or waived guarantees. 
Some places are doing well. "One thing has spiked," Mr. Wilson said. "It's the booze part. Some people under normal circumstances can't get on an airplane unless they're half gassed. And now that is even accentuated." 
In fact, if people arrive early expecting a long line and instead face a short one, it gives them more time to drink, retail experts at various airports say. But that hasn't helped Personalities, a restaurant and bar outside the checkpoint for Gates 20 to 36 in San Francisco, which handle domestic flights. One noontime recently, 200 stood right in front of the bar -- all waiting to go through security. The bar was empty. Tai Yung Liang, the full-time bartender, has had his hours cut back to 30.
Pittsburgh International Airport was clearly designed for peacetime use, with a shopping mall in the center and concourses radiating out in four directions, all of it inside the secure area. At the Eckerd drugstore, the manager said she had had a visit from the F.A.A. and the company that manages retailing in the airport, who ordered her to remove all razor blades, tweezers, nail clippers and even eyeglass-repair kits from the shelves.
"They even confiscated our case cutters and scissors for personal use," said the manager, who would not give her name. She gets periodic visits from the F.A.A. to assure she has not restocked, she said. The store appeared to be busy on a recent visit, but traffic through the airport is down, and merchants say that sales are down at least in proportion to traffic. 
But in Pittsburgh, as elsewhere, the airport bookstore reports brisk sales of new titles like "Bin Laden: The Man Who Declared War on America," and "Target U.S.A.: The Inside Story of the New Terrorist War."
At the Au Bon Pain inside the security perimeter in Pittsburgh, Linda Kuhni, the general manager, said that because her knives had been taken away, she could no longer guarantee a visually appealing sandwich. On the other hand, her sales are up because airlines have reduced food service on board. "Not feeding them on the plane is helping my business," she said.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; 
Airlines Are Cutting Their Discount Services

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
When the airlines reduced their flight schedules by as much as 25 percent after the Sept. 11 attacks, they also cut discount flight operations and the favorite perk of very frequent fliers, the free upgrade to first class. The first major sign that low fares will be less available came in late September when United and US Airways said they would shut down their discount operations. 
United, the larger of the two, began shutting down its United Shuttle, which operated in the West using Boeing 737 jets with all-coach service and flew about 468 flights daily, a fifth of United's schedule. 
US Airways said that by December it would close down MetroJet, which began in June 1998 with flights from Baltimore-Washington in Linthicum, Md., using older Boeing 737-200's. MetroJet had grown to about 180 daily flights. 
Delta, the only other airline with a discount brand in addition to its mainline service, halved its Delta Express operations between 5 Florida cities and 15 airports spread from the East Coast to Kansas City, Mo. 
United Shuttle, MetroJet and Delta Express were created to compete against Southwest, the discount airline based in Dallas that has been bringing intense competition to many East Coast markets since 1993, when it started flying to Baltimore-Washington Airport. 
"These discount brands were innovative responses to Southwest," said Kevin Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition, an advocacy group that seeks lower fares and better service on behalf of major corporations. "Losing United Shuttle and MetroJet is bad for travelers in general and means a big step backward in terms of competition.
"The cuts mean less competition, or no competition, on some routes," he said. US Airways, which has the industry's highest cost per seat-mile, did not just close MetroJet; it radically reduced all flights at Baltimore-Washington, yielding in its battle with Southwest, which has the lowest cost per seat-mile among major domestic airlines. 
The presence of low-fare carriers like Southwest and jetBlue, while a boon to those using their routes, is not a free lunch. Comparing international service at Baltimore-Washington with Dulles, where United dominates and where jetBlue is trying to make inroads, provides an example of the effects on air travel of discount versus mainline carriers. High-fare Dulles offers service to 21 foreign airports, as opposed to 8 at low-fare Baltimore-Washington. 
Passengers are also finding that the airlines are replacing many Boeing 737 and Airbus A-320 single-aisle jets with smaller, regional jets or even with turboprops, which usually fly at less than 15,000 feet, where the ride is often bumpy. 
When Boeing and Airbus jets are withdrawn, road warriors lose their favorite perk: the upgrade to first class. The smaller planes have just one grade of service, and on most of the regional jets and turboprops the seats are narrower and less comfortable than coach seats on larger planes. 
And these regional jets and turboprops are replacing jet service in a number of cities. US Airways, for example, cut weekday service between La Guardia Airport and Rochester from four mainline jets, one junior, or regional, jet and three turboprops to just three flights, on two turboprops and one junior jet. It has since added back one large jet on the run. 
United is replacing Boeing 737's on flights from Los Angeles to Oakland, Phoenix and Tucson, for example, with 50-seat Canadair Regional Jets. 
In late September Delta announced a major shift in its route structure that will mean that far more passengers flying to its hubs in Atlanta, Cincinnati, Dallas-Fort Worth and Salt Lake City will fly on junior jets instead of mainline jets. 
The major carriers are switching to the junior jets as fast as their contracts with pilots -- and the production lines at the makers of regional jets -- will allow. Jamie Baker, the regional-airlines analyst at the UBS Warburg investment house, said that their share of the airline market is sure to rise because they can operate a regional jet for about half as much per hour as the Boeing and Airbus jets that they replace. 
The shift to smaller planes with only coach service makes sense given a drop of more than one-third in demand for air travel, said Clifford Winston, a transportation economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
 "The consistent issue for the airline business is matching capacity to demand," he said. Airplanes must be ordered years in advance, and when demand exceeds capacity, the airlines can charge top dollar and many people have to fit into middle seats. But when demand drops suddenly, as it did after Sept. 11, the airlines must park planes and fire workers and shift to smaller planes.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
When the 'Art Film' Label Is Deadly

BYLINE:  By STUART KLAWANS; Stuart Klawans is the film critic of The Nation. A collection of his reviews and essays, "Left in the Dark," will be published in January by Nation Books.

 BODY:
THE distinguished Italian writer and director Gianni Amelio has posed any number of riddles in "The Way We Laughed," not least of which is this: how do you get four elephants into a Fiat? I promise an answer before this article is done. First, though, I must ask a question of my own, since "The Way We Laughed" is finally opening in New York on Wednesday. Why did it take three years for this wonderful film to get here from Italy?
 To appreciate the complexity of the puzzle, you should know that Mr. Amelio earned a high reputation in the 1990's -- and mounting success at the international box office -- with "Open Doors," "Stolen Children" and "Lamerica." He then took the top prize at the 1998 Venice Film Festival with "The Way We Laughed," his third picture to star the lanky and resourceful Enrico Lo Verso, who is Sicily's answer to Jeff Goldblum. 
 In the role of a southern Italian laborer who moves to Turin in the 1950's -- a man like thousands of others entering a newly industrial economy -- Mr. Lo Verso turned in a performance of quirky, unsettling intensity, which Mr. Amelio and his cinematographer, Luca Bigazzi, captured in gorgeous, deep-colored images. The storytelling was ingenious; the characters were subtly drawn and engrossing. As for the theme -- the moral costs of prosperity -- "The Way We Laughed" ("Cosi Ridevano") proved to be all too timely. It revisited the beginnings of the 60's economic boom, just as the high times of the 90's were about to end.
"I'm sure this is my best work till now," Mr. Amelio said of the film recently, communicating by e-mail from his home in Rome. Although he, too, was born in the south -- Calabria -- and moved to Turin in his youth, the 56-year-old Mr. Amelio has avoided autobiography in "The Way We Laughed." Even so, an undercurrent of strong personal feeling runs through the picture. "It moves me more than my other films," he said.
Yet despite having all this in its favor, "The Way We Laughed" languished without United States distribution. When the American Museum of the Moving Image in Queens asked a critics' group last year to help choose a series of the most neglected movies of the 1990's, this writer did not hesitate to name "The Way We Laughed," both for itself and for the situation it represents. Imagine the problems faced by foreign films with lesser pedigrees. Why did this movie have so much trouble reaching our screens? What do its difficulties tell us about the fortunes of international cinema and about ourselves as an audience?
The answers start with the irony of success.
"The Way We Laughed" had the misfortune of being introduced at the 55th Venice festival, which was, like the previous 54, an occasion for Italy to show off its cultural products. By 1998, though, with Italian film in sharp commercial decline, proclamations of its "rebirth" gave off a hollow, grating sound to visiting journalists, especially those who'd taken to grousing against the festival circuit as such. Some influential writers, dismayed at the chasm between art cinema and popular movies, had begun to accuse festivals of promoting willfully unpopular films, made by self-validating auteurs who were addicted to government subsidies. In the eyes of these critics, the Venice festival was now guilty not just of drum-beating but of "cultural protectionism."
When, through no fault of its own, "The Way We Laughed" won the Golden Lion, it, too, became guilty, by association. Critics on the Lido spoke darkly of back-room deals and fixes. The festival's director, Felice Laudadio, might have responded by supporting his nine-member jury, only one of whom was Italian, or by pointing out that this "art film" had been produced by a media baron, Vittorio Cecchi Gori. Instead, Mr. Laudadio chose that moment to resign from the festival, declaring on his way out that prize-giving is "stupid."
Considering what had happened to Gianni Amelio, Mr. Laudadio could have skipped his proposal for abolishing the Golden Lion. Just rename it. How about the Exploding Cigar?
That Mr. Amelio had wound up with a faceful of ash may be seen from the press reports. Italian critics at first derided the notion that Mr. Amelio should be made a standard-bearer for their national cinema and then, in the next breath, complained that he hadn't raised the flag high enough. "Amelio's film met with a barrage of hostile criticism," Silvana Silvestri wrote recently in the English journal the New Left Review. Ms. Silvestri, a reviewer for the Rome newspaper Il Manifesto, maintains that the film gave offense by recalling "the world of poverty from which we have come -- a period in our past relegated by an entire nation to a kind of collective amnesia."
"The Way We Laughed" does not deliver what is now the conventional account of southern immigration to the north -- a story about quasi-exotic peasants who suffer tragically but are full of life. Instead, the film dramatizes the normal but none-too-pretty business of acquiring wealth and becoming middle class. Although set in the past, the film is really about today's audiences and how they have come to be sitting in those red plush seats.
"Now we are rich -- and arrogant -- without any memory of our past, of illness and poverty," Mr. Amelio says. "How much have we paid to achieve our affluence? Is it possible that in searching for material comfort we have lost something -- humanity, bravery, civic valor?" Because "The Way We Laughed" asks such questions, it is "not a comfortable movie," he says. "There's nothing nostalgic, sweet, exotic or rhetorical in it. It's maybe pitiless even in its most moving moments." It's also so strenuously honest as to have its characters speak in dialect. That was another reason the film caused a scandal in Italy: audiences had to read subtitles, in effect to understand themselves.
Some American critics had a separate set of objections. Writing from the Venice festival in Variety, the publication that most strongly influences potential United States distributors, David Rooney repeated the rumors of a jury fix, while heaping scorn on "The Way We Laughed" for being slow, confusing and opaque. (I would describe it as stately, intricate and nuanced.) These traits, of course, are markers of the suspect "art film." What Mr. Rooney and many others wanted instead -- what they'd been demanding since 1994 -- was a European "Pulp Fiction": something quick, sexy and violent, with big, cartoonish characters, a hip soundtrack and just enough foreign flavor to seem chic to Americans. That's what the 1998 Venice festival delivered with "Run Lola Run," a picture that Mr. Rooney praised as highly as he put down "The Way We Laughed."
So here was Mr. Amelio's dilemma: he hadn't made the hot new thing, nor had he faithfully imitated the classics. (True, he evoked Luchino Visconti's 1960 film, "Rocco and His Brothers," but only to mark the route from which he'd diverged.) The first audiences sat before the screen as if waiting for a different movie to appear. But for those who were willing to look, there were marvels on view, chief among them the devastatingly tangled relationship at the film's heart.
The illiterate Giovanni (Mr. Lo Verso) comes to Turin one day in 1958 to visit his schoolboy-brother Pietro (Francesco Giuffrida), the deeply beloved younger child, the hope of the family, the protected one. Some love, some hope, some protection. When we first see Pietro, he's already half-suffocated beneath the weight of Giovanni's self-sacrifice. (The aggression becomes visible when the brothers embrace: Mr. Lo Verso is so much bigger than Mr. Giuffrida, both physically and as an actor.) When Giovanni decides to remain in Turin -- purely for Pietro's sake, of course -- the boy's breathing room collapses altogether.
In developing this relationship, Mr. Amelio creates just the right time and space for the characters. You're given leisure to discover on your own the fragility beneath Pietro's nasty surface, the ice within Giovanni's generosity. As for space: Mr. Amelio's fluid, wide-screen compositions are a sustained essay in how to integrate figures with their world.
Here is a beautiful yet self-effacing style, put at the service of an emotional content that is wholly accessible. (How many millions of us have experienced family love as an unpayable debt, or education as the pressure to make good at any cost?) Yet, at the same time, "The Way We Laughed" is as studied as a movie can be. Film history references abound. (Decode as many as you like.) Social critique comes across with diagrammatic clarity. The film's structure -- which divides the story into six discrete chapters -- is the work of a teasing mathematician.
In short, those who want an art cinema with a populist heart -- or a popular cinema with brains -- need look no further than "The Way We Laughed." It turns out to have been the "Purloined Letter" of the Venice festival: the sought-after item that was so prominent, it was ignored.
Then, early in 2000, Dan Talbot of New Yorker Films took a second look at "The Way We Laughed" after its screening at the American Museum of the Moving Image. Mr. Talbot had long been a supporter of Gianni Amelio's work, and he now revised his judgment. "The financial aspects began to look more manageable," he explains.
By this time, other people as well were rethinking "The Way We Laughed." "Three famous Italian critics sent me a letter after their second viewing," Mr. Amelio says, "telling me they had changed their opinion for the better." The videocassette release in Italy has been successful, he adds, and the home-video distributor predicts that the DVD will also do well.
So the story may turn out to have a happy ending -- provided, of course, you don't think about all the other worthwhile films that go begging for an American audience. The structural problems of foreign-film distribution, which doomed "The Way We Laughed" in advance as an art film, have not improved since 1998. Still, in a world where good news is in short supply, we might as well be glad for "The Way We Laughed."
Mr. Talbot has added a grand new item to his company roster of Gianni Amelio's films, which already included "Open Doors" and "Lamerica." Mr. Giuffrida has gone on from his teenage debut to become a busy and well-regarded actor. Mr. Lo Verso, too, has been working, even playing a small role in "Hannibal." (I'm sure the check came in handy.) And over the past two years, Mr. Amelio has made documentaries, directed radio plays and written a script about a young couple with a disturbed son. "This will be my next movie, I hope," he says, "with shooting to begin in March 2002."
That accounts for everyone but the elephants.
It is now time to consider why, at both the beginning and end of "The Way We Laughed," characters ask how you can get four elephants into a Fiat. The answer has to do with the film's title, which was also the name of a feature in the magazine Domenica del Corriere. To illustrate how much society had changed in only a few years, people would write in with mossy jokes, which to their present amazement they had once thought funny. So now you know: two in the front, two in the back.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
A Certain Look The Camera Sold

BYLINE:  By VICKI GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
IN the 1920's, technology and business boomed in America. Production, media and advertising all gave new meaning to the word "mass." A complete Model T Ford rolled off the line every 24 seconds. Movie attendance climbed from 60 million in 1927 to 90 million in 1930. Magazines, newspapers and radio reached unprecedented audiences; so did fashion. Both mass and elite publications covered haute couture extensively, while the manufacture of ready-made clothing leaped ahead. Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, locked in a duel, both surged in circulation.
 It was possible to produce much more than people needed, so they had to be convinced to consume more. Photography, itself a medium quite at home with mass production, was called into service. By the end of the 1920's, photographs had begun to replace engraved fashion and advertising illustrations, making the camera a major purveyor of consumer goods and styles. At the same time, both fashion and celebrity were becoming conspicuous mass-market commodities, a situation to which photography had already contributed heavily. 
 Two men, George Hoyningen-Huene (1900-68) and Horst P. Horst (1906-99), figured prominently in this enterprise from the end of the 1920's. The Museum of Fine Arts here is currently honoring both in "The Look: Images of Glamour and Style, Photographs by Horst and Hoyningen-Huene" (through Jan. 6). This show, elegant in content and installation, is enormous: more than 70 pictures by Huene (as he was commonly known), more than 170 by Horst, plus some 20 photographs by other fashion photographers -- the two H's influenced almost everyone -- and a few items of furniture, decorative objects and clothing of the time. The section devoted to Horst is an expansion of a show of his portraits at the National Portrait Gallery in London; the Boston show was organized by Anne Havinga, the museum's curator of photographs.
Huene (pronounced HEW-neh) worked for Vogue and Harper's Bazaar but gave up fashion photography after World War II, which he thought had destroyed elegance. Later, he acted as an adviser on Hollywood films. Horst photographed first for French, then for American Vogue from 1931 to 1991. Huene was his mentor, briefly his lover, and his lifelong friend.
Knowing what this show was about, I wore my best Balenciaga to the museum and got a new perm, but nothing was any use. The technical mastery of both photographers, their crisp and inventive designs and exquisite control of every detail of light and shadow, gesture and fold, took beauty and glamour to the nth degree. (Each had worked in art or design before taking up photography.) The pictures of men alone could make a woman feel like a frump. Huene, who was a baron and had a well-deserved reputation for arrogance, was slender, tailored within an inch of his life, adept with a cigarette and practiced at posing among the geometrical constructions of the time. Horst seen through Huene's eyes had the body of a young god in an Art Moderne context, and he may have posed for Huene's well-known picture of a couple in bathing suits on a diving board, which was actually a box on a Paris roof.
Even Cecil Beaton, got up as Elinor Glyn for a costume ball, was more ineffably chic than I, despite his slightly witchy makeup. Of course, Beaton had only to stand still, faultlessly arranged before an admiring lens, whereas I was traipsing about with plenty of temporary and permanent faults. But fashion pictures of every kind from most of the history of fashion photography have been laced with a soupcon of humiliation and a large pinch of hope (no, you don't look like that; buy the dress).
Huene's numerous pictures of fashionable women elaborately costumed for masquerade balls in the 1930's create the suspicion that society was indulging its most luxurious fantasies in an effort to ignore a looming conflagration. Really pricey couture continues to carry a whiff of the same, flaunting economic security, dominant status and often exotic flights of fancy. Of course, masquerade did not vanished with the 1930's. In a 1991 picture by Herb Ritts in this show, Madonna is disguised as an 18th-century extravaganza, her skirt extended from the hips like a knickknack shelf, her wig like a wave from "The Perfect Storm."
Huene's photographs have a contemplative air and are determinedly classicizing. Some have background images of Greek heads blown up to colossal size. He enshrined stasis as if it were a virtue, though it was closer to necessity: the view camera could not stop motion. He got around this by posing models lying down and seen from above, arranged like classical dancers with gowns wafting out on the breeze. Horst was inclined to more elaborate settings and a more dramatic sense of contrast combined with a more pronounced sensuality. He could flirt with Surrealism -- Dali occasionally collaborated -- and with wit, as when four full-size beautiful women check out a man reduced to the height of a toy.
Fashion photography in the 1920's and 1930's was largely confined to the studio; Huene and Horst exemplified the pristine formality at its heart. At the end of World War II, Conde Nast decreed that fashion photography should be more "natural," which meant more movement, more outdoor work, more location shots. Horst was never as comfortable outside as in his hothouse studio environment, but he continued to work, and his contrived and ceremonial, refined, aristocratic and highly designed style had a revival in the 1980's.
Most of the portraits by both Huene and Horst are just as explicit statements of style as their fashion photographs are. In fact, portraits and fashion photographs often were (and often still are) the same. Society women and European aristocracy were the first models; it was not till the late 1930's that Horst promoted the use of professional models with greater posing skills. In the high-end fashion magazines, they all managed to look wondrously and reassuringly wealthy while the Depression played out on the street.
Huene turned a full-length portrait of Baron de Meyer, the fashion photographer whose soft-focus compositions were superseded by Edward Steichen's graphic boldness in the 1920's, into an exercise in Art Deco design. Horst set the Princess Marina, dressed in a gown that flowed more rhythmically than the Danube, in front of a column and a painting by Veronese, bestowing on her the somber grandeur of a work of art.
Marlene Dietrich leaned over the back of a chair for Horst, her arms on either side of an image of a classical male nude on the chair back. Through the magic of Horst's lights, her face seemed to glow from within, its slow curves set off by the pointed black halo of her hat and the angular shapes of her black suit. 
Huene and Horst, like fashion photographers and celebrity photographers generally, were boosters. They cleverly, gorgeously boosted both clothing and people into an empyrean of endless beauty, desirability, perfection or renown. The women (and some men) in their pictures were essentially manufactured and collectible objects, impeccably designed. Some were social constructs, some devised by the fashion industry, some the product of cinema or publicity machines, all refabricated as Images by the camera. Many of those Images were meant to inspire consuming passions, and, by George, they worked.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION; 
The Spin War

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Television, Like the Country, Loses Its Footing" by Caryn James Nov. 4 :
Television has not shown any actual, mangled, dead bodies of the victims of the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks. 
I don't recall seeing one (and I am sure I would have remembered it).
 This is to be expected, you may say, and thank heavens for it. But wait. People in the entire world see buildings burning and falling down -- buildings that symbolize American economic and military power. This is entirely too abstract when close-up images of destroyed individual people in Afghanistan are distributed. As a result, the image war is spun in our opposition's behalf, for they do not have the hesitancy of good taste and decorum and respect for the families of the victims that we do. In this sense, television is failing us.

JOSEPH NECHVATAL
Manhattan

HEADLINE: Mayor Must Now Campaign for Real Power 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
EDDIE PEREZ, the newly elected mayor of Hartford, the first Latino mayor of a capitol city in New England, campaigned for and won an office that hardly exists. By city charter, the office is more ceremonial than substantive, but Mr. Perez, a child of welfare, the first high school graduate in his family, the first college graduate in his universe, has never let what is, determine what will be.
 Charter reform will be his most important priority when he takes office Dec. 4 because the city needs a strong mayor form of government, he said. Although city residents voted on Nov. 6 to increase the mayor's salary from $30,000 to $75,000, they defeated a charter change last spring to install a strong mayor government. If it passes in November 2002, Mr. Perez will already be halfway through his term in a city where statistics are grim. 
 Hartford is the poorest city in the state, with 28 percent of its residents living below the poverty line, according to statistics from the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. 
Eleven of the state's 28 worst performing schools are in Hartford; in 1997 the state took over its board of education. Its population has decreased by 13 percent from 1999 to 2000. This year crime is down 4.1 percent, but 2000 saw an increase of 9.8 percent.
Perhaps only a man who lived it, coming of age on Bellevue Street in the city's scrappy north end, saved by the urban safety net of a loving mother, a few reliable neighbors and committed parish priests to graduate from its most prestigious college, can grasp both the difficulty and possibility of change.
"I've traveled the continuum, and I've learned there's something constant about the human spirit," Mr. Perez said, as he sat in the living room of his house, a blue colonial on Bloomfield Avenue, not far from the University of Hartford.
It was a Saturday morning and although Mr. Perez is nursing a cold, if he weren't attending the Veteran's Day Parade in another hour, he might be repairing a driveway or lingering over breakfast with his wife, Maria, and his daughter, Sierra, a freshman at Bulkeley High School. His son, Eddie Jr., is a senior at the University of Connecticut.
Right now Mr. Perez has little time to relax. A charter reform committee will be established shortly after he takes office, he said. Its report will be due in April to begin a six-month public education campaign in time for the November 2002 referendum question.
Mr. Perez, a Democrat, was elected with the help of $200,000 from many of the city's largest corporations and the support of its Democratic party. Four new Democratic councilors won election this year and each one has publicly stated he will support a charter change.
His administration will focus primarily on three areas: housing, where Mr. Perez said he wanted to add at least 500 new owner-occupied units to the city; public safety, preventing rather than reacting to crime by adding 40 to 50 new police officers, and building and repairing schools. He recently told The Hartford Courant that Adrian's Landing, the $1 billion downtown revitalization project, won't prevent him from seeking as much state and federal money as he can to accomplish these goals.
Mr. Perez, 43, is president of the Southside Institutions Neighborhood Alliance, a housing program that bought up decrepit homes using grant money, tore them down and built new ones, offering low-income loans to the working poor in the city. Public safety is a top priority of his constituents, as are schools.
Mr. Perez said he believed schools have to be the center of the community, with room for adult education and youth recreation programs. He will work with the superintendent of schools, the State Board of Trustees, and the business community to help insure jobs for high school graduates. What Mr. Perez won't do, he said, is spend a lot of time pointing out who is right and wrong.
"My responsibility is making the system just and efficient," he said.
Mr. Perez moved to Brooklyn from Puerto Rico when he was 9. He was 14 when he moved to Hartford. He is the second oldest of nine children in a household headed by his mother, who spoke only Spanish. Mr. Perez said he translated for her at the welfare office or at school conferences. The neighborhood was the center of his world. "I never felt poor," he said. "When I played stickball on the street, I thought I'd be in the major leagues someday." 
As a high school student who enjoyed the sciences, he guessed he would be a lab technician at a local hospital. For a time, he was a member of a street gang, but in the early 1970's a priest at Sacred Heart Church persuaded him to join a youth group and introduced him to the concept of social justice.
Father Thomas Goekler took a group of neighborhood teenagers to protest in Groton at the nuclear submarine base and to North Carolina to rally for the Wilmington 10, protesters who had been jailed. Another priest, Father Peter Rosazza, now Bishop Rosazza, whom Mr. Perez called "the poor people's priest," who made his rounds on a bicycle, taught him to remember the neighborhood.
Ultimately, Mr. Perez made his name in the neighborhood, working in the Stowe Village Housing Project on welfare-to-work programs before founding a neighborhood organization for housing and employment advocacy.
A summer job at Trinity College, Upward Bound, a federally financed program to help minority students go to college, began his relationship with Trinity, but it wasn't until he was 29, when he and his wife, Maria, had a boy, 13, and daughter, 2, that he decided to finish what he had started at a local community college and enroll at Trinity, taking courses part time before graduating in 1996 with a degree in economics.
It was at Trinity, where he was first the assistant to then president Tom Gerety and later Evan S. Dobelle, where Mr. Perez saw what could be accomplished with the resources of influence and money. Trinity, an elite college, sits in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods. 
"Trinity is a microcosm of Hartford and of most of America," Mr. Perez said. "It is an elitist institution set in a neighborhood that had third world problems."
Mr. Perez was introduced at university cocktail parties as the "right-hand man" of Mr. Dobelle because he had an ability to get things done and knew how to work with the neighbors as the college grappled with problems of campus safety and plans to expand despite disgruntled neighbors. Last year, Trinity, using money from the state private and corporate donations, completed the Learning Corridor, a complex of four public schools that is the jewel in the crown of its neighborhood revitalization effort. Mr. Perez was in charge of creating more owner-occupied housing in the neighborhoods that surround it. He made his name accomplishing the task.
Today, city residents eye him expectantly. Their neighborhoods differ, but their goals remain the same: homes that are safe and clean, good schools and a responsive City Hall.
Mr. Perez recalled a recent afternoon during his campaign when he was exhausted and had been knocking on doors for four hours. A little girl, maybe 3 years old, answered the front door, and he asked if her mother was home.
"She turned and called up the stairs, 'Mama! Es el alcalde!' (It's the mayor.) That really motivated me. If this tiny kid knew who I was, I thought, maybe she'll think she can grow up to be the mayor. Maybe she'll even believe she can grow up to be the president."

HEADLINE: Your Home; 
For Co-ops And Condos, Rising Costs

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
AT this time of year co-op and condominium boards meet with property managers, accountants and real estate specialists to figure out how much money they are going to need next year. And the experts are saying that the answer is likely to be more, maybe a lot more, than this year.
 Among the items that they say are expected to be responsible for the increase are insurance, property taxes and the salaries of building employees. 
 "In this market, the cost of insurance is increasing every day," said Carla Vel, co-president and chief executive officer of the Distinguished Programs Group, a Manhattan company that develops insurance programs for commercial and residential buildings. "And it's not just the increased premiums that are causing a problem, it's that it's becoming more difficult to buy all the coverage you need." 
Ms. Vel said that since about last December, property and casualty insurance premiums in the city had been "firming up" -- in other words, rates had been slowly increasing. After the attack on the World Trade Center, the trend has "fast-forwarded," she said, to a point where rates are now undergoing a "major firming" and some buildings could soon see their insurance premiums double. "Just a couple of weeks ago I would have said that increases would range anywhere from 30 to 100 percent," Ms. Vel said. "But now, even the 30 percent figure seems too low."
Robert E. Mackoul, president of Mackoul & Associates, an insurance broker in Long Beach on Long Island, said he believed that premiums for buildings that are considered poor risks could increase even more -- by as much as 300 percent.
"What we're seeing right now is just the beginning of the effects of Sept. 11," he said, referring to the stunning losses insurance carriers, and the reinsurance companies that insure them, have experienced as a result of the World Trade Center disaster. "The whole thing hasn't fully played out yet, and no one has a crystal ball to tell us where this is going. We could really be in a crisis situation by early next year."
Mr. Mackoul said that in New York, insurance companies licensed by the state must send out notices to customers if rates are going to increase by more than 10 percent. "And we're seeing a lot of those notices going out," he said. He added that in addition to charging higher rates for insurance, companies can use other methods to increase premiums. For example, he said, insurance carriers frequently offer good customers credits, or discounts, that result in the customers paying somewhat less. By eliminating or reducing the credits, Mr. Mackoul said, the carrier can charge more without increasing the rate.
Another way an insurance company can get more without raising rates, he said, is to require increased coverage. Since many policies are written on a replacement-cost basis, meaning that the company will pay whatever it costs to replace the entire building in the event of a catastrophe, the company can reassess that cost and demand an appropriate amount of coverage if the existing coverage is not considered sufficient.
"If a carrier takes away your credits and demands increases in the building's coverage, it can get 25 percent or more in additional premiums without even raising the basic rate," he said. 
One way an insurance company can charge more while providing the same amount of coverage is to change the customer's rating basis. If a carrier reclassifies a customer from a super-preferred tier to a preferred or a standard tier -- classifications established by the insurance companies that are based on the age and condition of the building -- a higher rate can be charged, Mr. Mackoul said. 
"That can be a huge difference," he said, because the difference between a super-preferred and a standard tier can represent a premium increase of 30 percent or more.
Finally, Mr. Mackoul said, in some cases buildings previously considered moderate risks -- those that have not filed an unusually high number of claims -- are now considered poor risks, because of the changing economy. And in some cases, he said, the carriers are simply declining to renew policies when they expire. "Insurance companies are doing whatever they can to increase income and decrease claims," Mr. Mackoul said. "And buildings that may have been considered acceptable risks when the economy was thriving may not be considered acceptable risks now." And now, he said, "is not the time to be out there looking for a new carrier." 
He added that while it is always possible for a building to get insurance, doing so can be quite expensive. "There will always be replacement carriers out there," he said. "But the premium increases are going to be enormous."
Matthew Newman, a senior vice president of Maxwell-Kates, a property management company in Manhattan, said that buildings that are well maintained and have the correct amount of replacement-cost coverage can expect increases of as much as 45 percent, while those that do not now have adequate coverage could see increases of 100 percent.
Another item next year's budget will have to address, the specialists say, is property taxes.
Mr. Newman said that given the enormous financial burdens New York City faces as a result of the Sept. 11 attack, property managers and financial experts are bracing for higher property taxes next year. And even if the actual tax rate does not increase, he said, the experts are preparing for higher tax bills as a result of increases in assessed valuations on their buildings. "We're expecting an increase of anywhere from 6 to 8 percent in the assessed valuation of our buildings," Mr. Newman said, referring to the requirement under state law that the assessment of every building must be re-evaluated at the beginning of each year. 
And while increases in assessments are phased in over five years, with one-fifth of the additional amount added each year, the result, Mr. Newman said, will likely be higher taxes for the tax year that runs from July 1, 2002, to June 30, 2003.
Abe Kleiman, a certified public accountant in Manhattan who specializes in co-ops and condominiums, said that his firm has been projecting tax increases of 5 to 7 percent, a range that takes into consideration both the additional taxes that may be due as a result of increases in assessments next year and increases already being phased in from previous years.
Mr. Kleiman said that another budget item that will likely increase next year is the building's payroll.
"Just based on the current union contract, salaries of building personnel are going to increase by about 3 percent," he said, referring to the contract negotiated between owners of multifamily residences and Local 32B-32J of the Building Service Employees International Union.
In addition, Mr. Kleiman said, some buildings are considering hiring additional staff members.
"I've been to a couple of meetings in the past few weeks, and it seems that shareholders and boards are a lot more concerned about security issues," he said, adding that some of his clients are now considering hiring doormen 24 hours a day, seven days a week. And while such additional expenses may be relatively minor when viewed in relation to an entire building's budget, he said, "they all add up."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Staten Island; 
New Hilton Hopes to Become Island's Meeting Place

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE Hilton Garden Inn on Staten Island has something that its counterparts in Manhattan lack -- outdoor space. The hotel, which opened on Sept. 15, is situated on 23 acres of land, much of it near protected wetlands, in the Bloomfield section of the western part of Staten Island.
 Much of the surrounding land has been developed as gardens, complete with original sculptures, walkways, waterfalls, gazebos and ponds with decorative koi fish. It is intended to be used for weddings and other social gatherings in good weather and as an attractive backdrop for the hotel during inclement times. 
 A hotel designed for Staten Island is different from one in Manhattan, said Richard Nicotra, co-chairman of the Nicotra Group, which built the hotel and the surrounding Corporate Park of Staten Island. His wife, Lois, is the company's other head. 
Because most visitors to New York City stay in Manhattan, the object there is to build as many guest rooms as the space will allow. But on Staten Island, a hotel is more of a place for social gatherings, like weddings and business meetings, and more of the emphasis at Hilton Garden Inn is on public spaces and less on guest rooms.
"We were convinced that there is more demand for conference and banquet space than there is for rooms," Mr. Nicotra said. "So we overbuilt the conference and banquet space and underbuilt the rooms."
The result is a building with an auditorium that can seat 1,000 people, five other meeting spaces with a total of 15,000 square feet and 148 guest rooms and suites. Sixty more guest rooms may be added on the uncompleted top two floors of the six-story building if demand warrants.
Tailoring a hotel to a local market makes a lot more sense than waiting for Manhattan to fill up and hoping to accommodate some of the overflow, observed Sean Hennessey, the director of the New York area hospitality practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. 
"That's what happened at the Marriott in downtown Brooklyn, which had a small number of rooms compared to its meeting space," Mr. Hennessey said. "They have had great success on the catering side of the house."
Because of the demand, the developer of the building that contains the Marriott as well as office and retail space, Joshua L. Muss, is seeking an agreement with city officials to add 280 guest rooms to the 376 in the existing structure. Mr. Muss said the centerpiece of the hotel was a banquet hall capable of seating 1,800 people, the fourth largest in the city.
Despite having a population of only 450,000, Staten Island is a free-standing market capable of supporting a hotel and meeting center with the Hilton brand, said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, a firm that specializes in hotels. "If one looks at Staten Island as a self-contained county, you note there is a lack of nationally branded hotel product," he said. "Staten Island is a vibrant community, and a hotel can be the focal point of a community."
However, Mr. Hennessey cautioned that just because a hotel is on Staten Island does not mean that it is not part of the New York market. "The challenge is that they may have Staten Island revenues but Manhattan costs," he said, because the property has to compete with hotels in Manhattan for personnel, particularly in management and culinary positions.
MR. NICOTRA said the rates for rooms at the hotel are $189 a night on weekdays and $169 a night on weekends, which is well below the pre-Sept. 11 average of more than $200 a night for hotels in Manhattan. 
But, he said, many of his hotel workers, including the top chefs, are residents of Staten Island and appreciate not having to make the commute to Manhattan. "People who live on Staten Island should not have to go to Manhattan to get good jobs," he said.
Mr. Nicotra is a native of Staten Island and a booster of the borough. He said that without the push by local residents willing to take on the financial risk of the project, national hotel chains would have continued to ignore the borough.
"We had this land and we spoke to Marriott and Hilton, but they didn't even want to take a look," he said. In the end Hilton was willing to sell him a franchise, he said, "and $35 million later here we are. No outsider would have done this. It took Staten Islanders who believed there are educated, classy people living here that will support something like this," he added.
Now, he said, Staten Island-based events can be held close to home. "There are almost half a million people on Staten Island, but until now, all the meetings and banquets went to New Jersey," he said.
Mr. Nicotra took something of a roundabout route to his current status as a hotelier. Indeed, it all began with yogurt. Starting in lower Manhattan, he built a chain of more than 200 Everything Yogurt stores, which have since been converted into Treat Street and Greenleaf's Grille restaurants.
He built his first office building at Corporate Park in 1992, partly to house his company, Restaurant Systems International, and partly on the speculation that other businesses on Staten Island would find Class A space desirable. "We built a 40,000-square-foot building and leased 10,000 square feet ourselves," he said.
The building did attract tenants, and Mr. Nicotra went on to build a total of 300,000 square feet of space in the 415-acre complex. In addition to the office space, he is building a shopping mall and is promoting another project that would be half office building and half another hotel.
"I'm building a village here," he said. When you own the village, you get to do things your way, such as naming a street in the park Lois Lane. And you can have an executive office that includes your wife and Lorenzo R. Nicotra, a 2 1/2-year-old Maltese dog. Lorenzo has his own business card, which lists him as chief executive dog. 
The new hotel he is planning in the complex would be strictly for lodging, without meeting space or food and beverage service other than a free breakfast, Mr. Nicotra said. The most likely brand is Hampton Inn, another Hilton Hotels Corporation property.
DEVELOPING the Hilton Garden Inn took almost five years from the time the Nicotra Group was designated by city economic development officials as the developer of a hotel until it opened on Sept. 15 -- appropriately, for a wedding.
The site of the corporate park was formerly partly occupied by a horse stable and an unofficial dump. "The whole area was a dumping ground before we got here," Mr. Nicotra said. "We took out over 5,000 tires and 50 burnt-out cars." He said his company worked with city officials to put up fencing to protect fragile wetlands and planted bushes and flowers on the median of South Avenue, which runs past the site, to improve the ambience of the area.
To capitalize on the hotel's relatively rural location in the city, there are large expanses of floor to ceiling windows in the main ballroom where people attending meetings can see the tranquillity of what appears to be a forest just outside.
"At night we light the trees," so the rural effect is not lost to darkness, Mr. Nicotra said. "We light them at 20 feet, 40 feet and 60 feet away."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard and Lois Nicotra with Lorenzo, chief executive dog, at the new Hilton Garden Inn in Staten Island. (Mary DiBiase for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Characters Flounder in Tough Love and Denial in 'Country Girl'

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE 

 BODY:
IN the mid-1930's, the name of Clifford Odets stood for social protest in the American theater.
 But by 1950, when he wrote "The Country Girl," now at Fleetwood Stage in New Rochelle, political idealism had been diverted by the profit motive. The specter of sentimentality diminished Odets's once-defining theme: the effects of materialistically induced stress on the spirit and soul of man. 
 More concerned with ego preservation than economic pressures, Odets shaped "The Country Girl" as a display piece for three major players who know precisely what the fight for the spotlight means, and he achieved the commercial hit he craved. But since the play is not the thing here -- it's rather more an accompaniment for three soloists -- it's a long shot for a small regional theater. Call it no win for Fleetwood Stage. 
No devotee of Odets will concede that he had forsaken the common man. But here that man was a somebody on a downward slide, being primed, pampered actually, to reclaim stardom, if he can "stay sober and learn lines." 
Frank Elgin, a fallen star, lands a general understudy's job, and that's only because Bernie Dodd, a rising star in the directorial ranks, remembers and cherishes Frank's glory days. Subtly, the play's real star turn falls to Georgie Elgin, Frank's downtrodden, maligned wife, trapped in a contest between the controlling, abrasive Bernie and her desperate husband. 
Will Frank, an unrecovering alcoholic who stashes away over-the-counter cough syrup (22 percent alcohol ) get it together or a triumphant comeback -- in the nick of time during a touch-and-go Broadway opening night after a disastrous Boston tryout?
Tune in next week, one is tempted to say.
With Bernie at war with Georgie, Frank battling his own demons and Georgie struggling to survive, Fleetwood Stage is set up for no contest. No one wins. 
Buzzwords like tough love and denial sum up Bernie and Georgie's persistence and Frank's resistance. But such short-cut paths to truth were a thing of the future in 1950. That makes it easier to embellish the stuff of soap opera with hifalutin themes like the rescue of one artist by another, the redemption of a fallen man through the love of a woman.
Given our psychologically enlightened age, it takes uncannily gifted actors to explore such self-sabataging characters, and divert us from their simplistic ways.
Yet the offstage explosions of Mr. Peters sound like out-of-control tantrums, not impassioned acting. How is one to know that Frank was -- still is -- a commanding actor who can create a character so indelibly that his performances are linked to legend. 
Poor Georgie is consigned to elevating self- abnegation and enslavement by love to an affecting level of human vulnerability and heights of superhuman sacrifice. At the mercy of unsightly costumes, to the discredit of the listed designer, Karl A. Ruckdeschel, Ellen David fails to provide character progression. Unwilling to play the victim, and rightly so, she has yet to find a compensatory alternative. 
It is important to believe in Bernie's memories, in his insistence on possibilities. Victor Barbella does not help us to believe that. More temperamental than passionate, his shifts seem caused by mood swings, not artistic temperament. The actor is playing a stock director-type whose gruff manner is no mask for dedication to theater art.
Fleetwood's actors cannot justify a star-driven play. Mr. Peters plays an overly indulged whiner with an adolescent mean streak, not even an interesting challenge or useful case study. Ms. David's Georgie suffers, by means of inflection, indication and gesture. What is on the inside, we'll never know, especially since the director, Gene Minkow, punctuates her final moment with an all too obvious, contextually inappropriate and altogether irrelevant feminist exclamation point. That is known as saving the worst for last.
"The Country Girl" by Clifford Odets. Produced by Fleetwood Stage, 44 Wildcliff Drive, New Rochelle. Performances through next Sunday. Box office: (914) 654-8949.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Peters, left, Victor Barbella and Ellen David in "The Country Girl," a play by Clifford Odets at Fleetwood Stage in New Rochelle. (Minkow)

HEADLINE: LABOR; 
Office Cleaners Seek Pact in Slow Economy

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
CISERON CIRIACO calls himself one of "las personas invisibles" -- the invisible people. The 62-year-old New Rochelle resident, who speaks only Spanish and has six grown children, leaves his home for work at 7 each morning. He goes to a shoe repair shop in Port Chester, where he works all day. Then, he goes to an office building in Armonk to clean at night. Getting home at midnight, Mr. Ciriaco sleeps for a few hours before returning to the shoe shop and then, again, to the cleaning. 
 While the terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center hit a symbol of the rarefied echelons of American capitalism, those in low-paying jobs have sustained the worst financial blow. According to a report from the New York State Department of Labor, those who work in low-wage industries like restaurants, transportation, retailing and hotels have suffered a high proportion of job losses since Sept. 11. In Westchester County, this comes on the heels of a five-year period in which, though the economy was expanding rapidly, low-wage job growth did not follow. In 1995, for example, 5,521 people worked in department stores. By 2000, that number had decreased by 1,152. 
 It is in this environment that Mr. Ciriaco's union, Service Employees International Union 32BJ, must renegotiate a contract with a dozen cleaning contractors for its 2,000 commercial office cleaners in Westchester. The union now also includes the Westchester cleaners, who were members of Local 32E. Contracts for most of its members expired Oct. 31. Negotiations are now under way. 
In a surprise development, Local 32BJ reached a tentative agreement for their New York City workers this week, seven weeks before the contract was to run out, due, both sides said, to a joint determination not to add to post-Sept. 11 anxiety. 
Currently, for his nights spent bagging garbage, vacuuming carpets and dusting other people's desks, Mr. Ciriaco is paid $6.30 an hour and receives no benefits. 
In the coming contract, Mr. Ciriaco wants only "a just wage and health benefits."
"Medicine and doctors visits "are so expensive," he said. "And it's so hard to spend time with your family when you work so much. But you have to provide." 
Michael P. Fishman, the union's president, said that a standard wage and benefit package was also important, because as it stands now without one, 80 percent of workers are compensated differently and thus compete against one another. While Mr. Fishman understands that the economy is slow, he is hopeful that an agreement can be reached and a strike avoided. A portion of his hope is because "people are more generous with each other since Sept. 11 and now is not the time to be squeezing an extra nickel out of workers pockets." 
But Robert Kaestner, an economist and a professor at the Institute of Government and Public Affairs at the University of Illinois at Chicago, said that while such action would be decent, the words Local 32BJ will probably hear most frequently at the bargaining table: "The country is sacrificing and this is how you're going to sacrifice. We'll give you yours when times are good." 
He said that a big reason for businesses relocating to the suburbs from the city is to save on such costs. As such, the likelihood of big concessions isn't great, especially since the cause of low-wage, mostly immigrant workers probably won't resonate with the Westchester public. 
Larry Colin, of Colin Service Systems in White Plains, one of the cleaning contractors, reached by phone last week, declined to comment on the status of the negotiations.
Asked if he sees a strike, a satisfying settlement or something in between, Mr. Ciriaco, the invisible person, could only laugh softly. "We'll see that very soon. I don't know."

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
An Old-Fashioned Job Hunt

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
EILEEN MORAN, an aspiring fashion designer, thought she had the right formula for success. She would attend a prestigious college, graduate with a degree in marketing and small-business entrepreneurship and then land a job with an independent fashion house or start her own company.
 It hasn't quite worked out that way. Although her passion is designing children's fashions, she earns her living these days as a freelance buyer of yarn for Ralph Lauren in New York. "It seems like people who want to work with smaller, innovative companies are forced to work for these big guys, which is not what I want," said Ms. Moran, 23, who graduated last year from George Washington University and lives in Jersey City. "Big companies are laden with bureaucracies and red tape." 
 Her story is familiar to many young people in the post-dot-com, post-Sept. 11 world. Gone are the days of fat paychecks and stock options, of leapfrogging from start-up to start-up or becoming a chief executive before the age of 30. Gone are the days of instant gratification. 
Because of the weak economy and the tight job market, "competition is high and people are going to have to go back to working their way up the ladder," said Jan Dinerstein, president and founder of the Dinerstein Group, an executive search firm in Manhattan.
"The entrepreneur who doesn't have life experience or wisdom is gone," she said. "You need to have some very real-world experience to deal with this economy, and you need to know how to run a profitable company."
But doesn't all that sound like the days of yore, when references, networking and healthy doses of nepotism helped to land jobs? Indeed, old-fashioned job-searching tactics are making a comeback, so young people may want to pay close attention to what the experts have to say.
Anne Maxfield, co-owner of Project Solvers, a New York firm that finds freelance and full-time employees for retailers and apparel companies, says it is more important than ever for job hunters, especially those without much experience, to do their homework. "Do background research so you know the company as well as anyone who works there," she said. If you're looking for a job in fashion, for example, become familiar with what's in the stores, she added. 
Career experts also advise young job seekers not to bother sending out their resumes en masse, especially when so many companies are no longer opening unsolicited mail because of the anthrax scare. Instead, they suggest focusing only on companies that are actually hiring by scouring the help-wanted advertising of newspapers and trade publications or job listings on the Internet. Job seekers should find out if their resumes are going to a human resources department or to a specific department head. "If it's for H.R., it's got to be much more conservative, straightforward and corporate, whereas for a department head you can be more creative," Ms. Maxfield said.
THE rules of conduct have also changed. And career experts offer these additional suggestions: be on time for interviews, turn off your cellphone, make eye contact with the interviewer and, please, proof your resume for spelling or grammatical errors. 
But don't take a job that doesn't thrill you, even if it means collecting unemployment a little longer.
"People give up too easily looking for what's really making them happy," said Linda Sedloff Orton, president of Intelligent Marketing Solutions, an outplacement firm in Manhattan for marketing professionals.
"Historically, in an economic recession, everybody says you have to be flexible," she said. "I'm saying, 'Don't let someone push you into a job that you're not going to be happy in.' Find out what's really going to charge you and do it."
Sometimes, fate intervenes and nudges the process along. Last month, Emily Retterer, 27, was laid off from her job as a project manager for Hubbard Online, a Web development agency in New York. Even while she was employed, however, she was unclear about her career goals and was enrolled part time in a master's program in elementary education at Hunter College. Since the layoff, she has had time to re-evaluate her plans and now realizes that she really wants to teach.
Today, she attends school full time and works as an assistant first grade teacher at a private school for boys in Manhattan. 
"It was an amazing company and a great group of professional, wonderful people, but I wasn't passionate about being a project manager at a Web development agency," she said of her previous job. "I thought, 'Why am I wasting my time in a position that's meaningless?' "
As for Ms. Moran, she still hopes that her less-than-idyllic day job strengthens her resolve to pursue her dreams in clothing design.
The situation "fuels your power and energy into doing something on your own," she said, and to "be ready when the economy swings back."
