HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE; 
Preserving Stuyvesant Town As a Shrine to the Ordinary

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
Changes are afoot at Stuyvesant Town. So is a movement to stop them. Last week, the Historic Districts Council announced its support for designating Stuyvesant Town a landmark. Now, its tenants must decide if they want to approach the Landmarks Preservation Commission. 
 Stuyvesant Town, between 14th and 20th Streets from First Avenue to Avenue C, was built by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to provide inexpensive housing for World War II veterans. It has remained largely unchanged since it opened in 1947. 
 "Stuyvesant Town has endured," said Corinne Demas, who wrote a memoir, "Eleven Stories High," about growing up in the complex. "It's like this old person who has seen the whole span of things."
But since MetLife began renovating formerly rent-stabilized apartments and renting them at market rates early this year, residents have feared the demise of their pastoral middle-class community. 
Proponents of landmark status say that Stuyvesant Town embodies the values of postwar America, and that while the buildings may be architecturally bland, the complex as a whole is a rare oasis of trees, curving paths and green space.
"I was born here and grew up here," said Alvin Doyle, president of the tenants' association. "I'm used to seeing the trees and well-manicured lawns, and clean walkways, and well-kept playgrounds, and on Saturday afternoons the seniors sitting on benches and the children playing in the playgrounds. That's what I want to preserve."
This week, the tenant group will begin to form a committee to look into the landmark question. Of course, although landmark status can protect a physical community, it cannot prevent economic changes like the looming rise in rents at Stuyvesant Town. But making such a complex a landmark would not be unprecedented. Three East Side housing projects -- the City and Suburban Homes Company Estates, the First Houses, and the Harlem River Houses -- have been granted landmark status.
This year, MetLife embarked on a $50 million project to improve the playgrounds, security booths, lighting, signs and landscaping at Stuyvesant Town and adjoining Peter Cooper Village.
The company says the project will not substantially change the way Stuyvesant Town looks. Mark Keeney, a MetLife vice president, said the company did not yet have a position on the landmark question, but, he added, "If it would detract from what we think is a win-win situation for tenants, which is $50 million in improvements at no cost to them, it would not be something we were in favor of." ERIKA KINETZ

GRAPHIC: Photo: Built to provide inexpensive housing for World War II veterans, Stuyvesant Town has remained largely unchanged. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times) Chart: "SAMPLER: On the Town"Grounds -- Stuyvesant Town was built on a portion of the old Gashouse District, which contained a large Armenian enclave, a condemned motion picture theater, foul-smelling gas tanks and tenements. Construction -- The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company spent $114 million to build the middle-class housing complex. About 500 buildings were razed and 3,000 families relocated. Size -- Stuyvesant Town covers 18 square blocks and has 3 dozen buildings, 36,500,000 bricks, 40,000 tons of steel, 8,755 apartments and about 25,000 residents. Sales pitch -- From an early advertising brochure: "The green lawns, the garden, and the trees that surround your home are sentimentally linked with the past . . . Your home is not called Stuyvesant Town by chance. The name itself breathes the spirit of old New York." Veterans -- Of the original tenants, more than 98 percent were World War II veterans and their families. Design -- Lewis Mumford said Stuyvesant Town has "the architecture of the Police State." Paul Goldberger has written that the buildings were "hardly imaginative, but not hostile either." Income Limits -- In 1999, the minimum household income for a one-bedroom apartment was $50,000. This year, it is $80,000.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Another Terror Victim: Health Care

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LONG before the economy started to sink, before terrorists crashed planes into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, before Cipro became part of the popular trademark lexicon, American health care had major problems. Now there are new twists.
 In New York, hospitals are reeling from the financial losses incurred after the attacks. Many of them made purchases to care for patients who, sadly, never came out of the World Trade Center. Hospitals also lost revenue when many patients canceled elective surgeries and other procedures immediately after the attacks. 
 Especially hurt are hospitals close to ground zero, but others lost equipment and supplies in the rubble, too. And hospitals around the country have also been enduring financial blows.
"We have heard about volume drops immediately post-Sept. 11 across the country as elective surgeries dipped," said Martin Arrick, a director at Standard & Poor's. Referring to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, he added: "In New York City, many hospitals have costs that are expected to be reimbursed by FEMA or other grants. However, no one expects that volume lost over the long term will be recovered if patients feel they do not want to travel into Manhattan for care. This is certainly unknown right now."
National issues have cropped up as well. The climb in unemployment has contributed to an increase in the number of uninsured Americans -- and just as the federal government was making progress in reducing their ranks.
According to a recent report by the Commonwealth Fund, 37 percent of unemployed people are uninsured, and more than one-third of the workers who lose their jobs lose their health insurance. The uninsured rate among unemployed adults is nearly three times as high as it is in the general population -- 37 percent versus 14 percent, according to the report. And many of the uninsured will undoubtedly find the cost of buying individual health insurance prohibitive.
Medicaid is an option for some of them, but that raises costs for states and cities, which help foot the bill. The Commonwealth Fund study asserts that an increase of two percentage points in the unemployment rate could add some 3.3 million people to Medicaid under current eligibility rules, at a cost of $5 billion for one year.
The government is finding itself with new and, in some cases, unexpected increases in health care costs. In New York City and New York State, health departments have spent millions to augment laboratories and to pay staff members to work around the clock to analyze samples and to perform other public health tasks. New York City has spent about $8 million since Sept. 11 -- all at a time when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is calling for cuts of up to 15 percent per agency in the city's budget. 
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has also devoted many staff hours to dealing with the anthrax issue. Some analysts predict that states affected by the anthrax attack may face increases of 2 percent to 8 percent in health care costs as a result. Also on the federal agenda is the development of new antibiotics, and possibly vaccines, to deal with bioterrorism threats. The government and the private sector can be expected to go head to head over who will bear those costs.
"Nationally, health care costs, broadly defined, will go up somewhat as costs of security rise and emergency-preparedness costs rise." Mr. Arrick said. "This would be general readiness as well as bioterrorism preparedness, and would include additional costs for stockpiling of medicines, staff training costs, large numbers of requests for screening of potentially fatal illness."
"Certainly, public health expenditures will rise," he added. "This is a traditionally underfunded sector."
MENTAL health costs are also climbing, with percentage increases possibly reaching double-digits for cities and companies across the nation, but especially in the Northeast. Many employees are seeking these benefits, analysts and consultants say, and New York City has offered them free to anyone who wants them. Some therapists, however, are providing services pro bono.
All of this comes at a time when insurance premiums were already on the rise. In many cases, workers are looking at having to pick up some of those costs, and premium increases for some companies are now more than 15 percent. 
Congress and local leaders will have to consider whether revamping the public health system and increasingly reimbursements to hospitals under government insurance programs are now part of the war on terrorism. It will be interesting to watch.

HEADLINE: Now Boarding, Dreams 

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
AS American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo plunged into a row of well-tended houses on a quiet middle-class street in Belle Harbor, Queens, killing 260 people on board and 5 others on the ground, another American Airlines flight to the Dominican Republic was en route to a much happier ending. 
 Flight 621, which had left Kennedy International Airport about 7:30 a.m., was cruising over the Atlantic east of Florida, heading to the country's second-busiest airport in the resort city of Puerto Plata. Like Flight 587 and countless others before it, Flight 621 was filled with Dominican New Yorkers heading home to celebrate holidays, visit relatives, attend weddings or conduct business in their homeland. 
 Among the passengers aboard Flight 621 was Arsenio Fernandez, a 41-year-old chef from Washington Heights who was on his way to visit his wife, Ana, and other relatives in his hometown, Tenares. The couple had married two years earlier, but after a time in New York, Mrs. Fernandez, 35, returned home to take care of several businesses her family owned. 
Not every one of New York's 600,000 Dominicans travels back regularly. Some have severed ties with the homeland. Others simply cannot afford a trip that can cost more than $600. But countless thousands go as often as they can, some every month. There are 51 direct flights each week, even more in December, mostly on American. It is estimated that 1,000 to 1,500 Dominicans make the trip daily.
The ritual begins weeks in advance with the frantic purchase of gifts on streets like Broadway or West 207th Street in Upper Manhattan, the heart of New York's Dominican community. It ends in small towns like Tenares; the bustling capital, Santo Domingo; or mountain villages. Then there are the embraces, the opening of the presents and a traditional meal, which, even if prepared with ingredients available in New York, tastes better on the island.
For many Dominicans in New York, these journeys home are the defining metaphor of their complex push-pull relationship with their homeland; they embody, vividly and poignantly, the tug between their current lives and their former selves. That fact gave Monday's tragedy a particularly horrible resonance for New York's Dominicans.
"These trips are crucial from the spiritual, sentimental and definitely cultural point of view," said Ramona Hernandez, a sociologist who will become director of the CUNY Dominican Studies Institute in February. "The Dominican community is very poor -- more than one of two households live below the poverty line -- but that doesn't matter. They'll save every single penny to go there on Christmas or on summer vacation."
The trip home is such a mainstay of life for Dominicans in New York that it is a fixture in Dominican songs, movies and fiction.
"It's a flight of so many dreams," said Angie Cruz, author of the novel "Soledad," whose title character makes the trip with her mother. "You're in a place with a lot of family stories. It's comforting, exciting and sad."
Balbuena: "Let's continue placing orders. Peje, your turn. What do you want?"
Peje: "My sneakers. And remember, I take size 10."
Balbuena: "How many pairs?"
Peje (pausing): "Five."
Balbuena: "How many pairs? Don't be shy, it's New York, man!"
-- From the film "Nueba Yol III," in which the main character, Balbuena, remembers what his friends in the Dominican Republic asked him to bring back from New York after he has gotten rich there.
Especially for immigrants whose families back home count on them for economic support, getting ready to travel to the Dominican Republic means collecting items for those back home. Many families keep an eye out for sales and store up used clothing and household goods throughout the year, packing them away in closets. The last few weeks, activity heats up.
First come the suitcases. Virtually every Dominican packs two, the legal limit. But since most of what is in the suitcases is left in the Dominican Republic, suitcases are sometimes left behind too. That makes luggage sales big business in Washington Heights. A typical shop is La Casa de las Maletas (the House of Suitcases), on West 181st Street near Audubon Avenue, a bustling place where cheap luggage of all sorts hangs outside the storefront, covers the sidewalk and is stored in a nearby van. Suitcases start at $5.99.
There are also plenty of cheap presents: $15 jeans, $3 flipflops, a lipstick 12-pack for $2.99, clearly intended for the multitude of cousins and neighbors who do not make the gift A-list. People start stocking up in earnest in October in preparation for the surge of holiday flights. 
"They go by the paycheck," said Jimmy, the man behind the cash register at La Casa de las Maletas. "Every week they buy a little." 
A few blocks away, at the Luz Maria Corporation, pants start at $2, shoes at $5. These are the gifts for the more economically minded travelers. But because many in the Dominican Republic are so label-conscious, Dominicans here who can do so buy Tommy Hilfiger and Banana Republic, even though nearly everything sold in the United States is available on the island. 
Packing is a balancing act. Since suitcases weighing more than 70 pounds will be rejected, many families pack, weigh their bags on a bathroom scale -- and repack.
A typical scene:
"Get rid of those shoes!"
"No, they're for Alberto!"
"Get rid of that skirt!"
"No, it's for Amarilis!"
"Get rid of the soap!"
"No, it comes 10 to a package. We can give it out to everybody."
Danilo Ramos, a Dominican building superintendent from Bedford Park, the Bronx, said: "You try to bring something for everybody: some socks, a liter of whiskey, shoes, soap, toothpaste, perfume. The last week is really hectic. The last night you don't sleep. At dawn, you're still running from one place to another, because the last thing you get to is packing your own clothes."
Mr. Fernandez, who was picked up for Flight 621 by his nephew at 4 a.m., is a seasoned traveler and did not go overboard when it came to gifts. A cook at Frank's Trattoria near Gramercy Park, he brought perfume, shoes and clothes for his wife and half a dozen family members. His wife's family is relatively prosperous and thus less dependent on relatives in New York. Still, his suitcases were packed tight.
"From above, Dominican Republic looks like a sequined dress. When the wheels hit the ground, we feel the vibrations on our behinds. The plane explodes into a concerto of applause filled with gratitude to the captain, who managed to fly the plane safely from one side of the water to the other. As I walk into the airport, I can bite into the humid air. It's so thick and smells like wet soil and rum. We survive the luggage inspectors, getting through their thorough search without having to bribe them. Feeling triumphant, I walk my mother out to the waiting area."
-- "Soledad," by Angie Cruz
Especially for those making their first trip back since emigrating and for factory workers who have scrimped for years to afford the fare, looking one's best is essential. Even those who have fared badly in the United States sometimes borrow money and clothes to pretend otherwise. 
Many travelers dress formally, the men with fresh haircuts, the women too. Boys wear shirts and ties; girls are in frilly dresses, brilliantly polished white patent leather shoes and ruffled socks that make them look like flower girls at a wedding. Once on board, mothers carefully spread napkins over their children's laps to avoid spills and vainly urge their offspring to sit still, lest they wrinkle their pretty clothes.
Almost everybody flies American Airlines, which holds a virtual monopoly on the New York-Dominican Republic routes. Even before Monday's crash, Dominicans had developed a complex love-hate relationship with American, complaining about high prices and baggage restrictions even while favoring the carrier over other airlines that used to travel the same route. 
Passengers start lining up long before the first boarding call, and the atmosphere on board is so festive, flight attendants sometimes struggle to keep passengers seated until the "fasten seat belt" sign goes off.
"Since everyone knows one other, from the beginning people start talking and talking," said Kinito Mendez, the popular merengue singer who had made the trip so often he featured it in his and Johnny Ventura's song "Flight 587," later released as "The Plane."
"The guy next to you says, 'Hey, we'll see each other there, we'll go buy some whiskey, a bottle of rum,' " added Mr. Mendez, whose former manager, Papi LaFontaine, died in Monday's crash. 
Ms. Hernandez of the CUNY Dominican Studies Institute added, "Why do you think they would want to be sitting in a chair just doing nothing?"
Flight 621 was in many ways typical. But back in Washington Heights and in the Dominican Republic, it only started out as an ordinary morning. The Fernandez household of St. Nicholas Avenue, which is headed by the 62-year-old family matriarch, Carmen Fernandez, went about their business as usual. The adults hurried off to their jobs. Ms. Fernandez stayed with her grandchildren, home from school for Veterans Day. She was half-listening to the news when she heard about the crash. 
"My God," she said afterward. "I don't want to remember that moment."
First, she went to look for Jonathan, Arsenio's son, 13, who had gone to his room after a traditional Dominican breakfast of yuca, salami and eggs. Then the phone began to ring as Arsenio's six brothers and sisters began calling desperately: Freddy from the French restaurant where he worked; Gisela, a secretary at United Cerebral Palsy of New York City; Enma, a designer at 1-800-flowers.
Carmen Fernandez rushed to Daysi Travel, a few doors down, where her son had bought his ticket. The family was well known at Daysi, one of many small agencies that serve the neighborhood. Mr. Fernandez used to stop in every day to take advantage of the 15-cent-per-minute rate in the international phone booths to call his wife, Ana, who worked in the agency when she lived in New York. Carmen Fernandez asked the woman behind the plastic divider what flight her son had been on. It was Flight 621. She breathed a sigh of relief. 
Panic was also flooding over Arsenio's family in Tenares. His wife was in Cafeteria Charlie, one of the family businesses, when she heard the news. Although she knew her husband was booked on the Puerto Plata flight, she was terrified; she was aware that if one plane is overbooked, passengers will sometimes get on the next one.
Meanwhile, on Flight 621, Arsenio Fernandez sat quietly and sipped a soda.
"Everything was just fine," he said afterward, "because we didn't know anything."
"Let me confess: I love Santo Domingo. I love coming home to the guys in blazers trying to push little cups of Brugal into my hands. Love the plane landing, everybody clapping when the wheels kiss the runway. . . . Love the redhead woman on her way to meet the daughter she hasn't seen in 11 years. The gifts she holds on her lap, like the bones of a saint. . . If this was another kind of story, I'd tell you about the sea. What it looks like after it's been forced into the sky through a blowhole. How when I'm driving in from the airport and see it like this, like shredded silver, I know I'm back for real."
-- "The Sun, the Moon, the Stars," by Junot Diaz
 As the plane starts its descent, things quiet down. Many people pray. 
A merengue band is generally on hand, and representatives from the three B's of the Dominican rum industry -- Barcelo, Brugal and Bermudez -- wait outside the gate offering small cups of rum to debarking passengers. 
Watching passengers walk from customs into the public waiting area makes non-Dominicans wonder if relatives can possibly love one another as much as these people seem to. When a person has not been back in years, there are sometimes so many relatives, they arrive in a rented bus.
"They hug you, they bite you, they pinch you, they jump all over you, they do everything," said Mr. Ramos, the building superintendent from Bedford Park. "Ten people hug you at once. It's like when a team wins the World Series, everyone jumping all over one another at the same time. You don't know who to embrace first."
"The airplane arrived
This is Flight 587, destination Santo Domingo
The airplane arrives full with bursting suitcases
It arrives full of hope
Also full of joy
To spend the Christmas season with my people
And look and see if more can fit
To take it to my mother
I'm taking seven suitcases
And this is not enough!
Hey Kinito, how many suitcases?
This is unprecedented, Ventura!"
-- "The Plane," Kinito Mendez and Johnny Ventura
Upon arrival, relatives who couldn't make it to the airport are waiting eagerly. The suitcases are treated with great care; in many ways, they are the most visible, tantalizing symbols of the American dream made flesh. Food is served, perhaps a grandmother's famous sancocho, the traditional Dominican stew. Neighbors arrive. Ice-cold Presidente beer flows freely.
Unlike the approach to the Santo Domingo airport, the flight to Puerto Plata comes in over water. The plane drops dramatically to the runway of the Gregorio Luperon International Airport, which nestles between the sandy beaches of the resort town and the verdant Isabela de Torres mountain. Passengers climb down the stairs and cross the tarmac to the terminal, pass through customs and are hugged by friends and relatives who had watched the landing from a partly enclosed balcony. 
But the arrival of Flight 621, which touched down at 11:58 a.m., was different. If possible, the greetings were more heartfelt. They were also more solemn, for every Dominican was touched, spiritually if not directly, by the doomed flight. There was no free rum this day. There was no merengue group. 
Mr. Fernandez's friend, Ramon Collado, who was waiting to pick him up, had called Ana Fernandez as soon as the plane landed. But the real relief did not come until after the 75-minute drive to Tenares.
Embraces were followed by an order: call New York. Just after 3 p.m. New York time (4 p.m. Dominican time), 11 hours after Arsenio had left for the airport, the phone rang in his St. Nicholas Avenue apartment. Carmen Fernandez was on the verge of tears as she spoke to her son.
"Oh, dear Lord, were you scared?" she asked.
"You can't be scared of death," her son replied.
Gifts were not handed out until the evening, although long before, Arsenio had had his favorite meal -- rice, peas and beef -- and a Presidente straight from the freezer of his father-in-law's supermarket.
It was a subdued reunion. A relative of Arsenio's father-in-law had just missed Flight 587. But the family knew of one other person from a nearby town who had not been so lucky.
In New York, even as Dominicans mourned, they kept booking flights. Rivas Travel at 184th Street and Broadway sold 37 airline tickets the day of the crash, said its owner, David Rivas. Just as Sept. 11 had little effect on ticket sales, neither did Nov. 12. 
"For the Dominican to go to Santo Domingo during Christmas and summer is like the Muslims going to Mecca," Mr. Rivas said. 
Ms. Hernandez, the sociologist, added: "Family for us is not just mother, father, sister. It's cousin, cousin of cousin, the neighbor who saw me grow up. They are the extended family. That's what makes us who we are."

HEADLINE: Airlines and Antitrust: A NewWorld. Or Not. 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT is one of the worst periods in aviation history.
 Hijackings and catastrophic crashes. Bankruptcies and buckets of red ink. Tens of thousands of laid-off workers and billions of dollars in a government bailout that may not be enough. Sharp reductions in passenger travel and scheduled flights at a particularly vulnerable time in the economic cycle. 
 Will all this lead to a new wave of airline consolidation? Should it be allowed? Whether or not the predicament of such a vital industry should prompt a reconsideration of fundamental antitrust policies is suddenly a matter of urgent debate. Although the industry had already shrunk significantly before the current crisis -- four airlines control two-thirds of the domestic market, and five global alliances control three-quarters of international travel -- some major deals, like the proposed acquisition of US Airways by UAL, parent of United Airlines, were blocked earlier this year. Is it time to rethink the traditional approach to airline mergers, strategic alliances and cost-sharing partnerships? 
The weakest airlines are quietly on the prowl for stronger partners, and the healthiest ones are looking for new opportunities. Federal regulators are reviewing a proposed alliance between American Airlines, the world's largest, and British Airways, Europe's largest -- two of only four airlines permitted to operate the profitable, heavily traveled routes between American cities and Heathrow Airport in London.
The decisions of Washington policy makers about these deals could shape the industry, not to mention prices and consumer choices, for a generation. Here are the arguments put forward by each side.

The Old Rules May Not Apply
The airline industry, like the information technology and telecommunications industries, tends to evolve toward heavy concentration among few players because of the phenomenon economists call "network effects." In these industries, often characterized by high barriers to entry and heavy capital costs, a product or service becomes vastly more valuable the more people use it. The old antitrust principles do not apply easily because there are countervailing benefits to consumers -- like lower prices, standardization or more frequent service -- when control of the industry is in the hands of a few companies. 
"Everyone benefits by consolidated routes and more cross-country and transcontinental travel," said George L. Priest, a professor at Yale Law School. "And having these large national airlines aids that network effect. You'd still like to have competition over some range and for some routes. But you can't have it for all." It is simply too costly; ticket prices would soar to support the network.
American Airlines and British Airways are making that argument in their quest for immunity from antitrust prosecution in their proposed alliance, and supporters of the deal say it is even more relevant these days.
In testimony earlier this month before the antitrust subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Donald J. Carty, the chairman and chief executive of AMR, parent of American Airlines, noted that because of the industrywide decline in demand, "it does not make sense for any of us to fly the schedule we had before the attacks."
But the alliance, Mr. Carty said, would have offsetting benefits. "Antitrust immunity would not only allow us to be more efficient and cost-effective in the delivery of these services, but consumers would be big winners also," he said. "Quite simply, in this increasingly global economy, what our customers are telling us is that they want one-stop shopping. Immunity allows airline alliances to provide that, while at the same time it allows allied carriers to offer better and more competitive network services" -- like better connections and schedules.
He cited a study that suggested the proposed alliance would lead to consumer benefits, mostly in lower fares, of at least $40 million a year.
Other experts say that amid the present difficulties, there are broader policy reasons for considering lenient antitrust treatment of the industry.
During the Depression, the Supreme Court adopted an approach to antitrust that took into account the distressed conditions of one industry when it upheld a joint sales venture involving 137 producers of bituminous coal. "The interests of producers and consumers are interlinked," the court said in an opinion by Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes. "When producing concerns fail, when unemployment mounts and communities depending upon profitable production are prostrated, the wells of commerce go dry." 
Since then, as the goal of antitrust enforcement shifted exclusively to the promotion of competition, and as free-market advocates grew in influence, the distressed-industry argument has fallen into disfavor. .
But now some experts say American antitrust law should take a more flexible approach and, as in some nations in Europe and Asia, take into account the welfare of employees, shareholders, creditors and other constituents of a corporation.
"Antitrust ought to be about more than economics," said Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission in the Clinton administration and an authority on antitrust law. "It ought to concern itself with the welfare of workers, shareholders and so forth."
There is more recent precedent for such a broad approach. Concerned about the decline of media voices, the newspaper industry persuaded Congress in 1970 to grant a generalized exception to antitrust law and permit joint operating ventures involving financially weak newspapers. In the early 1980's, the Reagan administration allowed the merger of LTV and Republic Steel, the nation's third- and fourth-largest steel companies, because of that industry's distress.
Now some airline executives contend that the $10 billion recently approved by Congress for the airline bailout, to be spent by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, should encourage mergers because they would ultimately benefit consumers by preserving routes and lowering fares.
"In cases where some airlines don't pass muster, or can't perform well enough, or simply because it makes good sense, the loan authority board should promote -- and perhaps encourage -- combinations of carriers," said Leo F. Mullin, chairman and chief executive of Delta Air Lines, in a speech last week at the Wings Club in New York. "Consolidation is an accepted method in all industries of improving performance operationally and financially." 

The Free-Market Remedy
If the government promotes consolidation, either allowing mergers or using government money to help finance them, critics say, Washington bureaucrats, rather than the marketplace, will shape the industry. That, they say, could prove disastrous for travelers.
"This would amount to using a credit organization with no commitment to competition to potentially determine winners and losers based on capital allocation, a form of a national industrial policy," said Albert A. Foer, president of the American Antitrust Institute, a nonpartisan research organization. "Downsizing should be done incrementally rather than by a central decision. It is likely to be more efficient over the long haul if each airline makes its own decisions about what routes or equipment it wants to take out."
Mr. Foer and other experts say the present regulatory system is flexible enough to address the airlines' financial problems. Current rules do not consider an industry's overall distress, but there is an established antitrust jurisprudence for dealing with distressed companies. 
"You think about things differently," Professor Priest explained, "because if a company is about to go out of business, there are fewer competitive issues posed."
Supporters of current policy also note that the industry has already consolidated enormously, and they argue that the results have been detrimental to consumers. They point out that the airlines have a checkered history of price-fixing and other anticompetitive schemes.
"This is an industry that lost its competitive juices years ago, because the government did not crack down quickly enough on discriminatory practices at fortress hubs," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union. "Once antitrust goes awry and you mess things up, it's very, very difficult for antitrust to fix things later. It's good at preventing concentration in the first instance. But once you have highly concentrated markets and an intervening event like terrorism that changes the demand curve, antitrust can't offer a solution. It can't create competition that isn't there anymore."
Antitrust officials have stepped in to block deals when the proposed partners have too much overall market share, have overlapping routes or dominate a particular hub, leading to higher fares. If United had bought USAir, the government contended, there would have been monopoly or duopoly service on more than 30 routes.
Defenders of the current rules system also say that the industry is capable of fixing itself in the long run, that the crisis will eventually subside and thus should not be used as a pretext for encouraging further deal-making. The proposed alliance between British Airways and American, they say, is precisely the kind of deal that should be blocked, because the cost to competition will far outweigh any efficiencies. They say the effect of the alliance would be to eliminate competitors that offer lower fares for many flights across the Atlantic. The vigorous competition between American and British Airways between American cities and Heathrow has been beneficial for smaller upstarts like Virgin Atlantic.
"At a time when we may be witnessing a forced reduction in competition among airlines, it is madness to actually encourage even less competition by allowing dominant carriers to collude in setting prices and agreeing to schedules," said Richard Branson, the chairman of Virgin Atlantic, at the subcommittee hearing.
Richard Anderson, the chief executive of Northwest Airlines, added that "the anticompetitive harm flowing directly from the proposed American Airlines-British Airways alliance will be large and enduring."
American and British Airways are now archrivals in a number of major markets, and the proposed alliance would "increase concentration in amounts and to levels that vastly exceed the increases and resulting concentration levels deemed tolerable under the U.S. merger guidelines," Mr. Anderson said. The levels of concentration in some of those markets, he added, were significantly greater than those that would have been posed by a combination of United and US Airways.
"If granted antitrust immunity, instead of being each other's strongest competitor, American and British Air will cease competing with each other at all, and combine their market power to limit capacity and raise prices," he said. The pair, he said, now dominate routes between Heathrow and Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, Miami and New York.
More generally, the linchpin of airline deregulation was vigorous antitrust enforcement. If there is much more consolidation, some experts fear an absence of competition that could lead to a reintroduction of rate and scheduling regulations.
"If you boil the industry down to too few players," said Michael E. Levine, a former senior executive at three airlines and former dean of the Yale School of Management, "you will face some pretty ugly choices."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
What Detroit Can Teach Washington

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
THERE is an American city where powerful people have swiftly responded to the nation's first recession in 10 years. About a week after Sept. 11, they announced a new policy -- call it a stimulus package -- that has lifted the economy and probably prevented layoffs of thousands of additional workers. 
 The city, of course, is not Washington, where officials in the White House and Capitol continue to proclaim a stimulus plan crucial but still cannot agree on what it should be. 
 But 500 miles away, a group of profit-driven executives have stepped into the void. They work in Detroit, and they have provided a vivid example of just how effective an economic stimulus can be. 
On Sept. 19, General Motors announced that it would temporarily charge no interest on many loans, effectively cutting the price of a $25,000 car by more than $3,000. The move came on the same day that two members of President Bush's cabinet visited Detroit and urged industry officials to help the reeling economy. Ford Motor and the domestic division of DaimlerChrysler quickly took similar steps.
The deals remain in place for most models, and the results have exceeded nearly everyone's expectations. Despite mounting layoffs and a pronounced shift toward conservative spending habits, consumers bought more vehicles in October than in any other month -- ever. Across the economy, retail sales, which stopped growing during the summer and declined 2.4 percent in September, soared 7.1 percent in October, the government said last week.
The level of the response may have been surprising, but the reason for it was basic. "The car companies put things on sale, and consumers are responding," said Richard J. DeKaser, the chief economist at the National City Corporation in Cleveland. 
Knowing that the interest-free loans will not last forever, people have suddenly become willing to spend money that they would not otherwise. This is economic stimulus. Many of the proposals in Washington, by contrast, do almost nothing to alter people's calculations about whether they should spend money in the short term, economists say. And immediate spending is the key to preventing the economy from lapsing into a vicious cycle of layoffs, weak consumer spending and yet more layoffs.
With Detroit riding to the rescue, it is tempting to decide that Washington's dithering does not much matter. But as important as Detroit's stimulus has been, it is still not as helpful to the $10 trillion economy as a well-designed plan from Washington would be.
For one, auto sales will almost certainly fall sharply once the incentives expire. Cars will suddenly be more expensive, and many people who were considering buying a new vehicle will have already done so. While the government can pay the bills for a stimulus program by running a deficit, the auto industry may have to lay off workers, potentially undermining a recovery.
By their nature, the deals also require consumers to take on additional debt at a time when debt levels are already high and the weak economy is threatening the income of many people. Even a no-interest loan will create problems for somebody who does not have a weekly paycheck.
"I suspect a lot of people who bought Ford Explorers with zero-percent financing are going to regret it," said John H. Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.
BUT the zero-interest loans do offer a wonderful model for how the government could lift the economy. They are surely more effective than refunding taxes to businesses or reducing payroll taxes, as many members of Congress are now urging.
Imagine instead that consumers had a temporary incentive to increase their spending on all products, including everyday ones like clothing or toys that would not require a substantial increase in debt levels. Senators Patty Murray, a Washington Democrat, and Olympia J. Snowe, a Maine Republican, have offered just such a plan, proposing that the federal government reimburse states that suspend their sales taxes for 10 days during the holiday shopping season. The bill is unlikely to pass, Congressional aides say, because of the many logistical difficulties that it presents.
But the economic foundation for the senators' bill is far stronger than for many other proposals. If policy makers need a reminder of that as they try to negotiate a compromise stimulus bill, they can look out their office windows and admire all the new cars on the road.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
In Refinancing, a Chance to Manage Your Debt

BYLINE:  BY JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
WOULD you like to improve your monthly cash flow, wipe out some debts or have more money to invest? For millions of American homeowners in these days of low interest rates, those goals can be easily attained through a mortgage refinancing.
 Refinancings now account for a record 78 percent of all mortgage activity; their popularity has soared as mortgage rates have fallen in recent months. The rate on the 30-year fixed-rate loan, for example, stood at 6.51 percent last week. In the previous week, it was 6.45 percent, the lowest in 30 years of record-keeping. 
 Andrea and Richard Weinbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., decided to refinance their three-bedroom co-op on the advice of Anthony LoCascio, who runs Investment Counseling Inc. in Clinton, N.J. 
Since they bought the unit 10 years ago, it has gone up in value by about $80,000, so they are taking out $26,000 from the equity, known in the industry as cash-out refinancing. The money will let them to renovate their kitchen and bathroom, trade in a 10-year-old Honda Civic for a newer vehicle, pay off credit card debt with interest rates up to 17 percent and increase payroll deductions for retirement plans. "We're not day traders," said Mrs. Weinbaum, 44, a public relations consultant, adding that she and her husband, a 43-year-old computer analyst, "are very conservative people." 
Even though their home equity was reduced, their monthly mortgage payments will still be $10 below what they pay now. The Weinbaums worked through a mortgage broker, the Manhattan Mortgage Company, and are moving to a 6 5/8 percent, 30-year mortgage at Citibank from a 7 1/8 percent mortgage at Chase. The fees for the refinancing total $1,600.
Asked if he was recommending refinancing to many clients, Mr. LoCascio replied: "Absolutely. This is the cheapest form of money right now."
One of his clients had both a first and second mortgage on her home, car payments and credit-card debts. A refinancing that consolidated all that into one mortgage saved her $900 a month, he said.
Mr. LoCascio advises other clients, who have loans against their 401(k) retirement plans, to refinance their home mortgages at lower rates and to take out enough money to pay off the 401(k) loans and even to invest in retirement and college savings plans. "Keep the money invested," he said. "That's how you get ahead."
But he offered an important caution: "You don't want to do this and get into credit card debt again. This is for people who are disciplined."
As helpful as Mr. LoCascio's advice was to the Weinbaums and others, a homeowner does not have to go to a financial professional to reap big savings in a refinancing.
For starters, most people can obtain attractive mortgage rates and terms on their own -- if they are willing to shop around. Homeowners may want to approach their existing lenders first; in order to keep your business, they may be willing to waive some of the closing costs like appraisal and title search fees, which can save hundreds or thousands of dollars. With most mortgages, closing costs and terms are negotiable. 
Who should refinance? Traditionally, experts recommended the move to borrowers who could get a new rate at least one and a half or two percentage points below that on their existing loans. But in today's low-rate climate, many people are benefiting with a new mortgage that is only a half to three-quarters of a point below their present rate. Those who are planning to move to another home in the near future, however, should not refinance, because it may take several months or longer to recoup closing and other costs, which vary widely nationwide.
Jean and Anthony Letai of Medfield, Mass., just refinanced their home mortgage and home equity loan, taking out an extra $10,000 to pay off student loans, and still reduced their monthly payments by $400.
Dr. Letai, 36, an oncologist at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, did not have to pay interest on the student loans while he was in training, but after he became an instructor at Harvard Medical School, with which the institute is affiliated, the loans had a 9 percent interest rate, while his home mortgage was at 7 1/8 percent.
After the rate cut by the Federal Reserve this month -- the 10th this year -- Ms. Letai, also 36, found a 6 1/8 percent, five-year adjustable rate mortgage from Quicken Loans (www.quickenloans.com), owned by Intuit.
Terry Del Rosario-Heard, 43, a psychiatric nurse at Western Medical Center in Anaheim, Calif., and her husband, Edwin Heard, 43, an engineer who specializes in nuclear medical equipment at Adac Laboratories, refinanced two properties through Quicken Loans. The couple own a rental property in Dana Point, Calif., that has appreciated sharply in the four years since they bought it, and they took out $80,000, using part of it to buy a condominium in Manila for Ms. Del Rosario-Heard's mother. Then they refinanced their own home, again taking out cash, with the intent of buying more investment real estate. 
Ms. Del Rosario-Heard said they had moved to 30-year fixed-rate mortgages of 6 1/2 percent in the refinancings from adjustable-rate mortgages of 7 to 8 percent and would keep their monthly payments at $2,200 a month on the Dana Point property and lower their payment to $2,200 on their home. They were paying $2,700 a month for a mortgage and home-equity loan.
Daniel Gilbert, chief executive of Quicken Loans, said the Letais and Heards were among many refinancing applicants. "I've been doing this for 17 years, and this is the strongest demand I've ever seen," he said.
Mr. Gilbert said many families had used this strategy to lower their debt loads. "Consumers have managed the asset side of their balance sheet," paying attention to their investments, he said. "Now they are getting smarter and managing the debt side as well. For most people a home mortgage is the biggest debt." 
HOMEOWNERS should be aware, however, that in certain refinancings part of their mortgage interest may not be deductible. For example, when the refinanced loan exceeds the original acquisition loan and part of the proceeds of the new loan are used for an unrelated purpose like paying off a credit card, the interest attributable to that portion of the loan may not be deductible.
Some industry experts say that mortgage rates are at or near a bottom but that they will stay close to their record lows in the coming weeks. Even so, Mr. Gilbert said, "if you have a significant savings, lock it in."
"Don't be like the people who made the mistake of not selling their dot-coms," hoping the stocks would keep rising, he added.
He offered these examples of the possible savings: A homeowner with a $150,000 loan at 8 percent interest who refinanced at 6 1/2 percent would see payments drop to $948 a month from $1,101. Over the life of the 30-year loan, the savings would amount to $54,919. If that homeowner also had $30,000 of credit card debt at 15 percent interest on which he was paying $579 a month, his total monthly payments would drop to $1,138 from $1,680 if he retired that debt and increased his mortgage amount to $180,000.
Robin Korn, vice president for membership banking at American Express, which has an online bank and offers mortgages at www.americanexpress.com/mortgages, said many customers were seeking to reduce monthly payments or to take money out of an appreciated home for purposes like remodeling or education. But others, she said, were "shortening the terms of their notes to coincide with retirement." 
Suppose that the homeowner with the 30-year, $150,000 loan at 8 percent moved to a 15-year mortgage at 5 7/8 percent. A calculator on the American Express site shows the payment would be $1,256, up a bit from $1,101, but the payoff time would be halved. 
Steve Garrett, manager for financial planning at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, said some homeowners were using the low interest rates not to refinance but to trade up to a more desirable home -- one that was larger or in a better school district -- while keeping monthly payments level.
And given today's faltering economy, Mr. Garrett suggested that anyone fearing a layoff at work should lock in a lower mortgage rate or a home equity line of credit. 
Not every homeowner benefits from refinancing, he said. An important consideration is the number of years remaining on your present loan. The way mortgages amortize, the payments in the early years are mostly interest, while those in the later years pay off the bulk of the principal. As a result, he said, "it does not make sense for a person who has only five years left in a 30-year mortgage to refinance." 
Even though rates have crept up, "there is definitely a buying opportunity," he said, advising people who were contemplating refinancing or trading up. "Now is the time to pull the trigger."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Champagne Houses Waiting Nervously For the Corks to Pop

BYLINE:  By ALICE FEIRING

 BODY:
MARILYN MONROE was rumored to bathe in it and Noel Coward claimed to drink it for breakfast. Napoleon and Churchill sipped it to toast battlefield victories. For generations, bottles have been uncorked to bless marriages, christen ships, honor job promotions and add a bit of seductive decadence to an intimate moment.
 But now Champagne, the effervescent drink of celebration that represents one-fifth of all French wine exports, is suffering from what could become a prolonged slump in the United States. The economic downturn, year-end corporate austerity, the Sept. 11 attacks and a resilient threat of terrorism have left fewer people in a festive mood. 
 "Except for weddings, no one is ordering Champagne," said Liz Neumark, president of Great Performances, a New York caterer to big corporations and special events whose largest client is now the Red Cross. "They're afraid of being perceived as too 'happy' in a time of mourning." 
It may be premature to write off 2001 for United States sales of Champagne, which is sometimes considered the poinsettia of the wine industry here. Nearly half of annual American sales are made in the weeks from Thanksgiving to New Year's Day -- a sharp contrast with France, where 60 percent of Champagne is consumed, and with Britain, the biggest Champagne export market. Sales have been little affected in those markets, where Champagne is more of a routine drink, and not only for special occasions.
But anecdotal evidence so far of a sales slump in the United States, the second-biggest export market, has unsettled many Champagne houses, wholesalers and retail merchants.
"It's fair to say sales are not doing very well here," said Jean-Louis Carbonnier, a wine consultant in New York and a former director of the Champagne Wines Information Bureau, a French trade group. Even if sales pick up somewhat for the holidays, he said, "I don't think anybody expects these holidays to be especially celebratory."
Harper's, a British weekly wine trade magazine, said in a report dated Nov. 1 that Champagne exports to the United States were down nearly 50 percent in the first half of this year, compared with the same period of 2000. That was because so much unsold Champagne was already on store shelves -- a vestige of the excessive amounts imported for millennium celebrations.
"If the second-half figures for 2001 are as bad," Harper's said, "there will be several major houses looking for an alternative market for more than 10 million extra bottles of fizz."
Last Monday, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's largest luxury goods company and parent of famous Champagne houses like Veuve Clicquot, Pommery, Krug and Moet & Chandon, issued its third profit warning in two months, saying the Sept. 11 attacks had seriously weakened its sales in the United States. No breakdown was given, but wines and spirits account for 20 percent of LVMH's revenue. 
Many American companies that once routinely ordered hundreds of cases of Champagne for holiday parties have drastically scaled back or eliminated their celebrations. David Adler, the president of Bizbash.com, a party consultant based in New York, estimated that the New York catering industry alone had lost $1 billion since Sept. 11, much of it from corporate party cancellations.
Marketing has been a problem for Champagne makers, who worry that they might seem crass or insensitive by encouraging people to forget their worries with bottles of bubbly.
After the September attacks, for example, Pommery pulled a Miami advertising campaign for its Pommery Brut. "It seemed the wrong time to launch a campaign focused in a vacation-tourist destination," said Dacotah Suter, the brand's United States manager. "Given the emotional environment, we thought consumers were not in a mood to be 'seduced' by Champagne advertising."
Some houses reluctantly went ahead with promotions that seemed aloof to the country's collective pain. Mireille Guiliano, the chief executive of Clicquot, said that she was about to cancel some of its La Grande Dame Champagne dinners, at which famous chefs pair their foods with the prestige cuvee, La Grande Dame, but that participating restaurants asked Clicquot to keep them. "They told me, 'We need this now; please come,' " she said.
Others expect that they will need to spend more on advertising to stimulate sales. Bertrand Steip, a senior vice president at Moet & Chandon, said he had requested a larger ad budget for 2002. The House of Krug, which makes one of the most exclusive Champagnes, is considering ordering its first ad campaign.
NOT everyone, however, is avoiding Champagne. A scattering of restaurants have even reported an increase in orders since Sept. 11.
At Five Points, a neighborhood restaurant in Manhattan's East Village, sales of Champagne by the glass have risen 20 percent in the last few months. "Stranger than that," said Vicki Freeman, the co-owner, "we sold more bottles of Krug since the 11th than during the whole two years we've been open. I really can't explain it."
Nor are all sponsors of big celebrations canceling orders. Colin Crowe, a caterer with offices in New York and Los Angeles who specializes in celebrity parties in the entertainment industry, said he had just orchestrated a Los Angeles party with nonstop Champagne. In Chicago, Clicquot reported overflow attendance at its annual Halloween Champagne party.
Others say the decline in Champagne sales so far this year may be a false alarm. They say it partly reflects the oversupply in the United States during much of 2000.
There is also evidence of steady, albeit modest, demand for expensive Champagne at small, private functions. Alison Mesrop, a New York caterer who specializes in groups of fewer than 125, said that unlike caterers who specialize in large events, she is pouring lots of Champagne. And one New York club, which did not want to be identified, recently ordered a large quantity of Pol Roger's Cuvee Sir Winston Churchill, at $175 a bottle, for a member's party.
However, it would take many small gatherings to make up for the absence of the huge holiday parties to which the industry has grown accustomed.
Retail sales figures offer little insight into how the full year will go. A.C. Nielsen, a Chicago-based research firm that tracks consumer spending, said grocery store sales by volume of all sparkling wines in the United States, a category that includes Champagne, had fallen sharply since Sept. 11. 
There is no reliable way to track Champagne sales at wine shops. Sherry-Lehmann Inc., a leading retail wine merchant in New York that can be an indicator of broader trends, said that Champagne volume sales fell 35 percent in September, compared with the month a year earlier, then rebounded in October. But Michael Aaron, Sherry-Lehmann's chairman, said dollar sales from Champagne were down, which shows that consumers are buying less expensive brands. 
Many are turning to nonvintage Champagne, which, unlike the vintage variety, is made annually regardless of the grape harvest's quality.
Many Champagne houses anticipate they will have to accept price cuts if sales do not pick up. Tim Enos, president of Dreyfus Ashby & Cois in New York, the exclusive importer of Bollinger, said the Champagne Bollinger house "is not happy with this state of affairs, though the house understands that it cannot fully bind its importer, distributor and retailers to its desires."
Mr. Steip of Moet & Chandon said: "No one will be making their margins this year. If we are flat with last year, we are fine."
Others were also guarded in their outlook. "Champagne houses will trim costs and wait out the storm," said Jack Robertiello, editor of Cheers, a beverage industry magazine. "But nobody's going out of business -- that is, depending on how long the storm takes to blow over."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Luxuries Are Looking Like Durable Goods

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
EVEN in a tough economy, cachet counts. 
 It helps that those who value cachet most can still afford to pay for it. But after years of high living, luxury goods companies have suffered a bit recently. 
 Dana Telsey, a specialty goods retailing analyst at Bear Stearns, took some time last week to talk about the prospects of purveyors to the carriage trade. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. How big is the luxury goods market?

A. We estimate it is an $80 billion market, growing at an annual compound rate of around 6 percent. That is a couple of percentage points less than the growth the group enjoyed from 1998 to 2000, which was driven by a strong equity market.
There are six main categories of luxury goods: clothing, which accounts for 28 percent of sales; fragrances and cosmetics, which are around 24 percent; shoes and leather goods, at about 21 percent; wine and Champagne, at 15 percent; jewelry and watches, at around 7 percent; and home accessories, at around 5 percent. 

Q. Are margins on luxury goods higher than on merchandise at other retailers?

A. Gross margins on luxury goods can average around 60 percent, compared to more mainstream brands like Liz Claiborne, the Gap or Talbots, with gross margins of 40 to 50 percent. After expenses, operating profits at luxury goods companies are around 18 to 20 percent. On more mainstream brands it is 9 to 12 percent.

Q. How big is the universe of luxury goods stocks?

A. There are 50 to 60 smaller true luxury good companies, but there are about 15 to 20 publicly held companies, including Bulgari, Gucci, Hermes, LVMH, Tiffany, Richemont, which owns Cartier,and Coach.

Q. Last week LVMH, the French company that makes Louis Vuitton handbags and Veuve Clicquot Champagne, among other things, issued its third profit warning since Sept. 13. What is going on with that company?

A. LVMH has a very different business than most of these companies. A big part of their business comes from sales at duty-free stores, and right now traveling is not on the top of everyone's mind. The Japanese represent about 15 percent of total industry sales, and right now the Japanese are not traveling.

Q. You recently estimated that Japan accounts for as much as 45 percent of the global luxury goods market. How can that be, given the weakness in its economy?

A. In Japan, around 20 percent of households invest in the Japanese stock market, compared to 52 percent in the United States. So they are not as vulnerable to the stock market, which has been so bad for so long.
Second, real estate is very expensive in Japan, so homes are smaller. That means they can't show their wealth as much in their homes as in what they wear. Third, there is a portion of the population known as the office ladies, who live at home with their parents. The money they earn from their jobs is spent on brands. Finally, it is important to remember that Japan has the highest savings rate in the world.

Q. What is the condition of balance sheets at these companies?

A. The balance sheets are clean. LVMH is the most debt-laden, but Tiffany has a 19 percent debt-to-capital ratio, Coach is less than 10 percent and Gucci is less than 20 percent.

Q. What are the price-to-earnings ratios of luxury goods companies?

A. On average, the stocks are trading at about 22 times 2002 estimates. In the last five years, the stocks have traded as high as around 33 times. But the average multiple has been 18 to 19 times earnings.

Q. Will luxury goods rebound more rapidly than less upscale products?

A. We think a turn in the economy would be manifested a little bit earlier. Wealth among high-net-worth individuals has been growing. In the U.S., around 10 percent of the population earns about one-third of the disposable income. The negative impact on sales now is really likely to be more psychological than anything else, because the rich are still rich.

Q. Are holiday sales at these companies as important as they are for most retailers?

A. The holiday season is important, but it isn't as big a percentage of sales or earnings as it is for other formats of retailing. Rising unemployment is not terribly relevant to the luxury goods segment.

Q. So which of the stocks do you like?

A. Tiffany, Gucci and Coach are three of our favorite names. Each of these companies has room to continue to open more stores, which allow them to showcase their brand. Each has a strong balance sheet and can weather the economic times we are facing. And each has room to expand product categories.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
An Insider Shadow Looms Over a Stock's Party

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
ANYONE nostalgic for the heady days of the tech stock bubble can rest assured: pockets of euphoria do remain. A quick consultation with investing chat rooms shows that speculation is alive and well.
 Consider FalconStor Software Inc., a provider of storage networking software in Melville, N.Y. Even though the company is not yet two years old and has amassed $10.9 million in losses, it is a very hot number on both the message boards and in the market. FalconStor's stock price -- up 33 percent this year -- gives it a market value of $385 million. That's 40 times its annualized sales, based upon the $2.5 million it generated in revenue in the third quarter. 
 The company calls itself an emerging leader in "one of the fastest-growing areas of the $44 billion global storage industry." Most of FalconStor's top management hails from Computer Associates, a software company that is its neighbor on Long Island.
FalconStor was private until Aug. 22, when it completed a reverse merger into Network Peripherals, a 12-year-old company with no operations, also known as a publicly traded shell. One big investor in FalconStor, Barry Rubenstein, also served on the board of Network Peripherals. He is a principal at Wheatley Partners, a Long Island venture capital firm. He and Wheatley also own 45 percent of Network-1 Solutions, a microcap company in which FalconStor invested $2.3 million on Oct. 2. 
Network Peripherals agreed to the merger because it lacked the resources to compete in the storage networking market, said Jacob Ferng, FalconStor's chief financial officer. He called the merger "financial re-engineering" and explained that together, the companies' products held promise.
Although the stock is down 37 percent from a midyear peak, ebullient investors pushed it up 35 percent last week. They may not realize that 28 million shares held by insiders could come onto the market at any time and without notice. Given that the company has only 44 million shares outstanding, that's one heck of an overhang. 
In the merger, Network Peripherals' insiders agreed to a one-year lockup on the 28 million FalconStor shares they received. But, unlike most lockups, this one can be rescinded at the discretion of FalconStor's board. 
In May, when the merger was announced, shareholders were advised of the lockup release in regulatory filings. "Following the merger, the board of directors of the combined company may, in its sole discretion, release any or all of the shares from the lockup restrictions," the company said. 
On Sept. 21, FalconStor registered the 28 million shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission, allowing them to be sold any time. In this filing, the company changed its description of the lockup, adding that its release could come "at any time with or without notice."
On Friday, a company spokeswoman said no insiders had yet been allowed to sell. Mr. Ferng said any decision to rescind the lockup would be based on market conditions. In spite of the "without notice" clause, he said, the company will disclose when shares have been sold in a quarterly or annual filing "or other method of communication with the public." 
Why put in the clause? The spokeswoman said it was just a disclaimer. 
Nevertheless, Paul Elliott, an analyst at Thomson Financial/First Call, said that releasing insiders from selling restrictions undermined the whole idea of a lockup. He said: "A lockup is a big selling point because buyers of the stock don't want insiders to be swamping the existing shareholders. These early releases are not positives. And the timing of this one is really unusual."

PERSON: Chekib Khelil 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
For OPEC's Captain, U.S. Roots

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA 

 BODY:
CHEKIB KHELIL, the president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, will tell you that the only house he owns is in Potomac, Md.
 He is an Algerian, but he grew up in Morocco. When he is not directing OPEC, he runs Algeria's oil ministry, but his wife and two grown sons are American citizens. As he tries to reorganize the Algerian energy sector, he draws on his 20 years of experience in reforming the oil industries of Latin America as an official at the World Bank. 
 A life that has coursed through so many different cultures appears to have given Mr. Khelil, 62, a flair for compromise and diplomacy that is crucial for steering the OPEC ship, with its conflicting egos and national interests. It certainly gave him the toughness to embark, right or wrong, on a price war last week with OPEC's biggest rival, Russia. In a move that blindsided the markets and sent world petroleum prices to two-year lows, the OPEC ministers meeting here chose not to reduce output unless non-OPEC producers did the same.
"Of course, it will hurt our economy, Saudi Arabia's, Iran's," Mr. Khelil said, "but it will hurt non-OPEC producers, too. We are not trying to put anybody on their knees. We want other producers to share in the pain if they are going to share in the benefits."
And pain it will be. Mr. Khelil's assurances notwithstanding, OPEC wants very much to put Russia and other uncooperative producers on their knees. 
To bolster falling oil prices as the global economy slowed, the 10 voting members of OPEC reduced production by 3.5 million barrels this year, or 13 percent of total output. But OPEC's rivals increased production, cashing in on the high average price of $25 a barrel for oil and gobbling up some of OPEC's market share. 
OPEC said last week that it would no longer tolerate such a situation. Russia, the world's second-largest exporter of oil, after Saudi Arabia, remains defiant. It is a price war, a term that makes Mr. Khelil wince ever so subtly.
Algeria gets 60 percent of its budget revenue and nearly all its foreign-currency earnings from oil, according to Mr. Khelil. As prices tumble, the country will be hit hard. Stumbling out of years of a civil war that has left as many as 100,000 dead, the country must cope with what many Algerians see as continued repression and political corruption. Oil money, and a great measure of fair government, could help fix those problems, Mr. Khelil acknowledged. 
"We are going to have an explosion of social needs now that people are feeling some new freedom again, which we have to meet," he said. "And oil is our only resource."
After leaving the World Bank in Washington, a posting that explains the house in Maryland, Mr. Khelil has cast his lot with Algeria's president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, a childhood friend from the same hometown in Morocco. In 1999, Mr. Khelil took over the Ministry of Energy and Mines, and he is now the head of Sonatrach, the state oil company. (He lives in government quarters in Algiers.)
Though Mr. Bouteflika is a civilian who was elected two years ago to succeed a junta, his administration is nonetheless dogged by controversy. All the other candidates in the race withdrew, and critics contend that the generals who once ran Algeria still do so from the shadows. 
But Mr. Khelil is certain there will be room in Algeria for what he has learned abroad. He is loath to say Algeria will privatize Sonatrach, though he oversaw the privatization of state petroleum concerns in Argentina and Peru. But he wants to make it more like a private company.
"From all those years in the West," Mr. Khelil said, "I have no doubt that transparency, training, markets are the way to go."
After the turns his life took, there may have been no other route for Mr. Khelil except to return home. Algeria was in him, though he moved within other borders. His grandfathers farmed in western Algeria; his father was born there, in Tlemcen, where the last Arabs from Spain fled centuries ago, Mr. Khelil said. The elder Khelil was a tailor who ended up in the Moroccan town of Oujda, importing fine fabrics from France and outfitting local doctors and teachers, and, years later, his own overachieving son. 
Mr. Khelil grew up with five brothers and six sisters, "and none of them wore a veil," Mr. Khelil said with a laugh. In the working-class family, the children seemed to thrive on education. They became doctors and teachers. But Mr. Khelil was intrigued by the coal mines he visited on school trips and decided to be a mining engineer.
"Does the year 1959 mean anything to you?" he asked, suggesting that the year meant everything to him.
It was then that Algeria was in the thick of a war of independence against France, its colonial master. For someone of Algerian descent like Mr. Khelil, then 20, studies in France were sealed off. So he went to the country that would take him, the United States. He gave up mining to pursue petroleum engineering at Ohio State. "The coal mines in southwest Algeria are closed now," he said, "so I guess it was a good bet!"
His speech is the accented, all-American English of "gonna's" and "shoudda's," though he is the only one in his family who is still an Algerian citizen. At Ohio State, he met his wife, Najat Arafat Khelil, a Palestinian from the West Bank, who was there to get a doctorate in physics. They moved to Texas A&M University, where Mr. Khelil earned his doctorate in petroleum engineering and learned to tell Aggie jokes. 
They spent the 1970's in Algeria, and Mr. Khelil rose quickly to become an adviser to the president. But that president died -- "a natural death," Mr. Khelil is quick to point out -- and Mr. Khelil went to work for the World Bank in Washington. His family became American citizens but always traveled back to Algeria. Mrs. Khelil rose to prominence as a leader in the peace movement between the Palestinians and Israelis. Despite the violence now, she still nurtures her hopes.
With four grandchildren who are now in New York and New Jersey, the most recent one born early last week, the Khelils have a hard time staying away from their adopted country of shopping malls and interstates. The friends and quirky memories of home are there, if anywhere.
The first Aggie joke that comes to Mr. Khelil touches on some foreigners who attended Texas A&M and who, like him, rose to prominence.
"What do you call an Aggie two years after graduation?" he asked. "Boss. What do you call him 30 years after graduation? Mr. Minister."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Gearhead Nation; 
A Time Out for Technophilia

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
"THERE was a sense that this could be a turning point like no other, that perhaps technology will never be viewed in quite the same way," said Robert C. Post, a senior fellow at the Dibner Institute for the History of Science and Technology.
 Historians, by education and inclination, are practitioners of the long view. But Mr. Post and many fellow members of the Society for the History of Technology, who gathered in San Jose, Calif., last month, agreed that Sept. 11 coming at the end of an extraordinary, decade-long infatuation with technology may have a lasting impact on a nation known for its technological optimism. 
 Airliners and the mail became weapons, while skyscrapers became targets, and all of it shook the belief that America's technological supremacy could shield it from a troubled world. But terrorism is not the only reason the American faith in technology is being questioned. The collapse of the dot-com bubble and the precipitous slide in technology stocks on Wall Street has also had a sobering effect. The economic surge of the 1990's was led by investment in the digital technologies of computing, telecommunications and the Internet. Technology startups were the vanguard of a "new economy" that would render economic downturns obsolete. Meanwhile, traditional companies would be obliterated -- "Amazoned" -- by Internet upstarts.
The Internet was also seen as an important cultural, political and social force, a democratizing technology that would overthrow the old order. When Wired magazine began publishing in 1993, it declared, " The Digital Revolution is whipping through our lives like a Bengali typhoon." It struck a chord at the time, but no longer.
"The story's over," said Jason McCabe Calacanis, publisher of The Silicon Alley Reporter, whose current issue will be its last. "You can't have a magazine about unemployed people."
Henry Blodget, a 35-year-old Wall Street analyst who became a pied piper for Internet stocks, said last week that he was leaving Merrill Lynch, taking a buyout offer along with thousands of others. "It just seemed like a good time to pursue the next thing," he said. Who could argue?
Boom-and-bust cycles -- in business and in public attitudes -- have been a hallmark of new technologies for more than a century. These cycles of business euphoria, disenchantment and consolidation typically last 5 to 10 years, and they accompanied the creation of the telegraph, railroad, electric power and automobile industries, among others.
Every new technology brought with it confident pronouncements that it would, as the Internet enthusiasts declared, "change everything." The telegraph was going to eliminate the obstacles to communicating over vast distances, and with them ignorance and discrimination. The railroad collapsed physical distances, and would unify American society. And the electric light bulb would "defeat the night." 
"Americans are much more likely to go to the incense shrine of technology and get carried away," said John Staudenmaier, editor of Technology and Culture, a quarterly journal of technology history. "And when things turn negative, they also tend to behave as if their faith has been betrayed. We are surely in the betrayed and shocked cycle."
Still, the major technologies of the last 150 years did have a profound impact, and so, probably, will the Internet. A study, led by the Brookings Institution, concluded in September that Internet technology will add one-quarter to one-half a percentage point to the productivity growth of the United States economy over the next several years. Over a decade, that would mean additional economic growth of 2.5 percent to 5 percent, or additional wealth of about $1,250 to $2,500 a person.
SO the question now is whether the United States is experiencing the downswing in just another cycle or whether it is something more -- possibly a shift away from the nation's characteristic technological optimism? 
Throughout history, dominant nations stayed that way in part because they were pre-eminent in the technology of the day. Their influence waned when their innovative edge eroded. The long-term economic decline of Britain, the pioneer of the Industrial Age, was partly attributable to the evolving attitudes of the English elite beginning in the 19th century, a denigration of technological progress and a "profound cultural pessimism," according to Martin J. Wiener, author of "English Culture and the Decline of the Industrial Spirit, 1850-1980." That translated into less investment and innovation.
THERE have always been articulate critics of technology in the United States, like Lewis Mumford, the social philosopher who wrote skeptically of the "myth of the machine." But they have generally not shaken the mainstream belief that technology is synonymous with progress, and that progress meant something good -- higher living standards, greater convenience, longer lives.
The lasting effect of the terrorist attacks, historians suggest, may be similar to the legacy of the atomic bomb or the use of military technology in the Vietnam War. Both have become indelible reminders that technology is not always beneficent, but neither caused a retreat from the fundamentally optimistic American view.
In this case, said Joel Mokyr, a professor at Northwestern University, technological development will likely move in new directions, rather than slow down. World War I, he notes, brought rapid development in the chemistry of explosives and poison gas, and the aerodynamics of fixed-wing aircraft, which supplanted airships. World War II sharply accelerated the development of nuclear weapons and power, antibiotics and computer technology. 
The present conflict, he noted, could well stimulate biotechnology to combat bioterrorism, and hasten the deployment of high-speed telecommunications networks and the development of low-cost, sophisticated video-conferencing to partly obviate the need for air travel.
"Terrorism isn't going to stop technology," Mr. Mokyr said. "It's going to tweak its direction."
