HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Indexes Gain as Prospects Look Rosier for 2002 Rebound

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
United States stocks, led by Citigroup, rose yesterday as investors speculated that profits would rebound next year. Airline stocks, including the AMR Corporation, surged as oil prices languished near two-year lows.
 AOL Time Warner climbed after its film "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" took in $93.5 million over the weekend, the biggest movie opening ever. Lowe's, the home improvement retailer, gained after it said sales would rise this quarter. 
 "People are looking into next year, and earnings are looking a lot better compared to 2001," said Brian Slater at Condor Capital Management in Martinsville, N.J. Interest rates at the lowest levels in four decades, combined with increased government spending and tame inflation, "are the prime ingredients for a strong rebound," Mr. Slater said.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12.41 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,151.06. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 35.84 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,934.42. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 109.47 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,976.46.
Banks advanced. Citigroup, the largest financial services company, gained 80 cents a share, to $49.60; Bank One rose 95 cents, to $36.90; Mellon Financial advanced $1.15, to $37.75; and the PNC Financial Services Group added $1.08, to $56.73.
AOL advanced 85 cents, to $37.75. Its Warner Brothers unit made the Harry Potter film that is setting box- office records. The Harry Potter franchise, based on the worldwide best-selling children's books by J. K. Rowling, includes seven movies. It may generate more than $3 billion in sales for AOL over 10 years, Gordon Hodge, a Thomas Weisel Partners analyst, said on Friday. AOL has jumped 26 percent since Sept. 21.
The Amex airline index climbed 10 percent, the biggest one-day gain since May 2000. AMR, parent of American Airlines, rose 71 cents, to $20.77; Continental Airlines climbed $1.19, to $21.55; and Delta Air Lines advanced 85 cents, to $28.82.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as investors snapped up heavily discounted government bonds after a hefty week of selling in which yields on the benchmark 10-year note returned to rates seen before the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States.
"Certainly after six hard sessions, it needed a correction," said Robert Lunder, head of government bond trading at Bear, Stearns.
Bonds have lost much of their safe-haven luster in the Treasury market as stocks have forged higher and the United States has made swift progress in its war in Afghanistan.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 15/32 , to a price of 10121/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.78 percent from 4.85 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32 , to 1023/32 . The bond's yield fell to 5.23 percent from 5.28 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: A Better Chance for Free Trade 

BYLINE:  By Michael M. Weinstein; Michael M. Weinstein is director of the Geoeconomics Center at the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
On some propositions, economists are nearly unanimous: Trade promotes economic growth. Growth reduces poverty. The agreement reached last week among the more than 140 trade ministers gathered in Doha, Qatar, is good for rich countries, perhaps even better for poor countries and surprisingly protective of the environment.
 The progress made last week could also prove to be a major policy success for the Bush administration. Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative, deftly handled demands to reconsider patent policy, which is supported by the American pharmaceutical industry, as well as antidumping laws, which are favored by Democrats and union leaders. 
 The Doha negotiations took place under the shadow of the 1994 agreement that created the World Trade Organization. Under that agreement, industrialized countries in effect promised to buy more textiles and food from poor countries, a promise that has been largely ignored. In return, poor countries promised to honor copyrights and patents for drugs and other products -- a commitment that has proved to be hideously expensive. In Doha, poor countries demanded and got a better deal.
The ministers called for negotiations to phase out agriculture subsidies -- payments that encourage European and Japanese farmers to produce and export more food, thus driving down food prices to levels that make it impossible for third world farmers to survive. Poor countries also won a promise to revisit the enforcement of patent rules with an eye toward making it easier to produce their own generic drugs or buy them from other third world countries. Mr. Zoellick made the key compromise, even though American firms, among the largest and most profitable drug makers in the world, stand to lose the most.
Yet the compromise makes sense even for drug firms. They need to charge customers in rich countries high prices -- in excess of manufacturing costs -- to recover the huge costs of research and development. Once they do so, they do not need to charge high prices in poor countries. The Doha agreement invites such segmented pricing.
The Doha agreement should help countries become more environmentally friendly as well. The challenge was to find ways to protect the environment without coddling protectionists or zealots. Toward that end, ministers asked the trading community to take explicit account of the environment -- by, for example, calling for the environmental review of ongoing trade negotiations. The ministers also steered clear of calling for expensive environmental standards, heatedly opposed by the third world as unaffordable and as driven more by the need of Western firms to block competition than by humanitarian or environmental motives.
The ministers also wanted trade negotiators to find ways to accommodate multilateral environmental treaties. To enforce provisions, these treaties sometimes include trade sanctions -- sanctions that can violate the rules of the World Trade Organization. The Doha agreement invited negotiators to find ways for the organization to provide legal cover for trade sanctions that are part of a well-established, multilateral environmental treaty.
By allowing review of "antidumping" statutes, the Bush administration has drawn Democratic ire. These statutes permit countries to slap tariffs on imports that they decide are being sold below the exporter's costs of production, presumably for the purpose of driving domestic firms out of business. But antidumping statutes are routinely manipulated to punish legitimate foreign competition, especially from the third world steel firms. Poor countries demanded relief, and the Bush administration wisely agreed to a review.
This was no concession. It is the United States economy that gains from more cautious application of antidumping laws. Tariffs can prop up a steel plant or two. But they drive up costs in industries, like autos or construction, that use steel, making them more vulnerable to foreign competition and resulting in higher prices for hundreds of millions of consumers.
The Doha agreement does not do everything right. For example, it does not call for opening the organization's dispute-resolution panels to public scrutiny. Nor can the ministers guarantee that negotiators will follow their wise counsel. But if negotiators over the next several years are to have a chance of finishing in the right place, they almost certainly need to know where they should be heading. Doha points them in the right direction.

HEADLINE: Gore Joining a Financial Services Company 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 

 BODY:
Former Vice President Al Gore announced today that after more than two decades in government and politics, he would become the vice chairman of Metropolitan West Financial Inc., a financial services company based in Los Angeles. 
 Advisers to Mr. Gore said his foray into the private sector, which is effective immediately, should not suggest that he had ruled out running for president in 2004. If anything, they said, it will diversify his experience. 
 But the two chief fund-raisers for Mr. Gore's political action committee, Lon Johnson and Brian Hardwick, have announced their resignations in recent days. Both have told associates that they want to move beyond fund-raising.
Mr. Johnson, who was director of the committee, will run the re-election campaign for Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan. Mr. Hardwick, a consultant to the committee, will be the campaign manager for Tom Strickland, a Colorado Democrat running for the Senate.
The Gore committee, called Leadership '02, was created to help Democrats running for office next year. Some party strategists wondered why, if Mr. Gore had not ruled a presidential race in 2004, Mr. Johnson and Mr. Hardwick would leave the committee, which could become the vehicle for such a run, to take positions outside Washington.
People close to Mr. Gore, however, said that both aides would be replaced and that their departure should not be interpreted as suggesting that the former vice president was getting out of politics.
Metropolitan West is a 10-year-old closely held company that is not particularly well known but claims more than $50 billion in assets under management. With his extensive contacts, Mr. Gore will seek to bring it new business so that it can add to its equity investments in biotechnology, information technology and international markets. 
"For more than 25 years, I have worked on business and economic issues from the perspective of a public servant engaged in public policy," Mr. Gore said in a statement. "I am eager to learn more about business as an active executive of this dynamic and community-oriented company."
Since he lost the presidential election last year, Mr. Gore has been teaching, writing a book on the American family with his wife, Tipper, and speaking at select Democratic gatherings. People close to him said he had joined Metropolitan West because he wanted to make money -- the company would not disclose his salary -- and was intrigued by the offer.
But while the company is based in California, Mr. Gore plans to keep his principal residence in the Washington suburbs. He has been reconnecting with party fund-raisers, and his advisers said he was still considering whether to try to take on George W. Bush again. 
"This is not an indicator of future status of politics at all," one of Mr. Gore's advisers said of the new job. "It's not the decision he's going to make right now. He's in the same place he's been; he's having some other experiences."
Richard S. Hollander, Metropolitan West's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview that he met Mr. Gore last spring at a New York luncheon for the Triarc Companies. The intermediaries were two major political fund-raisers who know Mr. Gore: Nelson Peltz, chairman and chief executive of Triarc, a restaurant holding company, and Peter W. May, president and chief operating officer.
Mr. Hollander, a 44-year-old Queens native, began his career in 1980 in the institutional fixed-income department of Paine Webber in New York. He joined Drexel Burnham Lambert four years later, headed its high-grade-bond sales team on the West Coast, but left in 1988 to start a real estate investment and mortgage fund.
Metropolitan West was formed by him to acquire the securities-lending operations of Bank of America. It has expanded through a series of acquisitions of companies and talent, and now has 200 employees.
Mr. Hollander would not comment on Mr. Gore's possible political aspirations.
"Met West has never been an active political firm," he said. "That goes for myself as well. I've never been active in politics. And we're not going to have Met West cross into the political sphere. What people do on their own time, we're O.K. with it as long as it doesn't reflect poorly on us."
Mr. Hollander said he expected Mr. Gore to spend "a reasonable amount of time" in California and to travel extensively abroad to bring in business for the company.
Mr. Gore also plans to continue teaching courses on family-centered community building at Fisk University in Nashville and at Middle Tennessee State University in Murfreesboro. In addition, he will be a research professor at the University of California at Los Angeles.

Cloud Forest in Danger

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AFGHAN RELIEF EFFORT; 
Gift Tally: $1.5 Million In, But $2.5 Million Is Spent

BYLINE:  By The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 

 BODY:
America's Fund for Afghan Children, a program President Bush started last month to encourage children and families in the United States to contribute to the relief efforts for the children of Afghanistan, has collected about $1.5 million, officials said.
 But the American Red Cross, which receives and distributes the contributions, has already spent nearly $2.5 million through the program. 
 "We have spent more than we have taken in," said Leslie VanSant, a spokeswoman for the Red Cross. "The response has been so great, we are certain enough money will come in." 
Ms. VanSant said the program had been severely affected by the anthrax scares in Washington. "There is a lot of mail at the White House processing center that we have to get and open," she said. 
The off-site mail center for the White House was closed after traces of anthrax were discovered there on Oct. 23.
The White House created a ZIP code for the fund when President Bush established it last month, asking every child in the country to send in a dollar "right here to the White House." (There are roughly 72 million children younger than 18, according to the Census Bureau.)
The American Red Cross said it would absorb all overhead costs associated with the program "so that every dollar contributed by the American people to the fund will directly benefit Afghan children."
Ms. VanSant said she expected contributions to the fund to increase "exponentially" once mail began to flow regularly. Before the mail disruptions, she said, donations had arrived from every state and Puerto Rico -- at a rate of about 20,000 pieces of mail a day. 
Mr. Bush said he hoped schools and youth and community organizations would help raise money, too. "Wash a car," he said. "Do a yard for a neighbor."
Roxanna Brereton, 11, of Washington, for example, decided to sell flag pins for a profit, designing a simple version made from red, white and blue beads suspended from a safety pin. She sold them to her neighbors and to fellow patients at a dentist's office and to people on the street.
"When people on the street say they like my pin, I sell it to them," Roxanna said. "I tell them it was my idea for helping the children of Afghanistan."
She has made $123 in profit, which she sent to the White House, she said. 
The Red Cross says it consults the Agency for International Development on spending from the fund. In addition, the Red Cross works with international relief programs in Afghanistan and neighboring countries. The fund, Red Cross officials said, will help refugees in the region as well as children in Afghanistan.
The Red Cross said one in four Afghan children died before age 5. One in three is an orphan, it said, and almost half suffer from chronic malnutrition.
The program has paid for thousands of winter jackets, mittens, hats and boots and winter tents to be delivered this month, Ms. VanSant said. In addition, the Red Cross has sent blankets and tarpaulins to refugees in Pakistan and Turkmenistan. And tented medical sites, each run by two doctors and two nurses, have been set up in Pakistan. Each unit can provide basic care for about 4,000 children for six months, the Red Cross said.
The fund was modeled on the original 1938 March of Dimes campaign from the administration of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. In that successful effort, Roosevelt appealed to American children to donate a dime each to help eradicate polio. In four months, 2.6 million dimes were collected.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush collecting donations last month from children at an event in Washington to promote America's Fund for Afghan Children. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 19, 2001; 
Talks About the Future, Pressure on the Taliban, Suspects in the West

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. MCFADDEN 

 BODY:
Decades of war and centuries of ethnic hatred have left Afghanistan broken: a country without a government, a land without an economy, a people torn apart by rivalries. With the Taliban nearly beaten, an effort to put the nation back together has begun, and a crucial step was made by the Northern Alliance, which seized control of the capital, Kabul, last week.
 A CONCESSION -- An American diplomat, James F. Dobbins, said that leaders of the victorious alliance had agreed to surrender sole power in Kabul to a transitional government that would be representative of Afghanistan's ethnic and political groups. Talks to establish an interim government are expected to get under way in Europe by the end of the week. 
 Formidable questions face the conference, which will presumably seek a power-sharing formula that would give appropriate weight to many factions -- Tajiks, Uzbeks and Hazaras from the north and Pashtun groups from the south.
Beyond the new government's shape is another question: What sort of multinational force, if any, should be sent to Afghanistan to stabilize the country and support the new administration? Britain and France have indicated a willingness to send troops, but resistance to such a force is strong among the Northern Alliance leaders, and even the Bush administration is hesitant.
Another, more immediate problem is the alliance's reluctance to withdraw its forces from Kabul now, and to let a multinational force take control pending the establishment of a new government. Pashtun groups and Pakistan want the alliance to give way. With nothing settled, a British plan to send 4,000 troops was put on hold while the rival sides try to sort it all out.
LAST REDOUBTS -- Taliban forces were still holding out in Kunduz, in the north, and Kandahar, the southern city where the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was believed to be hiding. There had been talk in Afghanistan of letting Mullah Omar go if Kandahar was surrendered, but Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said no. American special forces combed mountains, caves and valleys southeast of Kandahar, but did not find Osama bin Laden. American bombs continued to fall around Kunduz, but Northern Alliance troops besieging the city suspended their ground assault and tried to persuade thousands of defenders -- mostly foreigners who fanatically support the Taliban cause -- to give up.
On the road from Jalalabad to Kabul, four foreign journalists -- Spanish and Italian reporters and Australian and Afghan photographers -- were shot dead by a half-dozen gunmen who halted their cars, ordered them out, beat them with rifle butts and opened fire, three witnesses said. The victims were part of an eight-car convoy, including Americans, with no armed escort.
TERRORIST CHARGES -- In Spain, where eight men were charged over the weekend with terrorist-related crimes, a judge disclosed details of the case -- suggesting that the suspects were Al Qaeda members who had led middle-class lives for years as they secretly recruited fighters for Mr. bin Laden's training camps or committed crimes to raise money for guns and explosives. He also said they might have had roles in preparing the attacks of Sept. 11.
In Washington, President Bush stoutly defended his order creating special military tribunals for foreigners accused of terrorism, saying extraordinary times demanded extraordinary measures. The plan has drawn a storm of criticism from civil libertarians, who contend it undermines fundamental rights of the criminal justice system.
The President also signed into law an airport security measure that will allow the Federal government to hire 28,000 people to screen passengers and baggage, replacing often ill-trained and low-paid employees of private security companies. It also calls for the inspection of all checked baggage, more sky marshals and the reinforcement of cockpit doors. Mr. Bush also invited scores of Muslim leaders and ambassadors to the White House for a traditional Ramadan dinner.
While the anthrax scare has been relatively subdued lately, investigators said that a sealed letter sent to Senator Patrick J. Leahy was contaminated with a highly refined form of the bacteria, comparable to one sent last month to the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle. Two Senate office buildings closed for cleaning after the discovery of the Leahy letter last Friday were reopened, and officials said they posed no risk to public health.
 ROBERT D. McFADDEN

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FEDERAL AID; 
Billions at Risk as New York Makes Missteps

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 

 BODY:
Only a few days after the World Trade Center attack, President Bush summoned members of New York's Congressional delegation to the White House. There, the Republican president promised to help New York recover -- and then pledged $20 billion to get things started. Even the most partisan Democrat there was moved by the gesture.
 But by last week, all that good will seemed to have vanished, and with it perhaps at least half of the $20 billion. New York lawmakers were summoned back to the White House, only this time to be taken down a notch. Vice President Dick Cheney, the president's enforcer on Capitol Hill, wanted them to back away from their threat to introduce legislation intended to force the administration to hand over all the money Mr. Bush had promised. 
 The contrast between those two meetings captured, in many ways, how far New York has already fallen in Washington's hierarchy of priorities, as the nation wages a war in Afghanistan and confronts the threat of more domestic terrorist attacks.
Some reasons for New York's predicament are beyond its control, like the nation's slumping economy, which makes the overall demand for federal money much higher than it has been in years.
But at least part of the blame rests with New York officials themselves, lawmakers from both parties say. The state's federal, state and city representatives often seem to have different, if not competing, agendas. At times, it has been hard to tell who is really doing the talking for New York in Washington.
Last week, for example, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani seemed to undercut the lobbying efforts of his successor, Michael R. Bloomberg, who had traveled to Washington and joined members of New York's Congressional delegation in calling on the administration to make good on the president's $20 billion promise.
The next day Mr. Giuliani criticized such efforts, saying that he believed that the Bush administration would eventually move to fulfill the president's commitment. 
"What I would urge on everyone is to have a cooperative relationship rather than some of the finger-pointing that seems to be beginning," Mr. Giuliani said. "I think it should be nipped in the bud. And a cooperative relationship should replace it, and the city will get far more that way."
Mr. Giuliani's comments infuriated some New York lawmakers, who said it undermined their efforts to pressure the White House to give the state the money it was promised. "If the mayor says that New York doesn't need all the money right now, that hurts our cause," said a Congressional aide. "Why would he do that?"
New York's case has been undermined in other ways, most notably by what Democrats and Republicans characterize as missteps by Gov. George E. Pataki. A few weeks ago, Mr. Pataki submitted a $54 billion bailout request to Washington that sought money for, among other things, projects that had nothing to do with the events of Sept. 11. That plan was met with derision from Democrats and Republicans on the Hill who saw it as opportunistic.
Then, after a few trips to Washington to sell his plan, Mr. Pataki assumed a lower profile and seemed to cut back on his lobbying efforts. The governor appeared reluctant to take a position when a bipartisan group of New York lawmakers in Congress moved last week toward a showdown with the White House by introducing legislation that would have provided New York with the money agreed to by the president. (The measure sought $9.73 billion on top of roughly $10 billion the White House has sought to provide New York.)
In the end, the legislation was defeated by the House Appropriations Committee after the White House pressured lawmakers to oppose it. Afterward, many New York lawmakers accused Mr. Pataki, a Republican, of sitting on his hands and refusing to use whatever influence he has with the White House to help their cause.
These lawmakers -- none of whom wanted to be identified publicly because they feared antagonizing the governor, whose help they need -- say that Mr. Pataki's silence was all the more remarkable because the showdown with the White House was led by two upstate New York Republicans with close ties to the governor, Representatives John E. Sweeney and James T. Walsh.
Mr. Pataki's office has yet to say what the governor's position is on the matter, despite repeated requests over the last week. 
It wasn't supposed to turn out this way. Many lawmakers even expected the $20 billion pledge by the president to be a down payment -- not the entire amount that New York would need from the federal government to recover from the attack.
As things stand, the White House says that New York will eventually get all the money the president promised, though it hasn't said exactly when that will be. To date, the Bush administration and Congress have earmarked from $9.2 billion to $9.5 billion for New York's recovery effort. After last week's standoff, the White House agreed to increase the earmarked figure by $2 billion.
Many New York lawmakers say they are skeptical of the White House's $20 billion promise because the money was to have come from a $40 billion package that Congress approved after Sept. 11 to pay for military operations, antiterrorism measures and disaster relief. Only about a quarter of that $40 billion package was set aside for New York.
The lawmakers say they are concerned that Washington will stall on delivering the rest of the money now that it has a slew of new expenses -- a war in Afghanistan and antiterrorism efforts here at home -- at a time when the national economy is in steady decline.
Worse, they wonder, what will happen if there is another major attack in the United States before Washington gives New York the money it was promised?
Some New York lawmakers and their aides say the situation is especially troubling because they could be moving on to other pressing matters, instead of having to haggle over money that was already promised.
The state's two senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, have had some success in moving a $5 billion economic stimulus package for New York through their own chamber.
Many people feel a version of that plan would have a better chance of passage in the Senate and the House if the state's delegation focused on getting behind it rather than fighting over the $20 billion that the president had agreed to. As one Congressional aide from New York put it: "A promise is a promise. Why should you have to fight so hard for something you already have?"

HEADLINE: Advocacy Group Says Homeless Are Breaking Shelter Records 

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
The number of people sleeping in municipal shelters and welfare hotels exceeds 29,000 nightly -- the highest number in the city's history, according to a report released yesterday by the Coalition for the Homeless, an advocacy group.
 The report, based on an analysis of city data, comes in the midst of an economic downturn, aggravated by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center -- about 80,000 jobs were lost in October alone -- and just 41 days before Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg begins his term on Jan. 1. 
 That combination of factors -- a city bleeding jobs as a new mayor prepares to take office -- has prompted advocates for the homeless to sound the alarm and challenge Mr. Bloomberg to come up with creative solutions. 
"The cost of doing nothing is a real cost," said Patrick Markee, senior policy analyst for the coalition. "We call on the new administration to have a fresh approach."
Among the coalition's recommendations: expanding programs that provide emergency grants to families at risk of losing their homes and investing in legal services that help low-income tenants fight eviction. In addition, the group called on the city to convert private-market apartments, currently used as emergency shelters, to permanent housing. 
Housing emerged this year as one of the three main issues voters were paying attention to during the mayoral campaign, polls showed. Mr. Bloomberg has promised to put a deputy mayor and what he calls a multiagency "strike force" in charge of housing. He has said he dislikes new subsidies for housing, but wants to foster private development of affordable housing along the waterfront.
Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mr. Bloomberg, said that although Mr. Bloomberg had not met with members of the coalition, he was aware of the increasing number of homeless people. Bob Mascali, first deputy commissioner in the Department of Homeless Services, said the city "continues to spend whatever is necessary to meet the needs of its homeless population."
Though the annual budget of Mr. Mascali's department is $490 million a year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would have to expand its emergency shelter system to make sure demand does not exceed supply, as members of the coalition said was likely to happen this winter.
The coalition's report says that 29,498 people reside each night in the city's shelters and welfare hotels, a record. That includes 12,414 children, an increase of nearly 60 percent from three years ago.
"It's time for the city to look at intelligent investments to prevent homelessness," said Steve Banks, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society, which works with the coalition. "An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure."

HEADLINE: BY THE BOOK; 
Childhood Recipe Horrors Exorcised

BYLINE:  By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

 BODY:
A BOOK that makes you laugh out loud on virtually every page is not to be underestimated right now. But James Lileks's "Gallery of Regrettable Food" (Crown, $22.95) is more than a collection of easy jokes about gruesome photography and time-warp attitudes in recipe booklets from the 1940's through the 60's. The author sneaks in some serious insights into America's food culture along with all the belly laughs.
 In a chapter about a pamphlet on cooking with 7-Up, he writes: "At first, it seems as if they're trying to reassure us. Really! You're actually cooking when you use 7-Up! You're not just pouring sugar water into a bowl, you're really cooking. But you're not. You're committing a sin." 
 A steak is described as looking "as if El Greco had attempted to paint the mask from the 'Scream' movies." If the humor is often crude, so was this food, however familiar it seems.
Reading too much into "Regrettable Food" makes me feel a little like one of those academicians who can divine deep meaning in every finger of Michael Jackson's glove. But I'm fascinated by American food history, and this is a serious slice. 
The undercurrent on many pages is a sense of the rage felt by women of the era who were trapped in careers as home economists (that was once a career, remember?) at big food corporations they could be running today. The contortions they went through to make Vienna sausages appetizing were herculean. And the alternative to the white-glove and perky-hat world, Mr. Lileks reminds the reader, was a woman's trading her identity for a married name and a bleak life chained to the stove.
In a chapter called "Poultry for the Glum," about a booklet with 250 ways to cook birds, Mr. Lileks takes a real headnote, "You will enjoy spaghetti more than ever as a la diable," and completes it with "provided you don't mind the stink of brimstone when you pull it from the oven."
Like Dave Barry, and just about every other American male of a certain age that I know, Mr. Lileks takes indecent pleasure in finding what's funny in bodily functions. But somehow it seems appropriate. Any child of the 50's will feel vindicated on reading his descriptions of this food, much of which seems as if I had refused to eat it only yesterday. 
Mr. Lileks is a columnist for The Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune and also runs his own Web site (www.lileks.com). He has that highly honed sense of irreverent topicality that daily newspapers and insatiable cyberspace demand. He also lets his id out at every opportunity, as journalists did back in the days when they hung out after work in bars, not gyms. This food is not culinarily correct. Why should he cave in to political niceties? 
The tough cynicism is tenderized, though, by the genesis of the book. In 1996, the author discovered a pamphlet called "Specialties of the House" published by the North Dakota State Durum Wheat Commission, which was given to his mother in 1962 by the Welcome Wagon in Fargo. It was pristine, lying under an unused atlas in a closet, and he was fascinated by the photographs: "The Italian dishes look like what happens when a surgeon gets a sneezing fit during an operation." 
Mr. Lileks had opened a door into an age of innocence, when the only spice permitted in excess was fat. Yet he was living in an era when "each gram of fat is regarded as one more bounce on the diving board over an open grave lined with Doritos."
This is the kind of book that could wind up relegated to toy stores for grownups, like Alphabets. But right now, when Americans look back in longing, it belongs on every food lover's bookshelf. 
Meantime, I take comfort in thinking that one day someone will be inspired to do a similar riff on the great chefs' ego extravaganzas of those peaceful, blissful years in the very late 1900's.

HEADLINE: Foundation Starts $50 Million Fund for Arts Groups Hurt by Terrorism 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation announced yesterday that it was establishing a $50 million fund for museums, theaters, dance companies and other cultural institutions affected by repercussions from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as well as for public parks where people congregated after the disaster.
 "At the same time that we are concerned about the victims and their families, we have to be concerned about the future of the city," said William G. Bowen, president of foundation, which is based in Manhattan and is a longtime supporter of the arts. 
 The fund comes at a time when many arts and cultural organizations are reeling from an economic downturn made worse by the terrorist attacks, a decline in tourism and a falloff in donations. The New York City Department of Cultural Affairs also anticipates slicing about $20 million from its $137 million budget to meet Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's order that city agencies look for 15 percent budget cuts. 
A survey of 150 New York arts organizations released this week by the Center for an Urban Future, a nonpartisan policy institute that focuses on economic issues, found that "nonprofit arts organizations are entering their rockiest period in over 30 years." 
Dr. Bowen said the foundation would accept grant requests immediately and would probably make awards ranging from $250,000 to $1 million or $2 million. There are no formal applications. 
T. Dennis Sullivan, the financial vice president at Mellon, said the foundation expected to spend at least some of the money before the year ends. 
"We would invite them to submit proposals and to describe how they have been affected and how they would use this transition funding," Dr. Bowen said. "We're not big on forms." 
The foundation has no specific checklist of criteria, and is willing to give money to large institutions and small ones. Foundation officials say they may also try to work through some established service organizations like the New York Foundation for the Arts, letting them deal directly with applicants.
"We're looking for ideas," Mr. Sullivan said, "and we'll be persuaded by the cases that will be made to us."
The foundation is less certain about what it might do with the parks.
"Our trustees had a sense of wanting to go beyond the kinds of institutions that we've traditionally supported, like museums, libraries, theaters and dance companies, to do something for the city more generally," Mr. Sullivan said. "The parks served such an important role in the immediate aftermath of the September events that we wanted to do something. In the weeks ahead we will try to explore what vehicles might be available to capitalize on that idea."
Mr. Sullivan said the money would come in part from the substantial returns the foundation earned on its investment portfolio until recently.
Dr. Bowen said the foundation was concerned that cultural institutions were being financially pummeled and that those with limited resources might have to close. 
"All of this is happening so fast that some places may be compelled to make decisions that could have long-term effects on them, because they have no choice," Dr. Bowen said. "We thought that if we could help by providing some significant funding now, we could make a difference." Information about the program will be available on the foundation's Web site: www.mellon.org. 
The grants will be administered by a committee of three trustees led by Hanna H. Gray, the president emeritus of the University of Chicago who is also chairwoman of the foundation's trustees.
The other members will be Dr. Bowen and W. Taylor Reveley III, dean of the William and Mary School of Law. Mr. Sullivan, a former executive director of the New York City Municipal Assistance Corporation, will be the chief staff officer for the effort.
The Mellon Foundation has an endowment of about $4 billion and a long commitment to the humanities and the arts. About a quarter of its approximately $175 million in annual spending goes to cultural and performing arts organizations. Money spent through the new fund will be in addition to the previously planned spending.
"Foundations generally are like little old ladies crossing the street," said Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's commissioner of cultural affairs. "Somebody has to take the first step. The Mellon Foundation has positively taken the first step and I hope others will follow."
He said he was particularly pleased that the money would be available to arts organizations throughout the city, not just those below 14th Street.
Ellen V. Futter, president of the American Museum of Natural History, said: "This is a shot in the arm to cultural institutions at a time we all very much need it. Our attendance is down; there are many fewer tourists in New York and we feel that right away."
David Fischer, project director at the Center for an Urban Future, called the fund a "great idea." 
"It really provides some first aid in this abnormal time," he said. "This might make the difference between 10 or 12 organizations riding out the storm or going under."
Dr. Bowen said that the foundation also saw arts and cultural institutions as a critical part of the rebuilding process and hoped that the fund would "send a message about the importance of these institutions and our commitment to them."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
Accord May Be Near on Oil Production Cuts to Prop Up Prices

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Russia remained the question mark in the standoff between OPEC and oil exporters outside the cartel after two of the largest nonmember exporters signaled today that an agreement was near to reduce output in hopes of propping up prices.
 After meeting in Oslo, the energy ministers of Norway and Mexico, No. 2 and No. 3 among exporters that do not belong to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, said they were in agreement on a plan for cutbacks, and that it was now up to Russia, which is No. 1, to make the plan succeed by reducing its daily production by "a couple of hundred thousand barrels." 
 The ministers said they expected to reach a consensus on the 500,000-barrel-a-day total reduction OPEC wants from non-OPEC producers "in the next few days."
The remarks drove up the price of oil from the 29-month low reached on Monday. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 72 cents, or 3.9 percent, to $19.15 a barrel. In London, Brent crude oil for January delivery rose 74 cents, or 4.1 percent, to $18.75 a barrel. 
Earlier in the day in Moscow, the Russian government, which made no official statement on the matter, nonetheless appeared to be shifting its stance concerning production cuts. Viktor Khristenko, the deputy prime minister in charge of oil exports, said this morning that Russia was worried about falling oil prices, and without elaborating, said, "further decisions will be set out soon."
Separately, the Russian finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, told the Parliament today that the government would have to review its growth forecasts for next year because of world recession and low energy prices, a sign that the country is growing worried and may be less averse to cuts.
Still, many analysts are unpersuaded. Russia has never agreed to a production cut of more than 100,000 barrels a day, they said, and even the reduction the country promised during the 1998 oil price collapse would largely have happened anyway because of a debt crisis.
It is "a classic Russian game of playing hardball and then giving away as little as possible," said James Henderson, oil analyst at Renaissance Capital, a Moscow-based investment bank. "While the price is at $18, the Russians are happy. They might offer something small, but it will be one of those offers no one will really believe."
OPEC has been trying for weeks to get its own members and the major non-OPEC exporters, especially Russia, to agree to reduce supplies of crude oil that are now flooding the market and depressing prices as the world economy slows. To press the point, OPEC's secretary general, Ali Rodriguez of Venezuela, is expected to visit Moscow sometime in the next few weeks.
Russia's refusal so far to promise more than token reductions, and OPEC's announcement that it would not cut back production on its own, sent benchmark oil prices tumbling 20 percent last week.
The root of the problem is surging Russian oil production -- up 7 percent this year and likely to rise another 7 percent next year, analysts said. Even if the Russian government agrees to require its oil industry, now mostly in private hands, to trim exports by the 150,000 barrels or 200,000 barrels a day demanded by OPEC, rapid growth in production is already in the works for next year, and the financial health of several major Russian oil companies depends on it.
In the short term, a cut in daily exports of "150,000 barrels is very easily achieved," said Simon G. Kukes, the chief executive of Tyumen Oil, Russia's fourth-largest producer. "The hard part for Russia is not reducing from current levels. The industry was planning to increase production in 2002 -- can we divert all this to the domestic market? It's unlikely."
Russian oil companies still have some breathing room before falling prices start to cause them pain. Mr. Kukes said that his company would increase output at a slower pace if the reference price of Brent crude fell below $18 a barrel, but that the Russian industry would still be profitable at prices down to $10 a barrel. In fact, falling prices may prompt some companies to step up output further to maintain revenue.
"Our idea was to try to keep the same earnings but with different volumes -- to increase volumes dramatically," said Eugene Shvidler, the president of Sibneft, another Russian oil company, in a recent conversation.
Government officials responsible for keeping next year's budget on course, like Mr. Kudrin, may have a different perspective. A fall of $1 in the price of oil removes $1.1 billion in revenue from Russia's federal budget. A surplus this year gives the government some maneuvering room, but a long period of low prices could play havoc with future spending plans.
Still, analysts do not see cause for alarm. "Kudrin is nervous to some extent," said Aleksei Zabotkine, chief economist at the United Financial Group, an investment bank based in Moscow. "He's just trying to go the more conservative way. I don't think they consider themselves as being in danger."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Posts Decline That Is Largest on Record 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
The trade deficit shrank by a record amount in September after the terrorist attacks disrupted air travel, slowed oil imports and drove up payments from overseas insurance companies, the government reported today.
 The gap in goods and services trade narrowed to $18.7 billion from $27.1 billion in August, the Commerce Department said. The deficit was the narrowest since March 1999, and the decline was the largest on record. Exports fell to the lowest level in two and a half years, reflecting weak economies worldwide. 
 "The world economy is slowing, and that is reducing demand for U.S. products," said Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors Inc. in Holland, Pa.
While a shrinking deficit is typically positive for gross domestic product, the September report is unusual because adjustments for insurance claims depressed imports.
A separate report, from the Conference Board, showed that the index of leading economic indicators unexpectedly rose 0.3 percent in October after falling 0.5 percent in September. The increase would typically point to a stronger economy next year. That may not be true this time because some manufacturing components in the index were stronger than other measures suggest, analysts said.
Slower supplier delivery times, which imply rising demand, and higher stock prices were among the signs of a strengthening economy, the leading indicators report said. Other positive indicators were an increase in the money supply, a wider spread between the yield on 10-year Treasury notes and the Federal Reserve's benchmark interest rate, and rising consumer expectations.
The Conference Board also said it expected that orders for nonmilitary capital goods and for consumer goods would show an increase for the month, adding to the index.
Negative indicators included increased claims for unemployment benefits, shorter factory hours and fewer permits for new-house construction.
Analysts had expected the Commerce Department report to show a trade deficit of $24.8 billion.
Imports fell 14 percent, the sixth consecutive decline, to $96 billion. That included a drop of 75 percent in services imports, where insurance payments and air fares are counted.
The attacks on the World Trade Center led to claims on overseas insurers in excess of premiums. Lloyd's of London may have responsibility for as much as a quarter of the $40 billion in losses. The Commerce Department subtracted $11 billion in insurance payments from imports.
Without the adjustment, the trade gap probably widened. The effect of the import drop on gross domestic product will probably not be felt because the Commerce Department will offset the value of insurance coverage with a reduction in the price.
September imports of consumer goods rose 0.2 percent, to $23.3 billion, led by increases for pharmaceuticals, household goods, televisions and VCR's.
Exports fell 8.5 percent, to $77.3 billion, the lowest since March 1999. The drop was led by capital goods. Exports of consumer goods fell 4.2 percent. Exports of commercial aircraft fell 6.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Court Ruling In Arms Case Frees Menem In Argentina 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Former President Carlos Saul Menem was released from house arrest today after the Supreme Court ruled that prosecutors had failed to prove that he and his former brother-in-law were involved in a conspiracy to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. 
 The six-to-two decision does not close the door to future prosecution of Mr. Menem, but aides said he was already planning a national tour to begin his campaign to become the presidential candidate of his Justicialist Party in 2003. 
 Mr. Menem has cast a long shadow over Argentina since his election in 1989 when he burst onto the political scene with his mutton-chop sideburns, zest for fast sports cars and ostentatious way of life. During his decade in power, he sold off much of the state to private businesses, pegged the value of the peso to the dollar, expanded commercial relations with Brazil and linked his country's foreign policy with that of the United States. 
The 71-year-old former president, still the official head of his party, faces a challenge for the leadership from former Vice President Eduardo Duhalde, now a senator-elect from Buenos Aires Province. The fight is expected to be heated and could determine how helpful the opposition will be as President Fernando de la Rua tries to avert a financial collapse in the coming months. 
Mr. Menem is considered a less aggressive opponent of the de la Rua administration than Mr. Duhalde, who has called for a complete revamping of economic policy. 
Today's ruling dropped charges of illicit association against Emir Yoma, Mr. Menem's former brother-in-law and business associate, who prosecutors said was put in charge of a gun-running scheme by the former president. But by ruling that there was a lack of evidence, the court by implication extended the decision to Mr. Menem, who had been under house arrest since June in a friend's house outside Buenos Aires.
Congressman Adrian Menem, the former president's nephew, said Mr. Menem told his supporters today that "without rancor or hatred I will work for Argentina."
A federal judge and prosecutors charged that Mr. Menem, Mr. Yoma and several senior officials had secretly transferred 6,500 tons of arms and munitions supposedly destined for Panama and Venezuela to Croatia and Ecuador.
Mr. Menem and the others said they did not know that arms dealers had rerouted the shipments, in violation of a United Nations arms embargo in the Balkans in Croatia's case and in the case of Ecuador when Argentina was mediating a border dispute between that country and Peru.
Polls indicate that Mr. Menem does not have wide popular support these days because of persistent accusations of corruption and a continuing recession that began in the last two years of his second term. Nevertheless, he is a charismatic campaigner with strong support in several western rural provinces and among several powerful governors and members of Congress. 
Shortly before his arrest he married Cecilia Bolocco, a 36-year-old Chilean who is a former Miss Universe. Ms. Bolocco has since tried hard to imitate Eva Peron, the wife of Juan Domingo Peron, the Justicialist Party's founder, by flashing the V for victory salute just as Ms. Peron did when her husband was a political prisoner and, later, president.
In recent months, Ms. Bolocco appeared on the cover of one magazine apparently wearing only a rabbit stole dyed in the colors of the Argentine flag and for a time she tied back her hair in the Eva Peron style. She has also proved to be a fiery speaker and says she is eager to join her husband on the campaign trail. 
The two are expected to tour La Rioja Province, Mr. Menem's home base, within the next few days and then head for Buenos Aires Province, Mr. Duhalde's stronghold. 
After the announcement of her husband's release, Ms. Bolocco greeted dozens of well-wishers outside the house where she has remained with her husband and exchanged hugs and kisses. "We are very content," she said.
In recent days, Mr. de la Rua and his senior aides have said they thought it was a mistake to hold a former president under arrest on charges of "illicit association." Critics viewed the comments as an unusual public intervention by the executive branch in a judicial case.
President de la Rua denied today that he had anything to do with the court's decision despite a long history of presidential interference in cases here. 
Mr. Duhalde said he would forcefully compete with Mr. Menem for leadership of the party in a primary election scheduled for next year. "Menem became an ally of the powerful and that is not what Justicialism is all about," Mr. Duhalde said.

HEADLINE: Big Economies Near a Standstill, O.E.C.D. Says 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
The world's major economies have slowed to a "virtual standstill" this year but are expected to rebound strongly in the second half of 2002, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said here today.
 The group, made up of 30 advanced economies, said in its twice-yearly report that the "slowdown that started in the United States last year, and spilled over to other countries, has turned into a global economic downturn." 
 The O.E.C.D.'s chief economist, Ignazio Visco, said at a news conference that output in its 30 countries was expected to contract by 0.3 percent in the second half of this year. 
Growth for all of 2001 will be limited to 1 percent -- compared with the 2 percent growth forecast in the organization's report in May -- and remain "very weak" in the first half of next year.
The pace is projected to pick up in 2002, paving the way for a rebound to 3 percent growth in 2003, the report said.
Events related to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 worsened the situation, further slowing business investment, consumer demand and overall economic activity, and inflicting "a severe shock to the world economy," the report said.
"For the recovery to occur," it added, "it is crucial that the sentiment of insecurity prevailing since September dissipates."
The O.E.C.D. praised the "rapid and timely" interest rate cuts in the United States before and after the attacks, saying these were among the factors that would contribute to a robust recovery for global economies.
"With the fading of the main contractionary forces, demand and activity would rebound and the recovery could be strong and fully visible by the second half of 2002," said the report, which forecast 3.8 percent growth for the United States in the second half of 2002.
The O.E.C.D. said that economic activity in Europe "has weakened considerably" this year and that growth there is expected to recover more slowly than in the United States -- at a 2.7 percent pace by the second half of next year.
It was pessimistic about Japan, calling prospects for a recovery "distant" and adding that fiscal and monetary policy had "limited room for maneuver."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Pull Back as Sellers Try to Lock In Recent Gains

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street's efforts to start a new bull market stalled yesterday in a retreat that was expected as investors sold stocks to preserve profits from the latest rally.
 Prices fell despite a better-than-expected report on the index of leading economic indicators for October from the Conference Board, a private industry group. Analysts said the good news was not enough to offset doubts that the market's advance might last. They also said some selling was inevitable after the strong performance in recent days. 
 "There's still little evidence of an economic or business recovery, so this rally has so far been mostly based on expectation," said Barry Hyman, the chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. "And there's only so much you can invest on expectation before you start to worry you'll lose your profits."
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 75.08 points, or 0.8 percent, to 9,901.38. For a second day, the Dow remained 20 percent above the low for 2001, which it set on Sept. 21. Such a gain fits the technical definition of a bull market.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 8.40 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 1,142.66, while the Nasdaq composite index decreased 53.91 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,880.51.
The losses were not surprising given the market's recent surge. Investors have been buying gradually since the precipitous sell-off after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Specifically, analysts say that Wall Street is feeling more optimistic about a business turnaround and that the United States military victories in Afghanistan have helped restore investors' confidence.
Although the three major indexes have each made double-digit percentage advances the last two months and have returned to their preattack levels, most analysts caution against too much exuberance. They note that much of the recent gain is a rebound from a catastrophic loss, rather than buying on healthy earnings.
Still, there are some encouraging signs. For last month, the index of leading economic indicators, which gauges economic activity over the next three to six months, rose 0.3 percent, after a drop of 0.5 percent in September. Wall Street had been expecting a flat report for October, but the number suggested that the economy might be stabilizing. That might make the Federal Reserve less inclined to cut interest rates for the 11th time this year at its next meeting, but analysts were still pleased.
 --------------------

Treasuries Are Lower
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after an unexpected rise in the index of leading economic indicators suggested that the Federal Reserve would be less likely to cut the benchmark lending rate at a policy meeting on Dec. 11.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 17/32, to a price of 101 1/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.87 percent from 4.78 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 5/32, to 100 28/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.32 percent from 5.23 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Russian Oil Production Still Soars, for Better and Worse 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES and SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
While nobody was watching, this country's oil producers so dramatically ratcheted up production in the last two years that they now occupy a catbird seat, able to whipsaw oil prices -- and potentially the global economy -- just by turning down the Russian spigot. 
 Trouble is, they only seem to know how to turn the spigot up. 
 Witness last week's remarkable events. In the space of 10 days, the price of a barrel of crude has fallen 20 percent. Saudi Arabia beseeched the Russians to cut oil exports, to no avail. OPEC nations threatened a price war if Russia did not change its mind, again to no avail. 
Today the Kremlin had to pare back its 2002 economic forecast, principally because of lower oil prices. Meanwhile, the state-owned pipeline company, Transneft, trumpeted the opening of a Baltic Sea terminal that will flood an already saturated market with another 240,000 barrels of oil a day.
That is only the beginning. In the next four years alone, according to analysts at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, huge sums already sunk into new pipelines and reinvigorated oilfields should boost Russian oil exports by a fifth, to 5.34 million barrels a day.
"There's nothing in there that indicates a willingness to cut back either on the part of the oil companies or the government," said Thane Gustafson, the top Eurasian expert at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Washington. "If Russia were to slam on the brakes now, it would be Ben Hur pulling back suddenly on his chariot while it's going full speed ahead."
In that case, other oil-producing nations might have little choice but to go along for what could be, at least briefly, a wild ride. Prospects for a further plunge in oil prices seemed to ebb a bit today as two other big non-OPEC exporters, Norway and Mexico, said they would reduce their output in line with OPEC requests.
If, that is, Russia goes along.
Even some Russian oil companies are mulling over a temporary cut in exports. But they key word is temporary. No one, including the companies themselves, believes that the explosive growth in Russian output will be restrained for long, even amid a recession that has cut deeply into demand.
The temptation is to view Russia's sudden emergence as the swing vote on world oil prices as deft strategy by a Kremlin determined to reassert itself as a global power and a force in Western affairs.
President Vladimir V. Putin has surely packaged it that way, telling a World Economic Forum meeting in Moscow last month that as "instability in the world directly impacts world markets, Russia remains a reliable and predictable partner and supplier of oil." Translation: remember that should the Middle East crumble under terrorism and religious ferment, Russia can keep oil flowing westward.
Americans are listening. "The Saudis aren't so popular in the U.S. right now," Michael McFaul, a leading Russia scholar at Stanford University, said last week. "I've been on a hundred news programs over the past two months and every time, the question comes up. "Why doesn't the U.S. import more oil from Russia?' "
But there is less strategy here than meets the eye. Russia has influence by dint of being the world's second-largest oil exporter behind the Saudis, a ranking it has held for decades. Its present extraordinary hold on oil prices, however, has less to do with strategy than with the lack of one.
Russian oil is a free market. The major oil companies, profit-hungry and mutually mistrustful, are mostly beyond control by either the government or each other. If OPEC ministers can usually turn their government-owned spigots up or down with ease, Russia's powerful and mostly private oil industry argues for pumping and exporting as much oil as possible, as quickly as possible. 
Chief among them is economics. From 1990 to 1996, oil output here dropped by a staggering 3.86 million barrels a day -- almost 40 percent of all production. Russia's economy ground to a halt, as did the financing of its oil industry. Wells and refineries remained mismanaged and investment-starved for years.
But Russia's 1998 fiscal collapse transformed the industry's economics. Suddenly, currency devaluation made Russian oil companies the world's low-cost producers and put a huge premium on selling oil for dollars, as exports, instead of rubles.
Combined with a spike that sent oil prices to the mid-$30's per barrel, that sparked a staggering investment in oil fields: in the first half of this year, spending on Russian exploration and drilling rose 50 percent. The government, meanwhile, has helped build new pipelines to the Baltic and Black Seas to capitalize on surging demand for the region's crude.
From Russian companies' standpoint, limiting production now would amount to idling a multibillion-dollar investment -- and all to satiate Arab oil barons who profited handsomely from Russia's 1990's decline. Just as galling, perhaps, is that OPEC's proposed cut in exports, 500,000 barrels a day, happens to precisely match Russia's export increase this year.
"Russians will say, 'You had billions of dollars in revenue in the 1990's, and the only reason was that we cut our oil production while we reorganized our economic system,' " Adam E. Sieminski, a global oil analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown in Maryland, said. " 'What right do you have to tell me that we can't go up a million barrels after we lost four million! How dare you!' And it would be true."
All that said, the Kremlin might well profit from limiting exports, because Russia's budget hangs on petroleum. Oil and gas exports provide $4 of every $10 in government revenue. The government's economic plans assume that oil will average $20 per barrel in 2002.
Historically, low oil prices have not been good for Russia. Mikhail Gorbachev's government foundered in part because sagging oil prices in the late 1980's left it starved for cash to feed the Soviet Union's inefficient economy. A 1998 collapse in oil prices, to below $10 a barrel, broke President Boris N. Yeltsin's budget and doomed his government.
Avoiding that would be no problem if the Kremlin could dictate oil policy the way the Soviet Union did in the 1970's and 1980's. But here, at least, the Soviet Union is dead.
"The government does not control the oil industry -- it's the other way around," Yevgeny Khartukov, the director of the nonprofit International Center for Petroleum Business Studies in Moscow, said in an interview.
"Western specialists very often don't understand this. They ask, 'How will Putin's position affect the development of the oil industry?' And I answer: 'Putin's position will be handed to him by the oil sector.' "
In the long run, Russia's oil influence may not last.
No. 2 in exports or not, Moscow produces only between 9 and 10 percent of the world's output, and its newfound power rests in part on a recession that has reduced worldwide demand.
When global demand recovers -- and when Russian consumption increases, as it must if the economy continues to thrive -- Russian companies will gradually shift more oil flow to buyers at home, leaving less for better-heeled foreign clients. 
But that assumes that a future Middle East crisis does not catapult Russia to the top of the list of favored suppliers, an assumption that looks less reliable these days than in the past.
"If you think that is a problem, then substituting oil outside the Arab region is a good idea," said Lucian Pugliaresi, a Washington, D.C., oil consultant who advised President Reagan on energy security.

HEADLINE: Denmark Shifts to Right in Election Centering on Immigration 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Danish voters concerned that immigrants are exploiting the welfare system shifted to the right in parliamentary voting today, handing the Liberal Party-led opposition a big victory over the Social Democrats.
 With 98.4 percent of the vote counted, the Liberal Party and its supporters, including the anti-immigration Danish People's Party, had 98 seats in the 179-seat Parliament, well above the 90 needed for a majority. 
 The ruling Social Democrats and their parliamentary supporters won just 77 seats, down from 89 in the last Parliament. 
"It has been a historic day," said the Liberal Party leader, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, widely expected to be chosen the next prime minister. If given the opportunity, he said, "I'll be prime minister for the whole population."
Denmark's four million voters chose from 984 candidates in 10 parties for four-year parliamentary terms in the Folketing, or Parliament. For the first time, elections were held for county and municipal officials on the same day as the national vote.
The Social Democratic prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, 58, who has led the country since 1993, set the date for the quadrennial elections late last month. His popularity soared with his strong support for the American-led fight against terrorism, only to fall as the immigration debate exposed ruling party divisions. The two candidates are not related.
"The country we are now handing over to a right-leaning government is a well-functioning country," said Mr. Nyrup Rasmussen, who will remain in a caretaker role until a new government is formed within days. "We will be a fair and consistent opposition."
The more charismatic Mr. Fogh Rasmussen, 48, has played down criticism of xenophobia but pledged to crack down on foreigners trying to cheat the system.
"Denmark must not be the social security office for the rest of the world," he said during the three-week campaign.
It was the first time since 1920 that the Liberals, with 56 projected seats in contrast to the 42 seats they won in 1998, had surpassed the Social Democrats, who dropped from 63 seats to 53.
Many voters said they had been looking for a government change as they cast their ballots today. "Nyrup seems burned out and doesn't seem trustworthy anymore," said Stig Lassen, a 41-year-old businessman. 
The parties are largely in agreement on major issues, including a need to improve education, health care, care for the elderly and the economy. Denmark has an unemployment rate of 5 percent. 
The main issue in the campaign -- family reunification for immigrants, which has long simmered in the mainly Lutheran country -- was heightened by the attacks on New York and Washington. Critics also say the law provides a way for foreigners living here to bring in spouses and children and take advantage of generous benefits.
The prosperous Scandinavian nation of 5.3 million people halted open immigration in 1973 but still allows relatives of immigrants and political asylum seekers to enter.
Both Social Democrats and Liberals have promised to tighten the immigration law. But while the ruling party wants to study the issue, the Liberals are calling for faster measures, including a seven-year waiting period before new arrivals would be able to tap into the country's cradle-to-grave welfare system.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Battered by Sept. 11, Chinatown Economy Remains Crippled

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE

 BODY:
Chinatown has become a community of waiting.
 The waiting starts at 4:30 a.m., when lines form in front of the Mott Street center at which financial assistance is offered for those who lost work as a result of the World Trade Center attack. Some days, the crowds grow to nearly 1,000 people. Not uncommonly, they become unruly and frustrated by the lack of information. The police are called and the crowds scatter. 
 Many businesses and households are still waiting for their telephone service to return. Without a working line, Lam Fang Wang says, his gift store, Mott Street Gift Shop, can't take credit cards. "I lose a lot of money from customers who leave," he said, sighing. 
Garment factories are waiting to see how long it takes before they can no longer afford to pay their workers. Dozens of factories have closed. Others are working at half capacity because orders fell sharply when trucking restrictions were imposed downtown just after the attack. The garment industry, Chinatown's biggest employer with more than 10,000 workers, remains paralyzed.
While in much of New York the effects of the World Trade Center attack are no longer clearly visible, Chinatown is still reeling in many ways from the economic convulsions that flowed north and east from the disaster. With the garment industry and tourism suffering, and with restaurants and retailing in a slump, Chinatown is probably the hardest hit of any neighborhood outside of the red zone. Community leaders fear that this once-thriving 170-year-old neighborhood, a worldwide tourist attraction and home to 100,000 people, will be crippled and irrevocably harmed. 
Like all of Lower Manhattan, Chinatown is suffering from the steep drop of foot traffic from tourists and office workers. Parking at one of the area's largest garages, Chatham Parking, is down 70 percent, company officials say. A recent survey by local business leaders of 350 Chinatown businesses found that revenues were down 30 to 70 percent, depending on the industry. About 60 percent of businesses have already cut staff. Some businesses have started to shutter their doors. The only exceptions to the usually glum news have been video rental stores.
The unemployment lines in front of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association's community center have snaked down Mott Street and around the corner onto Canal Street. There are young mothers hugging brightly dressed children, cooks in food-stained white uniforms and white-haired women whose fingers are cracked from years of intensive sewing. In a community unaccustomed to asking for outside financial support, many find that they are running out of choices.
Don Lee, a member of Community Board 2, was frustrated and saddened by the desperation of many of those in line, so he helped work out a system to schedule appointments.
"People should have more dignity than to stand on a line like this," Mr. Lee said. Ultimately, though, the number of needy overwhelmed this effort, and crowds circled the center once again. 
From fruit stands to jewelry stores to garment factories, Chinatown's businesses need high volumes because they typically have low profit margins. Much business is done in cash, and today's proceeds often go to tomorrow's costs. Fixed costs are high because of the area's expensive rents. Even a slight drop in revenue can swing a business into the red. 
Jobs in Chinatown usually pay low wages. In other parts of the city, the average check for two weeks' loss in wages that Safe Horizon, a service organization known in Chinese as "safety line," has given out after the World Trade Center disaster is around $900, said Elizabeth McCarthy, vice president for research and planning at Safe Horizon. In Chinatown, the average is about half that. 
One unemployed garment factory worker, Yuan, had left his Brooklyn home at 5 a.m. to wait in line for unemployment aid at the Mott Street center one Saturday morning. Because of his documentation, he was eligible for only one week's pay. "One week is still $160," he said. "That is not so bad." 
Right after Sept. 11, orders dropped sharply, slamming an industry that was already suffering from the softening economy and years of exports of jobs to other countries. Trucking restrictions downtown limited the import of raw goods and the export of finished goods from Chinatown factories. Many workers, some of them illegal immigrants, did not want to pass police cordons to reach jobs in garment and other industries, Chinatown newspapers have reported. The bigger police presence has rattled illegal immigrants both north and south of Canal Street. 
The pain of the garment industry ripples through Chinatown's economy. Fewer women ride the $2 shuttle buses from their homes in Brooklyn to factories in Chinatown. Mei Wah Trinh, a fruit and vegetable vendor on Canal Street, says half of her regular customers, most of whom are garment workers, seldom come by anymore. "Sometimes they walk by and I call out to them, but they say they have no more work," she said. 
Officials and organizations are still figuring out how to provide relief. 
Often, there are problems that prevent those who have been affected from receiving aid. While more than half of the businesses citywide that have applied for disaster relief loans from the Small Business Administration are rejected, in Chinatown the rejection rate is even higher, business leaders in Chinatown say. 
Chinatown businesses say this is because few business owners qualify for the loans, since they are based in part on cash flow, which was down already, and ability to repay, which is hampered by the area's economic slowdown. Also, few business owners have the collateral to secure them. Business owners here and elsewhere are often asked to put up their homes as collateral for a $50,000 loan. 
A Chinatown accountant, Max Ng, says 80 percent of his clients' small business relief applications have been rejected, with the notices citing problems with cash flow and ability to repay.
To give some relief, several grant programs have been introduced for Lower Manhattan businesses, including one by New York State for retail businesses south of Houston Street that gives the owner three days' revenue. In the first week, 1,000 Chinatown businesses, about two-thirds of the applicants, applied for the grants.
The eligibility zone for many kinds of relief has been drawn at Canal Street. But the Canal Street boundary still leaves out the half of Chinatown north of the line, and all of Little Italy. "You don't decide need based on an arbitrary line," Mr. Lee said. "A line makes it easy for administration, but not for the people who have to suffer through the pain every day." 
Safe Horizon limits the money it provides to people who work south of Canal. "We had to draw the line somewhere, and Canal Street was the beginning of the frozen zone," Ms. McCarthy said. But only about 35 of Chinatown's 200-odd garment factories are south of Canal Street. 
Teddy Lai, executive director of the Greater Blouse, Skirt and Undergarment Association, gestured at a room full of people waiting to talk to caseworkers at the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association's offices. "There are still a lot of people who need help," he said. "This is only 35 factories. Can you imagine 200?" 
The Red Cross officially requires people to live or work south of Canal Street to qualify for aid, but Elaine Wagner, a spokeswoman, said the line is not "hard and fast." Aid is granted to people a block or two north if they demonstrate need, she said. 
Chinatown has traditionally been an insular community, and that insularity was magnified immediately after the attack with the truck restrictions and broadcasting interruptions, which resulted in a nearly complete Chinese-language news blackout on an event half a mile away. Because trucks could not reach the neighborhood, Chinese newspapers were brought in by hand truck and posted on walls or scalped for $4. Local leaders pleaded with the police to escort clandestine midnight deliveries of groceries because stores were running out of food. 
Despite the insularity, the community is feeling a need to reach out to the rest of the city for support with a louder, more public effort. Donations from Chinatown to Sept. 11 charities have reached $2 million. 
In the last few weeks, Chinatown businesses and officials have banded together to begin a "Welcome Back to Chinatown" campaign with full-page newspaper ads. They created a red, white and blue "Chinatown, U.S.A." logo. President Bush, Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer have all made brief appearances. Also, in the last few days, Chinatown, Harlem and Little Italy have joined hands to encourage people to visit.
But some Chinatown residents are still gloomy, pointing to further ill effects from old problems like the closing of the Grand Street subway stop for repairs of the subway line this summer, as well as new problems like the security measures that are being put into effect in Lower Manhattan to protect neighboring government offices and courthouses. 
"I think there is a new vision of Chinatown coming, and we have no input into it," said Paul Lee, owner of 32 Mott Street General Store, one of the oldest businesses in Chinatown. "We definitely need to be heard."
