HEADLINE: P & O and Royal Caribbean To Merge IntoLargest Cruise Line 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Two leading cruise lines announced a $2.89 billion deal today to combine, becoming the world's largest cruise ship company. 
 The two, P & O Princess Cruises of Britain and Royal Caribbean Cruises, which is based in Miami, said that a merger would extract profit from a market hurt by the attacks on Sept. 11 and dominated less and less by bookings from the very wealthy. 
 The cruise lines termed their deal a "merger of equals." The combined company -- with a "working title" of RCP Cruise Lines, according to Richard D. Fain, Royal Caribbean's chairman and chief executive -- would have 41 ships and 75,000 berths under joint management while maintaining separate stock market listings and dividend payments for investors. 
With a market value around $6 billion, the company would surpass Carnival of Miami as the world's biggest cruise ship company, analysts said.
The deal comes as vacation bookings slide and some travelers cancel plans in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks. Immediately after the attacks, P & O Princess lost 8,000 bookings in two weeks and business dipped again after the beginning of military action in Afghanistan before beginning to recover, said Caroline Keppel-Palmer, a spokeswoman for the company.
Some cruise lines have been offering discounts and other promotions to attract passengers, particularly on cruises that require the traveler to fly to join their cruise ships.
But the impact on some smaller cruise lines has been devastating. Renaissance Cruises shut down operations and filed for bankruptcy protection two weeks after the attacks. American Classic Voyages filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in mid-October.
Still, Mr. Fain, who will maintain both of his current positions in the merged company, expressed optimism today. "We are suffering a bit from Sept. 11," he said, "but we expect the industry to continue to grow."
The merger also comes at a time when the top cruise lines are attracting business from a younger group than before. The average age of passengers on Royal Caribbean is 45, and the company is seeking to attract people earning $35,000 and up, Mr. Fain said. That market, he said, was "not upper crust."
P & O Princess's average passenger is slightly older, Ms. Keppel-Palmer, the company spokeswoman, said, and cruising is not as common a vacation among Britons. Last year, P & O Princess became an independent company after splitting away from the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company.
Some travel agents in the United States were optimistic that the merger would be beneficial. "The economies of scale should be beneficial to both companies, since they will be able to keep their costs down," said Greg DeClemente of Valerie Wilson Travel in New York. "And if they get their expenses down, consumers will continue to get good deals in the marketplace."
Under the deal, each Royal Caribbean share will be worth 3.46 shares in P & O Princess, owner of the Pacific Princess vessel used in the "Love Boat" television show. P & O Princess investors will hold 50.7 percent of the combined company, which will have its headquarters in Miami. Royal Caribbean shareholders will hold 49.3 percent.
The successor business will have a heavy debt load: the two companies' debt totaled more than $5 billion at the end of September.
Mr. Fain said that executives had been meeting secretly on Sept. 11 to work out the final details of the merger at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. "We had every TV in the house going," he recalled. "We were shocked, horrified. We didn't get much work done."
The deal, he indicated, would have gone ahead even without the slide in travel after the attacks. "We had started quite a bit before Sept. 11," he said in an interview. But he acknowledged that the decline thereafter "reinforced" the logic of an agreement to bring together what he called "very compatible companies, very compatible fleets."
The two companies run cruises in a wide-ranging area that includes Alaska and the Caribbean, with operations in the United States, Britain, Germany and Australia.
Apart from their existing fleets, Royal Caribbean has six ships on order with 14,600 berths. P & O Princess has eight ships with 17,250 berths on order. The new vessels would increase their combined capacity by 2005 to 105,000 berths.
"This is an industry with lots and lots of spare capacity," said Amanda Forsyth, an analyst with Standard Life Investments in Edinburgh. "What they are hoping to do is to build capacity to corner the market, and whatever growth there is in the business going forward. The whole issue is whether they can attract more business as a combined entity."
Larry Norman, president of Vacation and Cruise Resources, a Miami-based company that provides cruise marketing support to the travel industry, said the merger should mean that the combined company would continue to order new ships built. "New ships and low prices should attract them," he said.
Shares in both P & O Princess and Royal Caribbean surged today. In London, P & O Princess rose 16 percent to $:3.6875, or $5.23, while Royal Caribbean shares rose $1.09, or more than 7 percent, to $16.10 in New York. The two companies forecast annual savings from the deal of $100 million, starting in 2003.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Royal Caribbean's new ship, Adventure of the Seas, at a pier in Manhattan. The line's planned merger with P & O Princess is expected to increase orders for new ships. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)(pg. C1); Peter Ratcliffe, left, P & O's chief, and Richard D. Fain, head of Royal Caribbean, in London yesterday. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. C11)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
As Nets Rise, Kidd Seeks Promotion

BYLINE:  By LIZ ROBBINS 

 BODY:
The Nets are 7-3, even after two consecutive losses, and the consensus within the organization and throughout the league is that Jason Kidd is the primary reason for the team's surprisingly strong start.
 Kidd, who came in an off-season trade from Phoenix for Stephon Marbury, has established himself over the first three weeks of the regular season as the chief catalyst for the Nets' revival. 
 And yet, before the Nets left Sunday on a West Coast trip, Kidd and his agent, Jeff Schwartz, expressed concern that neither Kidd nor his teammates were being sufficiently recognized by fans in the New York metropolitan area.
While both emphasized that it was still very early in the season, they wondered whether the organization's strategy of not promoting individual players has had an effect on attendance in the first six home games at Continental Arena, a league-worst average of 9,857. 
The Nets' approach to promotion could also affect Kidd's decision whether to remain in New Jersey when his contract is up in 2003.
"There are a lot of things that will be a part of it, and that will be one of them," Kidd said. "How are they going to market the team? And not just myself. They'll have other guys coming up here shortly -- free agents -- so you got to play the game.
"When a product is hot, you got to be able to package it as much as you can, because you never know how hot or cold it will be. They've probably experienced the cold side, but we're in the biggest market and you got to take advantage of that."
The Nets traded for Kidd in July. But there have been no billboards featuring his image, and there is no marketing campaign designed specifically around Kidd, who is the only four-time All-Star to play for the Nets. 
Schwartz said he has had preliminary discussions with the Nets' management and is taking a wait-and-see attitude, because the season is still so young. "Obviously, in building for the future, Jason is the foundation," Schwartz said. "If you want the ability to keep this team together, then hopefully they will do certain things to make that happen."
The Nets have paid for billboards, but the ads display only the Nets' logo, often next to those of their corporate partners, the Devils and Yankees, with a phone number for tickets. The cover of the Nets' media guide shows only a player's torso. The folds of the jersey reveal the top of the player's uniform number, 5, which is the only clue that the player is Kidd.
The Nets' new chief executive, Lou Lamoriello, who has also run the Devils for years, believes adamantly in not promoting individual stars. 
Lamoriello has also imposed this team-only attitude in the Nets' offices, where employees have been told to tone down their work space by removing personal items and to adhere to a more formal dress code. 
"Right now, what we're doing is what Jason is all about: it's about team," Lamoriello said. 
Lamoriello said he was not concerned that Kidd would consider marketing a factor in his decision on whether to stay in New Jersey when his contract expires. Lamoriello describes his advertising philosophy as old school, saying that "when you put dollars into something, you have to get something in return."
"You cannot get any more recognition than what's been given to Jason," he said. "We're all about winning, and through that the individuals will get the recognition."
Kidd, who is averaging 12.1 points, 9.9 assists and 7.1 rebounds a game, insists that he does not want to be a focal point. But Kidd, 28, is also known as a fierce and savvy competitor, and that attitude extends to the corporate world, as well. He knows that the N.B.A. is personality driven.
"With hockey and basketball, those are two different sports that generate two different products and economics," Kidd said. "One is a lot bigger than the other. You can't run a parallel."
While the Nets began the season with a burst of success, fans have seemed reluctant to buy in quickly, Lamoriello said, perhaps because they are still soured on the unfulfilled promise of seasons past. Winning will ultimately be what lures fans back, he said.
The size of the crowds at Continental Arena grew significantly for the Nets' game against the Knicks last Friday and for a game the next night against Allen Iverson and the Philadelphia 76ers. The Nets drew an average of 16,478 for those games. But what will happen when the Nets return from their road trip next week, perhaps not quite as hot, and play the hapless Chicago Bulls next Tuesday? 
Nets Coach Byron Scott, admittedly concerned only with what takes place on the court, did see a point in generating more fan interest and said that Kidd could be the one to do it. 
"They could promote Jason a little more, that's about it," Scott said. "I think we've done everything on the court. I know that we're not big into promoting things. But he's the one guy we all know who's proven and that's definitely been a guy you can market. But again, it's still real early."
It is early for Schwartz and Kidd, too. Kidd suggested that he and the Nets do not have to wait for his contract to expire to negotiate a new one. "We can solve it a little earlier than two years, next summer maybe," he said. He will be paid $17.6 million over the next two years, with a player option for $10.4 million in 2003. 
"They might have to court my wife more than me," he said with a laugh. "The big thing is: Is my family happy? My wife and my kids, are they going to be happy?
"We'll see what happens. There's a lot of things that need to maybe be looked upon, not just so much marketing, but for making it a family-friendly atmosphere. That's what the game is supposed to be. People need to be able to interact and recognize their team. It's not just me, but Keith or Kenyon, Kerry, that makes people want to come to the game," Kidd said, referring to his teammates Keith Van Horn, Kenyon Martin and Kerry Kittles. 
"Right now, my job is to win ballgames. I think if we win, everything will take care of itself."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CHARITIES; 
Outpouring for Sept. 11 Groups Means Less for Food Banks

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 20 

 BODY:
It has become a Thanksgiving tradition among the poor to come to the soup kitchen at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here for free turkeys to take home to their families. 
 But this Thanksgiving, supporters of the program have donated only about half as many turkeys as in recent years. Instead of 40 or so turkeys, the church received only 20, and they have all been given away by now to some needy families. Everyone else has been invited to a Thanksgiving dinner at the church. 
 "I wish there was enough to go around," said Roberta Apuzzo, the executive director of Community Service Associates, a nonprofit group that operates the church soup kitchen. "After what happened on Sept. 11, I think we need tradition more than ever."
The terrorist attacks have meant that many soup kitchens, food pantries and local charities throughout the New York region are entering the holiday season with fewer food and cash donations on hand than usual. The groups say that they have been hurt by "donor fatigue," because people who made charitable donations in response to the attacks now have much less for local charities, especially during a drop in the economy.
Interviews with food pantries and soup kitchens around the region indicate that several are forgoing the free turkeys for Thanksgiving, and many others are warning that they may have to eliminate year-round meal programs and other services for the poor if things do not improve. In an effort to cope, groups are trying to step up fund-raising, stretch existing resources, and remind people that it is not just the families of Sept. 11 victims who are in need this holiday season.
Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger, said some of the city's 1,000 soup kitchens and food pantries had reported turning away hungry people more often since Sept. 11. "The people on the front lines in the fight against hunger don't have the resources to do their jobs," he said. "As a result, more people are going hungry in the richest city in the richest country in the history of the world." 
Although not every charity has been affected, many of the largest food organizations in New York and New Jersey say they have fallen far short in canned goods and checks as well as turkeys. The severity of the situation may not become clear until early next year because many groups receive most of their donations between now and year's end.
Food for Survival, a nonprofit food bank in New York City that supplies 1,200 low-income programs, said it had received $79,154 from individual donors in September and October, a 38.3 percent decrease from the $128,337 collected during the comparable period last year. "That's a very big decline," said Lucy Cabrera, president of the food bank. "We can only guess that the reason for it is that the donations went to the disaster relief."
An annual turkey drive organized by the Community Food Bank of New Jersey, which is located outside Newark, brought in 2,200 donated turkeys this year, 1,800 fewer than expected. In addition, several companies that had asked their employees to donate turkeys in the past did not do so this year because of layoffs and other economic considerations. The companies that did make the request brought in an average of 20 turkeys each, a fifth of last year's average.
Meara Nigro, a spokeswoman for the food bank, said her organization had used cash reserves to buy more turkeys but was still 1,100 short of the 10,580 turkeys that have been requested by food pantries and other groups for Thanksgiving. In some cases, the food bank plans to distribute sliced turkey breast left over from donations to the World Trade Center relief efforts.
The Community Food Bank also delayed the start of its annual food-donation effort at supermarket checkout counters to avoid competing with a similar campaign by the Red Cross. 
Ms. Nigro said donor fatigue was not the only reason that charitable giving was down this year. Criticism of the Red Cross for its handling of disaster relief has also had an effect, she said. "People feel a lot of suspicion toward all charities right now," she said. "All of the smaller charities are being hurt by that."
The Westchester Coalition for the Hungry and the Homeless canceled an annual fund-raising dinner in October because it did not seem appropriate so soon after the terrorist attacks. The dinner, which was not rescheduled, usually raises about $100,000, a third of the coalition's total donations. 
Rosa W. Boone, the coalition's executive director, said she had tried to make up some of that money through a "stay-at-home dinner" campaign, in which donors give the money that they would normally spend on a restaurant meal. It has raised only $10,000 so far, but Ms. Boone remains optimistic. "I'm definitely short," she said. "I'm hoping that my next letter will touch the hearts of those who have given before."
The decline in donations has been particularly hard on small organizations with limited budgets. Betsy Wiltse, program administrator for the Sullivan County Federation for the Homeless in Monticello, N.Y., said food donations had tapered off by 40 to 50 percent. Her group's soup kitchen received 20 donated turkeys this year, not 50 as usual. 
"This is not a wealthy area," she said. "So when there's that big of a tap into those kinds of resources for a world disaster, local people end up feeling the pinch."
At Sacred Heart Church, Ms. Apuzzo sent out her annual appeal letter in September, two months earlier than usual, but has received only about $3,000 in donations. Last year, she had already raised $9,000 by Thanksgiving. If donations do not pick up, she said she might have to cut back on meals. 
Ms. Apuzzo was still scrounging around for one last turkey tonight for a woman who has been coming to her soup kitchen for four years. She finally found one, and handed it over with holiday wishes. 
The woman, Bobbi Davis, said she planned to cook the turkey for her two young daughters. "I've grown up all my life with a turkey on the table," she said. "My mom said always have your own turkey. It's the spirit of it. You know you're not too poor to have it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shelton Robertson and Lucille Peffers at the soup kitchen in Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y., yesterday. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: McGreevey Says Budget Falls Short by $1.9 Billion 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
After an intensive two-week review of New Jersey's fiscal condition, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey warned today that the state faced a shortfall of $1.9 billion in its current $24 billion budget, far larger than had been anticipated. He also forecast a deficit of $3.7 billion in the next fiscal year.
 At a news conference in his transition offices near the State House this afternoon, Mr. McGreevey urged Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and the State Legislature to refrain from any new nonessential spending through the end of the year. 
 "It is incumbent upon the State Legislature and the acting governor to absolutely freeze spending," Mr. McGreevey said, accompanied by Anthony R. Coscia, who is directing budget operations for his transition team. "Every dollar spent will only place New Jersey in harm's way."
But Mr. DiFrancesco and his fellow Republicans who control the Legislature would seem to have little political motivation to heed the pleas of Mr. McGreevey, a Democrat. Mr. DiFrancesco's spokesman, Tom Wilson, said Mr. McGreevey was exaggerating the problem while not offering solutions. 
"To say the sky is falling yet not provide any umbrella, that's not what being a governor is all about," Mr. Wilson said. "And he knows that." Mr. Wilson acknowledged that tax revenues had decreased, but he called Mr. McGreevey's estimates of the budget gaps "very pessimistic." 
Mr. Wilson said the DiFrancesco administration was willing to work with the governor-elect on any specific concerns that were raised. "On a case-by-case basis, if he wants to bring forward specific recommendations for specific freezes or cuts, we'll work with him," Mr. Wilson said. 
By law, the New Jersey budget must be balanced and the governor, before presenting his spending plan, must show that there are sufficient revenues to cover proposed spending. The state budget signed by Mr. DiFrancesco in July totaled about $23 billion in spending and included a $1 billion surplus. But even earlier, state officials were warning of a looming shortfall because of reduced tax revenues, and estimates of the gap reached as high as $1.2 billion in recent weeks.
At his news conference today, Mr. McGreevey vowed to balance the budget without raising taxes. "We are not going to increase taxes," he said. "We're going to cut government. We are going to live within our means." 
At the conference, he agreed with a suggestion that current circumstances seemed eerily similar to the situation that Gov. Jim Florio faced when he took office in 1990. Mr. Florio raised taxes, and furious voters tossed him out of office after one term. "I'm hoping for a different ending," Mr. McGreevey said, laughing. 
But after the news conference, Mr. McGreevey was speechless and his face turned red when he was asked what motivations the Republicans might have to do anything other than leave him with a big budget hole to fill. "Excellent question," he said, adding that he hoped the Republicans understood "the gravity of the circumstances." 
Mr. McGreevey also renewed his request today that the DiFrancesco administration officially recertify revenues, to provide a clear and updated portrait of tax receipts. Mr. Wilson, the acting governor's spokesman, said that the administration could not comply with the request because economic conditions were too unpredictable. 
For example, Mr. Wilson cited recent increases in both the total number of jobs in New Jersey and in the number of people who are filing first-time unemployment claims, an unusual confluence of the layoffs resulting from the struggling economy and the jobs that have moved to New Jersey from Lower Manhattan since Sept. 11. 
"The science isn't there right now to tell us, 'This is the number,' " Mr. Wilson said, adding: "Anything that you are going to get right now is an educated guess. And frankly, we need more than an educated guess to recertify revenues." 
Mr. McGreevey stressed that the most significant decreases were a result of income tax receipts that were lower than expected.
Independent budget analysts said that Mr. McGreevey's projections seemed plausible. "I would say it could almost be at the midpoint of a reasonable range as far as things look now," said Alan R. Kooney, the budget and finance officer for the State Office of Legislative Services, which does fiscal analysis for the Legislature.
Mr. Kooney said that his office had not done any formal projections since the state budget was approved in July and that it was virtually impossible to make specific predictions about how the fiscal year would end. But he said monthly revenue reports showed a steady decrease in tax receipts throughout this year. 
"So far the revenues are pretty anemic," Mr. Kooney said. 
But he and other experts said that Mr. McGreevey's projections did not account for a number of factors, including a national increase in retail spending during October. State sales tax receipts for October were due on Tuesday, and it will take several weeks to know if there was an increase to match the national trend. 
Senator John O. Bennett, the Republican majority leader, said he believed that Mr. McGreevey's estimates might be unduly grim. "I don't believe that his crystal ball is necessarily totally accurate," he said. Mr. Bennett noted that car sales were up 25 percent in October and that they account for a quarter of sales tax revenues. 
Mr. Bennett said Republicans were not out to sabotage Mr. McGreevey. "We are responsible elected officials," he said. "We intend to leave him a healthy surplus in the budget."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
EASTMAN CHEMICAL POSTPONES ITS PLAN TO SPLIT IN TWO

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Eastman Chemical Company, citing declining market conditions, said yesterday that it had postponed a plan to split itself into two companies at year's end. Eastman, the chemical, fibers and plastics manufacturer based in Kingsport, Tenn., said that because of the weak economy and "a lack of clear signals for near-term recovery," its management recommended delaying the spinoff, and said it would reassess the plan in mid-2002. The company planned to split into the Voridian Company, which would take the PET plastics and fibers business, and the Eastman Company, with the specialty chemicals business.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Aid for Small Companies 

BYLINE:  By Edward Wyatt (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 A business and civic group awarded $650,000 in grants and other aid to 14 small businesses in Lower Manhattan yesterday. The aid is part of a $7 million program to assist retailers and manufacturers harmed by the attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Small Business and Workforce Retention Project offers grants of up to $25,000, low-interest loans of up to $100,000 and payments to subsidize up to 50 percent of some employees' wages. Eligible businesses are those south of Canal Street with no more than 50 employees. The project's sponsors include the Alliance for Downtown New York, Seedco, Asian Americans for Equality and the Henry Street Settlement.
 Edward Wyatt (NYT)

HEADLINE: New Doubts on Enron's India Investment 

BYLINE:  By SARITHA RAI 

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
The fate of the single largest foreign investment in India, the $2.9 billion Dabhol Power project, has been thrown into new uncertainty by the financial meltdown and pending takeover of its majority owner, the Enron Corporation of the United States.
 Dynegy, the smaller rival that has agreed to acquire the once-mighty Enron, has said it will focus narrowly on Enron's core energy trading and pipeline businesses and sell other assets. Enron's 70 percent stake in Dabhol is high on the sales list. 
 But the company's bargaining leverage, already eroded by a bitter, ruinous dispute with the project's only customer, is weaker than ever. "Now that the sale of Dabhol is a certainty, the aggressive Enron may be forced to adopt a pragmatic approach during the negotiations," said K. Ravi, a utility analyst with the consulting firm of Frost & Sullivan.
Dabhol Power's 2,184 megawatts of generating capacity was the showpiece of an economic liberalization drive in the early 1990's. But Enron has had repeated conflicts with politicians and environmentalists over the project. Earlier this year, the Maharashtra state utility, which has a contract to buy all of Dabhol's output, complained that the prices were too high and stopped paying its bills, running up $64 million in arrears before the power was cut off and the plant shut down.
Enron raised the stakes in the dispute by serving notice that it would terminate the contract and pull out of the project. But a group of Indian state-owned banks and financial institutions, with $1.4 billion committed to the project, countered with challenges to asset sales by Dabhol and with other legal obstacles. Earlier this month, a court ordered Dabhol not to send the utility a final termination notice until Dec. 3.
Initially Enron adopted a tough posture over the sale of Dabhol. Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's chairman and chief executive and a close friend of President Bush, was quoted as saying that India would have to face economic sanctions if the government did not create a favorable climate for the sale of Enron's stake.
But Enron now will find little lobbying traction in either Washington or New Delhi, and the coalition-building diplomacy of the war in Afghanistan makes it unlikely that the Bush administration would agree to press India on Enron's behalf. 
In September, the asking price for Enron's stake in Dabhol Power was said to be over $1 billion. But the two serious Indian bidders -- Tata Power and BSES, both privately owned utilities backed by major industrial concerns here -- are reportedly willing to pay only about half that.
If the lenders and prospective buyers adopt a take-it-or-leave-it line, Enron may have little choice but to accept their offer and swallow a huge loss on a controversial project that once gleamed with promise. "It is bound to be a distress sale," one bank official said.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterdayabout the Enron Corporation's prospects for selling its interest in the Dabhol Power project in India misstated the size of its stake. It is 65 percent, not 70.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Conoco Plays Security Card In Promoting Its Merger

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
As he leads the cheers for his company's planned merger with Phillips Petroleum, the chairman of Conoco, Archie W. Dunham, has added a new rationale for the deal that would probably not have been mentioned before Sept. 11: energy security.
 Mr. Dunham at first cited the usual reasons for the union of Conoco and Phillips, like enhancing shareholder value and improving competitiveness. But in recent statements about the merger, which would create the world's sixth-largest oil concern, Mr. Dunham has highlighted the fact that the combined company would have more than 70 percent of its oil and gas reserves in the North Sea and North America, regions free of the political risks in the petroleum-rich Persian Gulf area. 
 "This is good for the United States," Mr. Dunham said during a conference call on Monday. "It's good for energy security."
The stance is somewhat unusual for Conoco, which, after all, has historically been a trailblazer, entering countries where there is plenty of political risk while other companies held back. It has led the effort to repeal the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, which prohibits American companies from investing in those countries, paving the way for European and Asian oil conglomerates to develop some of the best oil and gas fields in the world. 
Industry analysts said Mr. Dunham's comments did not mean Conoco was abandoning the campaign to repeal sanctions or its interest in natural gas projects in places like Saudi Arabia and Indonesia. The language is aimed at regulators, politicians and the broader public, the analysts said, to persuade them to support the merger.
"By tying the merger to a timely issue, one that the public is very sympathetic to, Conoco hopes to get the merger through the regulatory process with a minimum of pain," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Pain would mean the kind of forced divestitures of important assets that the government required when it approved the mergers of Exxon and Mobil and of BP and the Atlantic Richfield Company. It is not clear, in fact, whether the businesses of Conoco and Phillips overlap enough to require selling assets. But highlighting the merger's contribution to national security does not hurt.
"They're buying insurance at no premium by tapping a sensitive vein," Mr. Goldstein said. "So why not throw it out there?"
Could the flag-waving be undermined by Conoco's efforts to have sanctions against Iran and Libya lifted? At first glance, it may appear so, given the years both countries have spent on terrorism watch lists.
But Iran and the United States over the last several years have been edging closer to each other as moderates led by President Mohammed Khattami of Iran to try to reform the country. Easing sanctions would give a boost to Mr. Khattami, industry analysts said. And the entry of United States companies into the country might increase the global oil supply.
"If you lift sanctions, you will see more oil production in the long term," said Cyrus Tahmassebi, president of Energy Trends Inc., a Washington consulting firm, "and that means crude oil prices will go down."
Conoco, for its part, had been doing business in Libya for 47 years, most recently as part of a consortium pumping 500,000 barrels of oil a day, until sanctions imposed by the Reagan administration in 1986 forced its departure. In Iran, it was poised to become the first company to work with the government until sanctions passed in 1995 under the Clinton administration annulled a contract the company had reached to develop offshore gas deposits. The contract went instead to the French company, Total.
"These are truly strategic assets in the petroleum world," said Mike Stinson, senior vice president for government affairs at Conoco, explaining his company's interest, "and important for the long-term energy supply of the United States."
The American government, however slowly, may be coming around to that notion of energy security, too, and Conoco these days is the most hopeful it has been in years that the prohibitions might be eased somewhat. 
"We've been encouraged in the last couple of months," Mr. Stinson said about the relationship between Iran and the United States. "We see evidence of things going on, like very quiet government-to-government talks about the issues that are separating us. If they succeed, we have a bright future."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Microsoft Aims To Settle Suits By Equipping 12,500 Schools

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Microsoft filed a proposal in federal court yesterday that could remove another of its legal headaches: more than 100 class-action antitrust suits contending that it overcharged consumers. The proposed deal is an innovative approach because the proceeds would not go to the customers who say they were overcharged but to more than 12,500 schools in low-income neighborhoods around the country.
 Under the terms of the deal, Microsoft would be required to provide cash, training and support to help put computing services into disadvantaged schools with nearly seven million students. The five-year program would cost Microsoft at least $550 million and possibly far more. The deal is championed by a pair of leading class-action lawyers, Stanley M. Chesley of Cincinnati and Michael D. Hausfeld of Washington. 
 The plaintiffs' lawyers behind the settlement and executives of Microsoft hailed the proposed deal as an inventive way to end costly litigation while helping to narrow the "digital divide." 
But the settlement plan faces resistance from some lawyers in California who say they represent 13 million overcharged personal computer users in their state. 
The California lawyers will oppose the settlement in court next Tuesday. They say that the deal is cleverly altruistic, but that its main beneficiary would be Microsoft. The cost would be tiny compared with Microsoft's potential liability, they contend. And the nearly unlimited donations of Microsoft software to eligible schools, they add, would serve to create an even larger market in the future for the company's products because students would be introduced to computing by using Microsoft products, like Windows, Word and Excel.
"With this settlement, Microsoft gets off dirt-cheap," said Eugene Crew, a partner of Townsend & Townsend & Crew, a law firm in San Francisco, "and it helps Microsoft perpetuate its monopoly."
In the federal court in Baltimore where the Microsoft class-action cases are being considered, Mr. Crew will present next week the analysis of Jeffrey K. MacKie-Mason, an economist at the University of Michigan who estimates that class members in California alone suffered damages of $3 billion to $9 billion from 1994 to 1999. Nationally, the overcharges by Microsoft were $15 billion to more than $40 billion, according to the economic estimate.
Mr. Crew said he hoped to persuade Judge J. Frederick Motz of Federal District Court in Baltimore to reject the proposed settlement. If not, he added, "our case is still alive" in a California Superior Court.
Yet the proposed settlement, some details of which were first reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, promises a stream of money and technology to schools and would probably have great appeal. The plaintiffs' lawyers backing the settlement will present a economist who is a Nobel laureate to defend the wisdom of their approach: Joseph E. Stiglitz, a professor at Columbia University.
Microsoft lawyers said they expected some opposition to the settlement. But if Judge Motz approves the pact, they said, they expect the remaining suits in state courts to fade.
Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, said that the settlement would "avoid long and costly litigation for the company and really make a difference in the lives of children in some of America's most disadvantaged school districts."
The proposed class-action settlement comes a few weeks after the Justice Department and half of the 18 states suing Microsoft agreed to a settlement in the federal antitrust case. Mr. Ballmer said he was optimistic that the remaining state attorneys general would join in this season of settlement.
The plaintiffs' lawyers who engineered the settlement said they had taken the approach of a donation to schools after determining that each individual member of the class might get $10 or so after all administrative and legal fees had been paid. "It was really a matter of practicalities," said Mr. Hausfeld, a partner in Cohen, Milstein, Hausfeld & Toll.
So what had been a "public benefit" provision in early rounds of negotiations eight months ago became the foundation of the settlement.
"We have provided a major solution to the digital divide in our country," said Mr. Chesley, a partner at Waite, Schneider, Bayless & Chesley. 
Under the settlement plan, Microsoft would help set up a national foundation that would give grants to schools to purchase computers and software. Microsoft would begin the foundation with $150 million in cash and would provide up to an additional $100 million if those funds were matched by other donors. Two of the foundation's five board members would be selected by the plaintiffs' lawyers, two by Microsoft and one by the court.
Microsoft would also supply $160 million for a technical support fund overseen by the foundation to help schools use the computer hardware and software, and it would provide $90 million to train teachers and administrators.
The company would also establish a computer refurbishment plan that would make 200,000 computers -- both Windows and Macintosh computers -- available to schools each year for five years. Each refurbished machine would cost a school no more than $50.
Microsoft would also donate software upon request to eligible schools, from kindergarten through high school. Based on Microsoft's standard prices for schools, the value of the software could exceed $500 million, according to the company.
Because the grants could be used for Macintoshes and competing software, Microsoft said, the settlement would not be intended to give the company an even greater advantage in the marketplace. Microsoft does make a lot of software that runs on Macintosh machines, including the Office programs and much of its Magic School Bus software. 
The liberal software donation program would certainly tend to favor Microsoft. An Apple spokeswoman had no comment on the proposal.
Adding in its estimated value of donated software, Microsoft put the value of the settlement at more than $1 billion. But if the court approved the agreement, the company would take a $550 million pretax charge against earnings this quarter. After taxes, the charge would be $375 million, or less than 7 cents a share.
The schools eligible for aid from the settlement would be those in which 70 percent of the students qualify for federal free-lunch programs; that would cover about 14 percent of the students in public schools. The beneficiaries would be in all 50 states.

HEADLINE: In This Company's Struggle, God Has Many Proxies 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: DOWNERS GROVE, Ill. 

 BODY:
At the ServiceMaster Corporation, the forces of God and Mammon are in a tug of war.
 The company, founded in 1947 by an evangelical Baptist, has long declared that its primary mission is "to honor God in all we do." But with profits slumping, the stock price tumbling and big investors up in arms, ServiceMaster has brought in its first chief executive from outside the evangelical fold. And analysts and associates say he will probably soon move to play down the strong emphasis on Christianity. 
 The new chief, Jonathan P. Ward, a former R. R. Donnelley & Sons executive, is walking a corporate minefield, trying to stay true to ServiceMaster's tradition and yet assume the role of reformer at a company that many analysts say became too big and lazy. 
For decades, God and profits seemed to mix well in a potent alchemy that transformed the small Midwestern concern into a $6 billion Fortune 500 company that did well by doing good on everything from Merry Maids house cleaning to Terminix pest control and TruGreen lawn care.
Mr. Ward, who took charge in January, is treading carefully. He calls meetings to order by quoting the book of Isaiah, but he is also heeding calls to change corporate priorities. "He made it clear that his first principle is to increase shareholder value," said John Miller, an assistant portfolio manager at Ariel Capital Management, a large shareholder.
No one is attributing the company's woes solely to its religious orientation; indeed, though religion might be a distraction from focusing on improving ServiceMaster's financial situation, it might be an asset in other ways, like fostering a strong work ethic. And other culprits exist: an expansion that was too rapid and a weak, in-bred leadership lead the list.
Changing ServiceMaster's religious orientation, if that proves necessary, will not be easy. An 11-foot statue of Jesus washing the feet of a disciple sits outside the headquarters here in suburban Chicago. Inside, employees often gather for Bible studies. The motto "We Serve" has decidedly divine implications, annual reports are peppered with Scripture, and stockholder meetings begin with prayer.
The distinct culture does not stop there. Offices are enclosed in glass to create a sense of openness, and a John Philip Sousa march is regularly piped through the building after a big sale.
As long as employees can remember, pleasing shareholders has trailed behind other objectives. The corporate goals -- chiseled, like the Ten Commandments, into a stone tablet at the building's entrance -- rank "To grow profitably" a few notches down from "To help people develop" and "To pursue excellence."
In flush times, no one questioned those priorities. But now Mr. Ward is re-examining the whole company.
His first move was bold. In October, to trim a mounting debt load, Mr. Ward sold the giant management services division, with $1.9 billion in revenue, to the Aramark Corporation for $800 million in cash.
As part of the deal, the company also sold Aramark its Downers Grove headquarters, which has been as much a shrine to the founding principles as an office and training center. The company plans to have a smaller headquarters near Chicago and to move the statue of Jesus to the Memphis office.
Mr. Ward and the board say the moves do not signal a shift away from the company's roots. But some employees suspect that things are about to change.
"I don't know how you can believe that they're not throwing out the old stuff and the old ways," said one longtime executive, who insisted on anonymity. "For God sakes, they're moving Jesus to Memphis."
That may be the least of it. After years of gobbling up companies, ServiceMaster is narrowing its focus to selling house-cleaning and lawn-care services to residential customers -- to focus on "our best opportunity," as Mr. Ward told employees.
The company recently bought the Sears pest control business, adding bulk to its Terminix division in the United States. But the Terminix unit in Europe is gone, and ServiceMaster said it would also exit the landscaping business.
To truly remake ServiceMaster, though, Mr. Ward must decide how to manage a company with its own peculiar history and culture. 
ServiceMaster was founded by Marion E. Wade, who started off in the moth-proofing and rug-cleaning business in the Depression. After he nearly went blind in a chemical accident in 1944, he dedicated himself to the Lord. Mr. Wade, who died in 1973, asserted that running a profitable business was not inconsistent with serving this master. The notion of using the Bible as a guide was spelled out in his book, "The Lord Is My Counsel," which for decades was given to every new manager.
Over the years, many employees joined ServiceMaster because it was perceived as Christian; its management was deemed honest and ethical. (Though the original company was heavily evangelical, the company says it does not discriminate in its hiring.)
Since 1983, however, the company has largely been shaped by C. William Pollard, who as chief executive transformed ServiceMaster with modern management techniques and an aggressive acquisition strategy.
Mr. Pollard, a former lawyer and a Christian, won praise for turning an $800 million company into a $6 billion enterprise. And he wrote a best-selling book, "The Soul of the Firm," that offered his own theories about mixing God and profits.
Under his leadership, ServiceMaster thrived. It was listed among the top service companies in a Fortune survey in 1989. In 1998, The Financial Times called it one of the world's most respected companies.
"This was a great growth machine," said Alexander Paris Jr., an analyst at Barrington Research Associates. "Throughout the 90's, they had compound annual sales growth of 12 percent and net earnings growth of 19 percent."
But ServiceMaster also operated as a family-run company. Mr. Pollard handpicked directors and top managers, and an unusually large number of his choices were family members, friends and graduates of Wheaton College. Wheaton, an evangelical institution in Illinois, counts Billy Graham among its graduates and has a Billy Graham Center and a Marion Wade Center on campus. The company's ties to Wheaton are so strong that franchise owners joke about waiting till summer, when its students are free, to hire extra help.
Mr. Pollard's brother-in-law serves on ServiceMaster's board; his son-in-law is a top executive; a former law partner was general counsel; and one of Mr. Pollard's former Sunday School students is president of the huge management services division. 
The company's board is equally close. Mr. Pollard, who is now the chairman of ServiceMaster, and another director are trustees of Wheaton College; six directors are Wheaton graduates; three directors, including Mr. Pollard, helped form the Avodah Institute, a nonprofit company that lists its home as the ServiceMaster headquarters; and several other directors on the ServiceMaster board are relatives of former executives.
"I can understand the criticism of our board, but before growth slowed nobody raised that question," Mr. Pollard said in an interview.
For an outsider like Mr. Ward, taking control of a complicated culture is not the only problem. The company was weakened by an acquisition spree in 1998 and 1999, when ServiceMaster bought LandCare USA and American Residential Services, helping to saddle the company with $1.7 billion in debt.
"They got lazy and tried to buy growth," said Adam Waldo, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Other problems were brewing. Management services -- running food, janitorial and other services for hospitals and school systems -- were struggling.
In 1999, for the first time in nearly three decades, profit retreated, dropping to $174 million from $190 million in 1998. And the stock, which peaked at $25 a share in 1998, fell to $8 in late 2000, wiping out $5 billion in market value. It has since risen, and in trading on Tuesday it closed at $11.93, up 3 cents.
Several analysts complained that Mr. Pollard, now 63, had lost his touch and his enthusiasm for the job. Among other things, they said he was too busy with philanthropic and charity work tied to the company's foundation and other groups.
By the time Mr. Ward arrived in January, debt had ballooned to nearly $2 billion, and ServiceMaster faced cutting its dividend or watching its debt rating drop to junk bond status. Instead, it sold its management services division.
Some shareholders complained that the company lacked a strong leader and was reluctant to resort to layoffs.
"It wasn't just a couple of bad acquisitions," Mr. Paris, the Barrington analyst, said. "The company is maturing, and it needs to grow into the next phase."
Mr. Ward, 47, is trying to put his stamp on the company. He talks about building on its strength as the No. 1 pest control company (Terminix) and the No. 1 lawn care company (TruGreen ChemLawn).
"There's a $200 billion market for services in the U.S., and I've got $4 billion," Mr. Ward said. "So why do I want to go anywhere else?"
Although analysts praise Mr. Ward for shrinking the company, they expect it to be hurt by a weak economy. "They definitely have businesses that are cyclical," said Fran Blechman Bernstein, at Merrill Lynch. "So the softer economy is something they'll have to overcome."
No layoffs are planned now, but 400 employees, many of whom grew up at the company, will transfer to Aramark with the sale of the management services division. 
Mr. Pollard, still the chairman and drawing a $600,000 salary, may also be on the way out. He talks about stepping down and encouraging changes in the insular board -- a board he selected.
As for Mr. Ward, he is preaching the "willingness to change," as he told employees recently in Memphis.
Wall Street wants ServiceMaster to become more modern and efficient, with or without God. ServiceMaster employees and franchise owners say they welcome the change in leadership, but few expect the company to abandon its roots.
"I don't think there's any chance that will happen," said Rick Armstrong, a franchise owner in Wheaton. "I've heard Jonathan Ward speak twice, and I believe he has a relationship with Christ. And the board has a relationship with Christ. But they aren't naive enough to say ServiceMaster is a church."

HEADLINE: Cablevision Will Increase Rates 5.5% 

 BODY:
 Cablevision Systems Corporation, the New York region's largest cable television provider, said yesterday that it would increase its rates 5.5 percent starting next year. 
The increase reflects higher programming and operating costs, inflation and improvements in service, said Charles Schueler, a company spokesman. Last year's increase averaged 7 percent, he added. AT&T Corporation, the nation's largest cable television provider, raised its rates by an average of 5.5 percent this month. Cablevision has 3 million customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Court Backs Levi Strauss On Pricing 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
In a blow to consumers looking for savings on designer goods, Europe's highest court backed Levi Strauss & Company today in a long-running legal battle to keep cut-price versions of its blue jeans from being sold by Tesco, Britain's biggest supermarket chain.
 The ruling sets a precedent that threatens to crimp Tesco's practice of selling at a discount many "gray market" designer goods, like Nike sneakers and Calvin Klein underwear. It may thwart Tesco's efforts to upend the rules imposed on retailers by manufacturers who want to defend the exclusivity and high prices of goods with their brands. 
 "If we had won today," said Simon Soffe, a spokesman for Tesco, "this would have significantly changed the way the whole of the world trades."
Central to the dispute is the practice, widespread among companies like Levi Strauss, of selling the same or similar goods at widely different prices to outlets in different countries, depending on local market conditions. Levi's 501 jeans, for instance, typically retail for about $80 a pair in the company's leading London outlet, but sell in the United States for only $40 -- the price Tesco charges.
Retailers like Tesco and the Asda supermarket chain in Britain, part of Wal-Mart Stores, have responded by buying goods in countries where prices are lower and importing the goods on their own for sale. That creates a gray market of legitimate goods sold at prices that undercut the manufacturer's intentions.
The ruling by the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg represents a "strong win for brand owners," said Joe Middleton, the president of Levi Strauss Europe, in a statement. But Delroy Corinaldi, a spokesman for the Consumers' Association, a British advocacy group, said the ruling was appalling because it restricted consumers' access to lower prices and choices in where to shop.
Tesco had been pressing for the freedom to stock its shelves with jeans bought from wholesalers in America or outside the European Union and associated countries. It could then offer the jeans at a low markup to draw shoppers into its stores.
But Levi Strauss claimed a "right to decide the way in which we distribute our products to best serve our customers," Mr. Middleton said.
Paola Brandi, a Levi Strauss spokeswoman in Brussels, said that the company did not dictate prices at its 17,000 authorized European retailers, which range from department stores to small shops. She said prices reflected a complex array of factors.
Tesco said that it sold about 10,000 pairs of Levi's jeans a month, relying on intermediaries and wholesalers in Continental Europe. The company argued that this was permissible as long as the jeans were meant to be sold in the European Economic Area.
But the court said trademark owners, like Levi Strauss, must grant permission "unequivocally" before goods made outside the European Economic Area could be sold within the European Union. 
Mr. Soffe said Tesco would petition the European Commission and the British government to change the law. Starting on Wednesday, he said, Tesco stores will add name-brand hi-fi systems to its offerings of discounted gray-market merchandise.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
The 55-Cent Solution

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
When Gerald Ford turned down New York City's appeal for financial aid, the front page of The Daily News screamed "Ford to City: Drop Dead." Those were the days.
 These days, only diligent newspaper readers know that George W. Bush has backed off his personal pledge to provide aid to the battered city. And only serious policy wonks know that this is part of a broader picture -- that the economic measures now being discussed in Washington will impoverish state and local governments across the country. 
 Gerald Ford didn't really deserve that headline. He had never promised anything to a city whose fiscal woes were, without question, largely self-inflicted. Why should he have felt compelled to help?
This time, the story is different. Mr. Bush, you may recall, had a rocky couple of days after the terrorist attack. Some questioned his movements on Sept. 11; in New York there was some anger that he did not quickly visit the city. The White House responded to the first criticism with its story about a "credible threat" to Air Force One. More important, Mr. Bush quickly mended his fences in New York by promising members of the state's Congressional delegation that he would provide ample aid -- he told Senator Charles Schumer that the city had a "blank check." 
Mr. Bush may not have been specific about the details, but all involved thought they knew what he had promised. Every news story I've been able to find from those early days declared that Mr. Bush would allocate half the $40 billion proposed antiterrorism package to New York. And this was widely regarded as only a first installment. 
But last week the House Appropriations Committee finally filled in the details. And the antiterrorism package, which closely followed the administration's guidelines, contained only $9 billion for New York, less than half the promised $20 billion. In last-minute negotiations with irate Republican congressmen this was raised to $11 billion; but that's still only 55 cents on the dollar.
Administration officials say they will eventually provide the full $20 billion. But since they haven't kept Mr. Bush's promise to include that sum in the antiterrorism package, why should we believe them? As the memory of the attack recedes, as the administration returns to its pre-Sept. 11 embrace of hard-line conservatives -- which has pretty much happened already -- it becomes less and less likely that New York will see the rest of the money.
There may never be a specific day when the Bush administration tells the city to drop dead. Instead there will be vague promises, and then a lot of creative accounting -- for example, the costs of deploying the National Guard will be counted as part of the $20 billion. But more and more it seems that the aid New Yorkers thought they had been promised, the aid that was supposed to help rebuild the city, was a mirage.
As I said, this is part of a broader picture. The combination of an economic slump and the effects of Sept. 11 has placed state and local governments across the country in a severe financial squeeze. Since almost all state governments are required by law to balance their budgets, this will force draconian cuts in spending. 
You might have expected the "stimulus" packages being floated in Washington to provide some help to state governments in this difficult time. On the contrary, they will compound the damage. Proposals that would exempt large chunks of corporate profits from federal taxes will also reduce the profits subject to state taxes. Next year, in all likelihood, will present quite a spectacle: big tax cuts for corporations and people who make more than $300,000 per year, even as desperate state governments slash spending -- with the biggest cuts falling on education and medical care for the poor.
Coming back to New York, what puzzles me is how little attention the story of the promise that wasn't is getting. In the weeks after Sept. 11, everyone took it for granted that there would be a great national effort to help rebuild the city. Now it is clear that this won't happen; the administration may claim to be providing what it promised, but New York will have to beg for every dollar of that $20 billion. 
Where's the outrage? Have New Yorkers, of all people, forgotten how to complain?

HEADLINE: White House Cancels Christmas Tours 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the White House was canceling its public Christmas tours, an announcement that set off groans among local officials who fear that the shutdown contradicts the president's call for normalcy and furthers the image of a capital under siege.
 "Evil knows no holiday," the president told reporters. "Evil doesn't welcome the Thanksgiving or Christmas season, and in these extraordinary times, we're taking extraordinary measures." 
 The White House is also limiting access to the lighting of the national Christmas tree on the Ellipse on Dec. 6. Just 2,000 ticketholders will be allowed to attend, White House officials said. In years past, the ceremony has been open to the public. 
The Washington region has lost $10 million a day since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, city officials said.
Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the Secret Service had made the decision to bar tourists from viewing the holiday decorations, a longstanding tradition. The White House has been closed to tourists since Sept. 11, and Mr. Fleischer said today that it would remain closed indefinitely.
"No one wants to be in a position where the public is not welcome in the people's house," he said. "This building does belong to the country. It belongs to the people. But I think the people are the first to recognize that these are extraordinary times. Our nation is at war."
The virtual sealing off of the White House has distressed local officials, who say that it is one of the top draws for tourists and that every day it remains closed is another day the region suffers. The officials also said the closing was particularly difficult to understand while Mr. Bush was calling for normal activities and encouraging people to travel.
Moreover, the officials said, the closing is at odds with a new television advertising campaign that uses the actors from "The West Wing" to urge tourists to visit Washington.
"Welcome to your nation's capital, a fortress city," said Representative Constance A. Morella, a Maryland Republican who is chairwoman of the House subcommittee that oversees the District of Columbia.
Ms. Morella said Washington was expected to lose $1.25 billion by the end of the year.
"If you want people to go back to normal, you have to let them," she said.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's nonvoting delegate to Congress, said she expected a top-level meeting between the administration and local officials before the end of the year to discuss the effects of the closings.
"I think that the problem is that the only people at the table are the security people," Ms. Norton said. "All the options need to be on the table before you take the most draconian option."
Karen P. Hughes, counselor to Mr. Bush, said the fight against terrorism was something that the president "expects we will be dealing with throughout his administration and into many future administrations."
A spokeswoman for the Washington Convention and Tourism Corporation, Victoria Isley, was more upbeat than the politicians. Hotel occupancy has climbed, Ms. Isley said, to a high of 72 percent by Nov. 4 from a low of 25 percent the week after Sept. 11. Nov. 4 was the last date for which she had statistics.
"Washington, D.C., is open for business and open for the holidays," Ms. Isley said, adding that the White House was not the sole attraction in town. 
Tony Bullock, a spokesman for Mayor Anthony A. Williams, said studies showed that the top three attractions here were tours of the White House, the Capitol and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. All are closed. Shutting off the holiday tour at the White House, Mr. Bullock said, "is like going to Paris and not being able to visit the Eiffel Tower."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: RECONSTRUCTION; 
U.S. and 21 Other Nations Vow To Spend Billions on Afghanistan

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN with STEPHANIE FLANDERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
The United States and 21 other nations agreed today to spend billions of dollars to reconstruct Afghanistan after the war, as officials said they were prepared to pay for "high-impact" farm, road and school-building projects to try to win over the Afghan people as soon as the Taliban are defeated.
 Though discussions were still in the early stages, some officials estimated privately that the cost of feeding, clothing and housing people and ultimately creating a functioning society in Afghanistan would reach $10 billion. 
 The task seemed likely to dwarf recent reconstruction efforts in East Timor and Kosovo, which have much smaller populations and less devastation from war.
"The vast majority of the Afghan people awaken hungry, cold and sick every morning," Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said at a conference on aid convened at his agency this morning. 
"All of us know that the international community must be prepared to sustain a reconstruction program that will take many, many years."
While the United States and its allies have yet to defeat fully the Taliban or Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's organization, officials said they had begun preparing a blueprint for reconstruction because nations were more likely to pledge large amounts of money now than later, before so-called donor fatigue sets in.
Some also said that the war could end abruptly, while major aid projects take months to get under way.
"We are very focused on quick-hitting projects that can inspire hope that the international community is able and ready to help people live better lives," said Al Larson, undersecretary of state for economic affairs.
He referred in particular to improving irrigation to create viable farms and to building schools that would be open to girls and women, both as students and teachers, as projects that had the potential to deliver quick benefits to large numbers of people.
The Bush administration has emphasized since it began attacking targets in Afghanistan last month that it considers the aid mission there an urgent priority. Military aircraft dropped food packets to refugees even as they dropped the first bombs. 
The administration is also eager to rebut the contention that the United States is waging war on Islam generally, while it is also seeking to ease the extreme poverty that helped make Afghanistan a terrorist base.
But the cost and complexity of rebuilding Afghanistan could prove as formidable as the effort to oust the Taliban and capture or kill Mr. bin Laden. 
Experts say that international aid often goes to waste when it is suddenly showered on undeveloped nations and that it can be almost impossible to distribute effectively in countries that lack stable governments.
Moreover, the costs in Afghanistan are likely to rise over time. Delivering food and basic medical care, considered emergency priorities, is far less expensive than building roads, schools and hospitals, or training teachers and government officials.
"It's really three to five years out that it will really get expensive," said Mark Malloch Brown, the administrator of the United Nations Development Program, who attended today's session in Washington. 
"The trick is to turn today's political support into a check" that can be banked for aid programs several years hence, he said.
The meeting today, arranged on short notice by the United States and Japan, brought together officials from Britain, Germany, Saudi Arabia and other major donor countries, as well as the United Nations and the World Bank, which are expected to administer most of the aid.
Officials said they would finish preparing a more concrete plan of action and costs by January, when a major conference on aid is scheduled to take place in Japan.
"It is the early days yet," said William Byrd, the World Bank's country director for Afghanistan. "But we want to keep moving quickly because no one can predict how fast political events will move."
Few officials are willing to give a public estimate of the cost of rebuilding an economy in which the most recent economic statistics date to 1994.
The World Bank calculated in a recent study that just clearing known minefields in the country would cost $500 million, more than the entire reconstruction budget for East Timor.
Even before the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan in 1978, setting off more than two decades of armed resistance and civil war, the country was one of the world's poorest. 
Most institutions in Afghanistan will have to be built from scratch.
Other recent reconstruction efforts have ranged from $700 per person in the case of East Timor to roughly $1,500 per person in the West Bank and Gaza, according to the World Bank. 
Those places have much smaller populations than Afghanistan's 25 million people, though.
Some United Nations officials have compared the task in Afghanistan to a five-year rebuilding effort for Mozambique after a civil war there ended in 1992. Other countries and international groups ultimately spent $6.5 billion, or just under $400 for each of the nation's 17 million people.
A slight silver lining in Afghanistan's long history of war and drought is that it has a standing army of aid workers, many of them Afghans, who have years of experience running basic social services in the countryside and delivering aid. 
There are now 2,200 Afghans working in their own country for United Nations agencies, for example.
The United Nations aims to increase that number to 10,000 by the middle of next year.
"Because it's been in difficulty for so long you have homegrown experience and capacity to build on," said Mr. Byrd of the World Bank. 
"You also have several million Afghans who've gone through the refugee experience and have skills or have learned skills because refugees by the nature have to become entrepreneurial." 
Officials said they were trying to make longer-term rebuilding aid meld seamlessly with ongoing aid efforts to avoid what Mr. Malloch Brown called the "funding gap" that often opens up when an immediate crisis fades.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and a representative from Japan, Sadako Ogata, at a conference yesterday on rebuilding Afghanistan. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. B5)

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Consultants Put Aside Rivalries for New York

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON

 BODY:
Kathryn Wylde did not think twice about asking half a dozen consulting firms that have always viewed one another as archcompetitors to work together on a study of the terrorist attack's economic impact.
 "Ignorance is bliss," Ms. Wylde, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, said with a wry smile. 
 But she learned quickly how unusual the collaboration was when, at one of the first meetings in late September, the financier Henry R. Kravis looked at the participants and said, "Seeing you work together surely must be a first-time event." 
The firms' joint report, which was released last week and which forecast at least $83 billion in losses, was an important tool for city planners. But for the consulting industry, its making was a test of how such highly competitive and ordinarily secretive rivals would function as a unit. As it turned out, it was a sometimes messy process that left both bruised feelings and new friendships in its wake.
"I didn't appreciate, when first thinking about it, what a unique situation it was," said Ms. Wylde, whose group represents major employers and business leaders. "But I was confident that all this talent could in fact be corralled and pushed in one direction."
Crunched out in five weeks as a pro bono project, the study involved more than 70 management consultants from Booz Allen Hamilton, A. T. Kearney, McKinsey & Company, the Boston Consulting Group, Bain & Company and PwC Consulting. KPMG, the tax and accounting firm, also took part.
The firms jumped at the chance to participate in part because the project was a networking godsend for an industry hard hit by the recession. Booz Allen Hamilton, A. T. Kearney and PwC have laid off employees this year, and many firms are seeking more pro bono work, both to keep employees busy and to drum up business.
Especially attractive was the fact that the board included some of New York's most illustrious business leaders, including Mr. Kravis, the founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Sanford I. Weill, the Citigroup chairman. Consultants rarely get to meet Mr. Kravis three times in five weeks, as some did during this project.
Still, the spirit of solidarity that was born of the attacks inspired the consultants to levels of cooperation that were once unimaginable, participants said. At one point, for example, McKinsey helped PwC assess how the downturn in advertising would affect media companies.
"The attacks put me into as deep a funk emotionally as really I've ever been," said Scott L. Corwin, a vice president at A. T. Kearney. "This project personally gave me a way for me to channel the grief I felt, the sadness I felt, the overwhelming sense of lack of control about the world we live in."
At a first meeting, where the firms were divvying up sectors of industry to study, top partners anxiously tiptoed around one another. Few had met anyone from a competing firm. "It was almost like a tea party," said Joanna Barsh, a McKinsey director. "Everybody had white gloves on. Everybody said, 'What would you like to do?', 'Oh please, what would you like to do? After you.' I was surprised. These are all type-A people."
Still, tensions rose and fell as three levels of consultants got down to the meat of the report. At each firm, a "sector team" produced initial findings, mainly based on Federal Reserve data and interviews with the business community. A group of team leaders met to integrate the information, and seven senior partners -- one from each firm -- made decisions on how to proceed.
At first, much time was spent debating logistics, like how to alert people to meetings on short notice. "It wasn't as bad as, 'Should we use blue pencils or red ones?', but it got close to that," one participant said.
"It was the best of consulting and the worst of consulting," Ms. Barsh said. "It was really easy to get to work. They were all professionals. On the other hand, you had seven consulting firms, all simultaneously trying to help."
While egos were mostly parked at the door, the participants engaged in much competitive jockeying. Younger workers traded information about their workplaces, perhaps with an eye toward future jobs. The core team of seven senior partners was called alternately "The Island," as in the setting for the television show "Survivor," or the "Seven Samurai."
Even the food drew notice. People grumbled when McKinsey called a 5 p.m. emergency meeting and served only bottled water. Booz Allen Hamilton, which donated office space to the project, won kudos because Reginald Van Lee, a lanky Texan managing partner, made sure Krispy Kreme doughnuts and hot lunches were routinely served. 
The worst sticking points in the process came in wrangling over what role Lower Manhattan should take in the city's future and which firm should write the final presentation. Participants debated whether to urge the government to subsidize the rebuilding of office space in Lower Manhattan or instead let the private sector do the job. Ultimately, they chose the private sector.
Some feelings were bruised at the project's end when one partner rewrote the final slide presentation before a report to civil and business leaders, including former President Bill Clinton.
Still, participants said they wound up the project feeling a mixture of relief and pride, and many made professional friendships. Plus, one manager has a new view of his job.
"My wife is an elementary-school teacher, and when I talk to friends I always used to say, 'at least one of us does something good for society,' " said Anand Raghuraman, a team leader on the project for A. T. Kearney. "Here, for the first time, I could say I was actually doing something for society."
