HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
Less Stuff To Strut, But a Show Goes On

BYLINE:  By David Pogue 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, you might have described Comdex, the annual high-tech trade show, as the biggest computer show on earth. It would be safer to describe this year's edition, however, as the biggest computer show in Las Vegas. This month. So far.
 Its organizer, Key3 Media, says attendance in this post-crash tech economy was down 40 percent from the usual 200,000. But highly placed sources -- five cab drivers I met -- dismissed that figure with a chuckle. Based on years of honing their fares-to-attendance formulas, they said the attendance looked more like 70,000 to them. 
 Either way, the difference from last year was dramatic. The show's exhibit space contracted, leaving one of its traditional show floors, the Sands Convention Center, unoccupied for the first time in years. But in some ways, Comdex Lite was a more worthwhile trade show. 
For the first time in perhaps a decade, the aisles felt like real pathways instead of Times Square on New Year's Eve. You could actually approach booth personnel and conduct meaningful discussions instead of just shouting "How much?" before being swept away by the throngs.
There were fewer exhibitors this year, too. Rather than paying, for example, $50,000 for a booth, many companies, newly budget-conscious, opted to conduct their business in hotel suites around the city. And not everyone who did rent booths had products to hawk. Perhaps in hopes of attracting some of Silicon Valley's freshly unemployed, some exhibitors pitched locales instead, including Egypt, Dubai and Wyoming.
On the other hand, one company's presence was so enormous, the show might have been called Microsoftdex. To be sure, it's a big year for Microsoft, which spared no expense in spotlighting its new wares: Windows XP, Office XP, Pocket PC software and the Xbox game console. The company set up about a dozen Xboxes, amplified and projected on big screens, so that attendees could unwind with a little 3-D simulated violence. Everybody loved it, except perhaps the string trio at the adjacent exhibit.
But Microsoft aside, what remained of the show was still enough to provide a look at the technologies that may well dominate the news in the coming year.
For example, 2002 is shaping up to be the year of the smartphone. Handspring, Samsung, Kyocera, Nokia and others showed their latest attempts to fulfill the dream of the information worker: to combine all of today's belt-borne electronics -- Palm organizer, cellphone and text pager -- into a single gadget. 
Few phones could be smarter, though, than those on display in the huge yellow booth of NTT DoCoMo, Japan's leading cellular service. Goggle-eyed Americans pressed their noses to the display cases to get a better look at tiny, gleaming cellphones that are now available only in Japan, including a cellular videophone that would have made Dick Tracy drool.
More than one American wondered why DoCoMo was at Comdex at all. Was it just to rub our noses in how badly American cellular networks lag behind those of other countries? (Answer: Not exactly. With AT&T as its partner, DoCoMo hopes to bring its products and service to the American marketplace in the next few years.)
Comdex 2001 also served as a coming-out party for Bluetooth, a wireless technology whose failure to materialize after years of hype had made it the butt of sarcastic computer-industry jokes. 
The original concept seemed sound: Bluetooth-equipped gadgets can communicate with each other, via radio waves, at distances up to about 30 feet. Someday, we'll no longer need wires to connect our printers, laptops, phones and palmtops. At Comdex after Comdex, however, no real Bluetooth products were available, and the earliest prototypes spoke such different dialects that they couldn't even understand one another.
This year, the electronics companies were finally ready to strut their stuff. Palm Computing demonstrated tiny S.D. (Secure Digital) cards (the size of a postage stamp) and other Bluetooth attachments that permit palmtops to make printouts on compatible printers, surf the Net through compatible network base stations, and blast data to other Palms across the room -- all wirelessly.
Bluetooth also seems a natural fit with cellphones like the Bluetooth-equipped models from Ericsson. If you've snapped a Bluetooth card into your Palm, you can dial your Bluetooth phone from the palmtop's address book. And if you've popped a NextLink BlueSpoon (coming next year) into your ear, you can hide the phone in your pocket as you walk down the street, chatting away to an invisible colleague. The BlueSpoon, which resembles a translucent blue gumball, communicates with the phone by Bluetooth signals -- and picks up your voice via skull vibrations.
The events of Sept. 11 were too recent to have effected many changes in the industry's Comdex plans. That must be why Samsung, Sony, LG Electronics and other makers were still featuring stunningly big, bright, thin flat-panel TV screens that cost up to $8,000. That price (for Sony's new 60-inch model, due in January) is far lower than that of last year's models. But for most showgoers, such wall-filling screens remain an unattainable object of technolust.
Thanks to the country's heightened sense of vulnerability, the exhibitors in the Biometrics Pavilion unexpectedly found themselves the belles of the ball. These tiny companies have been at Comdex every year. But suddenly their "Mission: Impossible" style fingerprint scanners, eyeball scanners, face scanners and voice-identification systems were all the rage. (The most talked-about security system, however, was the one at the Comdex gates. Although attendees entered through metal detectors, they were told to pass their bags around the detectors and pick them up, uninspected, on the other side.) 
No obviously important new technologies surfaced at Comdex this year. Instead, the show was all about evolution: better digital cameras, brighter projectors, cheaper robot dogs. (The show was also all about silver. So much silver paint covered the products of Comdex this year that from a distance, it could have been the Tin Man's family reunion.)
If the keynote speakers had a single message to their financially shell-shocked comrades, it was, "Cheer up." Bill Gates of Microsoft, Jeff Hawkins of Handspring and Kunitake Ando of Sony, for example, each took the stage to paint a bright picture of technology's near future. 
If the exhibitors had such a message, it was, "Think about something else." Booth after booth featured sports cars, female models or those 60-inch flat screens, all calculated to catch the eyes of the predominantly male audience. Mercedes even let showgoers drive $120,000 cars around a gigantic test track in the convention-center parking lot.
The funny thing was that amid the gloom, grounds for optimism could indeed be found even at this downsized Comdex. Yes, PC sales have leveled off, but when the economic pendulum swings back, whether that's in 5 months or 10, the tech industry will be ready to roll with circuitry in a wide range of appealing and useful new forms. 
Until then, it's hard to forget the sight of the oxygen bars that one enterprising company set up outside the show's exits. For $12, attendees could spend five minutes breathing pure oxygen through nasal tubes. 
As one of the most difficult years in high-tech history comes to a close, the sight of oxygen being administered to weary computer executives may have been a more apt metaphor than Comdex's organizers would like to admit.

HEADLINE: When Prisoners Study 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 That such an obviously sensible policy as educating prisoners has not been examined systematically before the Department of Education study reported in your Nov. 16 news article ("Inmate Education Is Found to Lower Risk of New Arrest") suggests that there has been more to the issue than financial, moral or justice concerns. 
 Creating a consensus on the social worth of prisoner higher education will require overcoming the perception that an "undeserving" population is gaining an advantage or entitlement denied to many hard-working citizens. 
Not until there is universal opportunity for postsecondary education can we expect much public support for prisoner programs. Unfortunately, the recession and the Sept. 11 aftermath create an especially inhospitable climate for either reform. 

ROBERT P. WEISS
Plattsburgh, N.Y., Nov. 17, 2001

The writer is a professor of sociology and criminal justice, State University of New York at Plattsburgh.

HEADLINE: Four U.S. Companies Sign the First Trade Deals With Cuba 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Four American companies became the first in four decades to sign trade accords with Cuba and will supply food worth about $20 million to aid in the recovery from Hurricane Michelle, a business official said today.
 Representatives of the companies -- Archer Daniels Midland, Cargill, Riceland Foods and ConAgra -- were in Havana this week to sign the agreements with the state company Alimport to provide wheat, corn, soy and rice, said John Kavulich, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council. 
 The deals came after Cuba, which has been subject to a United States embargo since soon after President Fidel Castro's revolution in 1959, appealed to Washington to speed up authorization to buy food and medicines from the United States on a one-time basis to replenish stocks used after the hurricane hit on Nov. 4. 
The storm, the worst in five decades, severely damaged crops earmarked for both export and local needs.
Washington had first offered to send humanitarian aid via nongovernment bodies, but Havana replied with a polite refusal and a counteroffer to buy food and medicines with cash.
Archer Daniels Midland signed the first of its contracts on Tuesday, for about 20,000 metric tons of wheat at a market value of around $2.5 million, Mr. Kavulich said.
Cuba is estimated to want products totaling about $30 million, of which Archer Daniels Midland, Cargill and Riceland appear to have won the largest share.
There was no immediate confirmation from Cuban officials on the deals, which still require approval by the United States Commerce Department.
But Cargill's director of international business development, Van Yeutter, confirmed his company's agreement to sell 20,000 metric tons of wheat, 19,000 tons of corn and 5,000 tons of crude vegetable oil for shipment in January and February.
A spokesman for Archer Daniels Midland, Larry Cunningham, confirmed the company had sold Cuba "tens of thousands" of tons of food products for shipment in the next week to 10 days. The products are expected to be transported on American ships or those of a third country.
Mr. Kavulich said another three companies, Gold Kist of Georgie, Tyson Foods in Arkansas and Perdue Farms in Maryland, were likely to win some remaining Cuban contracts. 
Havana has stressed that the sales are exceptional because of the hurricane damage, and has reiterated its appeal for a full lifting of the embargo.
"The contracts being signed with Cuba should not be seen as as a start of an ongoing commercial relationship with Cuba," Mr. Kavulich said. "They are taking place under a humanitarian umbrella after Hurricane Michelle as the Cubans have made clear they don't expect to continue with these purchases." 
But the contracts may be an important crack in the embargo, which is opposed by a significant farm and business lobby in the United States.
"The hurricane seems to have broken the logjam," said Phil Peters, vice president of the Washington-based Lexington Institute and a former State Department official who has traveled extensively in Cuba.
The situation has not only brought a symbolic sale to Cuba but has helped reinforce both sides' positions on the embargo.
Washington can demonstrate what it has long been arguing -- that sales of food and medicine are in fact possible thanks to modifications of the embargo legislation, if there is a political will in Cuba.
Havana has an opportunity to open a chink in the sanctions, stoke the internal American anti-embargo lobby and perhaps move up Cuba on President Bush's increasingly crowded foreign policy agenda.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Take Step Backward In Trading Before Holiday

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated further from bull-market territory yesterday, as traders hesitated to hold big positions going into the Thanksgiving holiday with worries about the short-term health of the economy and corporate earnings.
 Even a bullish economic report, which showed the number of Americans lining up for first-time unemployment benefits was down for a fourth consecutive week, could not overcome fears that a recovery was still a way off. 
 "The market has been levitating -- you could pass a hoop over it and see there's not a lot of fundamental support," said Jeffrey Kleintop, chief investment strategist for PNC Advisors, who said his firm had sold bonds but was holding cash instead of buying stocks. 
"Jobless claims were down," he said, "and that's a good sign, but we're still a long way from seeing the bottom in earnings for corporations."
Indeed, analysts do not expect quarterly profits to start to increase again until at least the second quarter of next year, according to the market research firm Thomson Financial/First Call.
Amgen bolstered health shares after the company, a leader in biotechnology, said strong sales of new drugs would help earnings increase faster than analysts had expected. But big technology names like Microsoft fell.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 66.70 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 9,834.68, down for the second session after clambering into bull-market territory on Monday. A bull market is defined as a gain of at least 20 percent from a recent low.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 5.63 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,137.03, while the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 5.46 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,875.05.
The market is closed today for Thanksgiving; there will be a half-day of trading tomorrow.
Enron, the most-active stock on the New York Stock Exchange for a second consecutive session, tumbled $1.98, to $5.01, on worries the company may not stay afloat long enough to be rescued in a pending takeover by Dynegy.
Enron said it had won a three-week reprieve from its banks on a $690 million note and reaffirmed its agreement to be taken over by Dynegy. But shares remained lower after the announcement. --------------------

Treasuries Are Lower
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as jobless claims declined for a fourth week and a consumer confidence index rose, bolstering expectations the economy may have bottomed.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 22/32, to a price of 100 14/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.95 percent from 4.87 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32, to 100 11/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.35 percent from 5.32 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Hunger in the City

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
If you're interviewing people lined up at soup kitchens and food pantries in New York City, many will offer you their phone numbers and ask if you know where they might find work. Politely, quietly, often a little desperately, they'll ask you to let them know "if you hear of something."
 There's a shortage of jobs in the city at the moment, which means there's a shortage of food. The weather is getting colder and the lines of people in search of a hot meal, or a package of food that will help get the family through another week or two, are getting longer. 
 Germania Barahona was able to pick up some groceries on Tuesday at a food pantry in the basement of the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The pantry is run by the West Side Campaign Against Hunger.
"This is my first time here," Ms. Barahona said. "I had a job up until Sept. 11. I was a nanny for a woman that worked in the towers. When they fell she lost her job, and I lost mine."
Edwin Asencio was also at the pantry, with his wife, Edith, and their 3-year-old grandson, Mark. "I used to make $1,000 a week," he said. "I never came to a place like this."
He said he had been forced to stop working after suffering several heart attacks. Now he's grateful for the food assistance. He seemed to sum up the tradeoffs that are an inevitable part of tough times when he casually noted, "I have to walk sometimes instead of taking the train so I can use the fare to buy milk for my grandson."
There are more than 1,000 soup kitchens and food pantries in the city, and they are stretched beyond capacity. The pantry at St. Paul and St. Andrew is serving nearly twice as many people as last year.
"We are blown away by the neediness we're seeing," said the church's pastor, the Rev. James Karpen. "We're trying to make it as dignified an experience as possible."
This problem is not limited to New York in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack. Even before Sept. 11, an alarming number of Americans were lining up for emergency food assistance. Those seeking help included the jobless, a majority of whom do not qualify for unemployment benefits; working poor families that do not earn enough money to cover the cost of food as well as their other necessities, like rent and utilities; the elderly, including many men and women faced with the heartbreaking choice of paying for food or paying for medicine; immigrants ineligible for welfare or food stamps; and a wide range of individuals struggling with substance abuse, physical disabilities and mental illness.
"The demand for food is so high it's outstripping our ability across the system to replenish it," said Robert Forney, president and chief executive officer of America's Second Harvest, a national network of nonprofit food banks that provides 80 percent of the food distributed by private charities.
Last year in New York, about 20 percent of the pantries in the city had to turn people away because they ran out of food. That figure is expected to reach 30 percent this year, according to Joel Berg, director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger.
A survey of food pantries and soup kitchens released this week by the coalition showed a rapid rise in the demand for food assistance in the first several months of this year, and then a dramatic additional surge in demand following the Sept. 11 attack.
The coalition called its survey "From Bad to Worse."
The survey said, "The city's mostly volunteer-staffed soup kitchens and food pantries, more than two-thirds of which are faith-based, are finding it harder and harder to keep up with the ever-growing crowds at their facilities."
When you talk about hunger in America, the problems are not the same as in Somalia or North Korea or Afghanistan. Americans are not starving in the streets. But there is still something very wrong, in a society as affluent as ours, when families have to choose between food and rent, or when parents have to forgo a meal so their children can eat, or when the elderly look wistfully at food on television -- food they can't have because they spent their money on their medicine.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Payments Steady In September, S.& P. Reports 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Americans kept up payments on their credit card bills in September, despite an unstable job market and the terrorist attacks, the bond rating service Standard & Poor's said yesterday. 
 But the ability of card users to meet debt obligations will probably be pinched in the coming months if more workers lose their jobs, S.& P. warned. 
 "Consumer confidence continues to show signs of weakness with U.S. consumers nervous and the job market getting worse," S.& P. said.
The rating service's two barometers of credit card loan performance were stable in September compared with the numbers for August. 
Its monthly measure of bad credit card loans that card issuers wrote off was 6.5 percent in September, unchanged from August but still 1.4 percentage point higher than a year ago.
S.& P. had projected that the charge-off rate would climb to 8.4 percent. 
Its gauge of late credit card payments was unchanged from August at 5.1 percent. But the September figure was still up from 4.4 percent a year ago. 
But S.& P. noted that 80 percent of card issuers reported higher delinquencies in September than August.
It blamed a larger number of late payments on mail service disruption and slower collection efforts after the Sept. 11 attacks. 
Credit card issuers would be helped by another rate cut by the Federal Reserve before the end of the year, the rating service said.

HEADLINE: A's Soar at Harvard, Nearing a Majority 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Nearly half of the grades at Harvard University last year were A or A-minus, a steep increase from just 10 years earlier, a university study of grade inflation has found. 
 The report, issued on Tuesday, charted grades for the last 15 years and found that A's and A-minuses grew to 48.5 percent last year from 33.2 percent of grades in 1985. 
Failing grades, D's and C's accounted for fewer than 6 percent. 
 "With such a narrow range of grades available, faculty find it difficult to distinguish adequately between work of differing quality; they may also be unable to make such distinctions clear to students," wrote Susan Pedersen, dean of undergraduate education.
The dean's office has no official power over the faculty, but the dean can direct the departments to study the issue and push for change.
The highest percentage of A's was in small humanities classes, where they made up almost two-thirds of the grades given. Social science classes with 75 students or more were the toughest, with a third of the students receiving A's or A-minuses.
Some of the factors driving professors' generosity with grades were pressure to grade similarly to colleagues, fear of becoming known as a "tough grader" and pressure from students accustomed to higher grades, the Harvard study said.
The higher grades may also be deserved, as students work harder and are better prepared, it said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
In a model for lending in developing nations, a Bangladesh bank relies on peer pressure for collateral.

BYLINE:  By Hal R. Varian; Hal R. Varian is an economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. E-mail: hal@sims.berkeley.edu.

 BODY:
THE village moneylender in Bangladesh charges interest rates of over 150 percent a year. Citibank would love to get that kind of return on its investments -- so why isn't Citibank lending money in Bangladesh villages?
 This is a serious question, in terms of both policy and profit. The painfully high interest rates charged by moneylenders in developing countries suggest that marginal investment opportunities there are much more profitable than in advanced industrial nations. 
 So why isn't there a rush of investment from Western banks to exploit these profitable opportunities -- and, as a byproduct, increase the pace of economic development in these countries?
There are several barriers to entry in the lending business in developing countries, many of which have to do with the information advantages that incumbent moneylenders have over potential entrants.
To begin, the local moneylender is intimately familiar with his clientele, and this gives him a huge information advantage over a bank officer in selecting reliable loan recipients. At the same time, the moneylender is in a very good position to monitor borrowers since he can check up on their activities daily.
Local moneylenders are also familiar with village customs and practices and can offer useful business advice; they are also in a good position to provide informal insurance to the loan recipients, too, since they know when a nonperforming loan is caused by outside causes, like bad weather, and when laziness is the cause.
Finally, moneylenders operate at a much smaller scale than Citibank does. Most of these loans are minuscule by Western standards, and Citibank just is not set up to handle tiny investments, even if they are potentially very profitable.
These factors -- selection costs, monitoring costs, local experience, insurance and inappropriate scale -- conspire to create a virtual monopoly for the moneylender. Even moneylenders from neighboring villages might find it hard to compete with someone who has an intimate knowledge of a particular village's inhabitants. The result is tens of thousands of tiny monopolies and many profitable projects that are never undertaken because of the high cost of borrowing.
But there is hope. About 25 years ago Muhammad Yunus, a Bangladeshi economist trained in the United States, developed a lending model that managed to overcome these kinds of barriers. His business model for microcredit has been immensely successful, spawning imitators the world over.
Most of these lenders are nonprofits, but they are self-supporting nonprofits, which do not require subsidies or loan guarantees. There are even a few for-profit enterprises experimenting with the Yunus microcredit model.
Mr. Yunus put his plan into effect through an institution he called the Grameen Bank.
The critical feature of the program is that a candidate for a loan must form a group with four other people who are not family members. Two members of the group originally receive a loan, and if they do well, the others then receive loans.
The borrowers are encouraged to assist each other, and all loan disbursements and repayments are made publicly, in front of other groups. Loans are always for one year, at a fixed interest rate of 20 percent, and they are always for modest amounts: no more than a few hundred dollars.
The borrowers use the loans to buy looms, chickens, cows and make other small capital investments. They start repaying the loan two weeks after getting it, and once they have repaid the initial loan, they are allowed to apply for new ones.
How does this business model solve the information problems described above? First, take the selection problem. The Grameen design provides strong incentive for good borrowers to join together, since they don't want to risk losing a loan because of one failure or troublemaker. The fact that they cannot join with other family members removes one sort of pressure to dilute group quality.
Second, the members of the group have an incentive to monitor one another's activities actively. They can provide advice, assistance, education and, if necessary, insurance. The group members themselves are in the best position to know whether a recipient is slacking off or has just had a run of bad luck, and they have great incentives to monitor their behavior in an honest and helpful way.
Third, all of this selection, monitoring, educating and insuring is done not by high-paid professionals, but by Bangladeshi peasants. The transactions costs of using groups are far, far lower than are the transactions costs for traditional bank loans.
There are other interesting economic angles. Over 90 percent of the borrowers are women. This isn't so much an ideological choice as a pragmatic one -- women turned out to be better credit risks. They were more tightly tied to the home and had fewer outside temptations, so they focused much more intently than did male borrowers on completing their projects.
All this seems to work. The bank says it has a repayment rate of 99 percent, and over 92 percent of the bank's shares are owned by the borrowers. Peer pressure can be an immensely strong force, and the Grameen Bank has figured out how to make it work in the cause of economic development.
Experiments elsewhere haven't been uniformly successful. In some countries, the poverty stricken do not have enough group solidarity to provide the necessary discipline. In more urban settings, it may be difficult to find appropriate small-scale investments. But there are numerous successful operations inspired by the Grameen bank.
One program, Project Enterprise, runs a Grameen-type program for minority entrepreneurs in New York.
To answer the question posed in the first paragraph: Citibank and other Western banks are well aware of the Grameen model. In 1999 the Citigroup Foundation donated $1 million to the program.
Citibank, along with others, is currently experimenting with microlending in India and other developing countries. Multinational banks may yet find ways to break the moneylenders' monopolies and finance microinvestment in poor countries.
Access to capital is critical for economic development. Grameen and its many offspring, both nonprofit and for-profit, offer an exciting model for alleviating poverty.

GRAPHIC: Photo: To display products made by businesses financed by the Grameen Bank, huts were built at Joypura, a village near Dhaka, Bangladesh, before a visit by President Bill Clinton. The bank, which provides so-called microcredit, is a model for developing economies. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Some Mississippi Doctors Quit Obstetrics, Citing Insurance Cost 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 21 

 BODY:
When Kim Smith went into labor in Holly Ridge on Sept. 9, 1993, she had every intention of driving the two hours south to her doctor in Jackson.
 But Ms. Smith and her family ended up instead in a hospital in nearby Indianola, where a family practice physician, Dr. Edgar Donahoe Jr., delivered her son. 
 "We barely got in the car and it was time to have the baby," said Ms. Smith, a 40-year-old mother of three.
If Ms. Smith were in the same predicament today, she might not have found a doctor in time.
Specialists in family medicine and obstetrics-gynecology in Indianola and other rural areas of Mississippi are increasingly dropping obstetrics because of skyrocketing costs for malpractice insurance.
Medical liability insurance rates for doctors who deliver babies have risen from 20 percent to 400 percent this year depending on the carrier, the Mississippi State Medical Association said. Annual premiums range from $40,000 to $110,000, the association said.
"They're passing the load to every physician they cover," said Liz Carroll, the medical association's government affairs representative. "Good doctors are being forced to ante up for the jackpot justice mentality in this state. In the end, patients have fewer options."
The Delta, a poor, rural region, has been hit particularly hard because of the already limited choices for care.
Three of the six doctors in Cleveland who deliver babies ended that part of their practice in October because of the premiums. Greenwood will soon go to two from four. Yazoo City, which has 14,550 residents, has no one practicing obstetrics.
Dr. Waldemar Prichard, one of Dr. Donahoe's partners in Indianola, says he will have to stop delivering babies next year unless he gets a break on his malpractice insurance bill, which he pays himself.
Dr. Prichard's premium for the coming year was $70,000. His gross salary last year was $72,000.
"I wanted to be a doctor not for the money but for the sheer pleasure and satisfaction of making a difference in people's lives," said Dr. Prichard, 57. "But you still have bills to pay."
Insurance companies say they have had no choice but to raise rates because of increasing health care costs and the rising number of high-dollar lawsuits and claims in Mississippi and other states.
Mississippi has gained a national reputation for multimillion-dollar verdicts and settlements.
"The legal climate is one of several factors that has us where we are," said the Mississippi insurance commissioner, George Dale. "That's what the insurance companies want to talk about. But they've also seen their investments decline in this economic downturn."
The St. Paul Companies, one of Mississippi's largest medical malpractice carriers, earlier this year requested a 75 percent rate increase for doctors in the state. The state approved a 65 percent increase.
Not satisfied, St. Paul responded by dropping a number of ob-gyns and other doctors in high-risk specialties.
Mr. Dale said he had threatened to rescind the rate increase approval if St. Paul continued to drop doctors.
Mississippi is not alone in dealing with high rates for malpractice insurance.
Gov. Bob Wise of West Virginia called lawmakers into special session last week to come up with affordable insurance options for doctors, some of whom were leaving the state.
In parts of Florida, some doctors paid nearly $160,000 last year for professional liability insurance.

HEADLINE: Lots of Competition for 2001's Hit Toy 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
There were four Billy Blazes, the New York City Fire Department firefighter who is currently the most popular of the hit Rescue Heroes action figures from Fisher-Price, remaining on the spindle at the new Toys "R" Us store in Times Square at midday on Monday.
 Suddenly, a young man rushed up, pulled them all down and thrust them into one of the mesh bags that serve as shopping carts at the store. 
 Sasha, Jade and Yasmin, three of the four Bratz dolls from MGA Entertainment, were sold out at the store and, briefly, at the Toysrus.com Web site -- although Cloe, the platinum-haired Caucasian member of the ethnically correct group, was available in abundance.
And forget about the Hogwarts Castle from Lego.
It's not even Thanksgiving, and while there is no single must-have toy this season, there are plenty of best-selling toys that may be in short supply because of the faltering economy and the events of Sept. 11. Many toy retailers kept orders light this year because of concern about the economy, but now they are betting that sales will be fairly solid during this holiday season. 
History has shown that the toy business is more resilient than other retail businesses in a recession because parents tend to cut back on spending for themselves but not for their children, if they can help it. 
This year, consumers are expected to travel less, which may leave more dollars for toys and other gifts, and there is an extra week between Thanksgiving and Christmas. All of that may be a boon for retailers across the board.
In the wake of the terrorist attacks, more emphasis is being placed on family and home, which also bodes well for the toy business -- although retailers say sales of traditional board games and classic toys like baby dolls were strong even before the terrorist attacks. 
"We really haven't changed our outlook much following Sept. 11," said Melissa Comer Williams, a toy industry analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison. "We've always thought it was going to be a good holiday season for toys, driven by licensed toys tied to the Harry Potter and 'Monsters Inc.' movies and a variety of other products."
No one toy has emerged as a runaway hit, as this year's Furby or Cabbage Patch doll, but that is probably positive for the industry. "It's a better business for everyone," Ms. Comer Williams said, "if sales are spread across a broad assortment of products, rather than concentrated on one or two."
That is true, but the absence of a single blockbuster toy also has a downside. "The thing about a hit toy is it gets people back into the stores repeatedly looking for it," said Tom Alfonsi, senior vice president of merchandising at K-B Toys. "Traffic has been a little bit off, although we're looking forward to it picking up this week."
A hit could emerge tomorrow, the start of the official holiday shopping season. "When there are toys that are very strong, they usually make their appearance after Thanksgiving," said Neil Friedman, president of Fisher-Price Brands, a subsidiary of Mattel. "Tickle Me Elmo was selling fine, but it wasn't until the day after Thanksgiving in 1996 that he sold out in one day everywhere."
Fisher-Price has a new version of that smash hit for this year: Tickle Me Elmo Surprise.
From a parent's perspective, a wider variety of potential hits means less stress.
For instance, there will surely be a scramble for the two new video consoles, the Xbox from Microsoft and the GameCube from Nintendo, but the overall supply of game platforms will be greater than last year, when Sony ran into production problems with the hotly anticipated PlayStation 2. "This is the first time we've had more than one new-console introduction," Mr. Alfonsi said.
In any case, toy industry experts say PlayStation 2 will be the hottest seller in the video games segment because it has a wider supply of games, particularly popular sports games. They note that Furby had a much bigger year in 1999, when it was not the hottest toy, than it did in 1998, when it was.
"It's funny, but with all the news about the new consoles, PlayStation 2 is going to do really well, with good supply, no kinks, good games," said Chris Byrne, an independent toy consultant. "I think Sony will gain market share, and without cutting prices."
The hit retro toy of the season is Shrinky Dinks, a crafts toy formerly popular in the 1970's. Spin Master Toys, the company that makes Shrinky Dinks, filled orders for 400,000 of the kits, but Anton Rabie, president of Spin Master, said the company could have sold 200,000 more, based on inquiries from retailers in the last few weeks. 
Toys linked to characters in movies, cartoons or books continue to increase their dominance of the toy business, and the releases of two big children's movies this month, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" from Warner Brothers and "Monsters Inc." from Disney and Pixar, make toys related to them a pretty sure-fire bet. 
One toy that is flying off the shelves so far is Glowing Bedtime Sully, a fuzzy replica of the hairy blue monster in "Monsters Inc."; it is, in effect, a huggable, talking night light. Mike Wazowski, the one-eyed monster with Billy Crystal's voice, has been selling less quickly, but Babblin' Boo, based on the little girl in the movie, has sold far better than expected. 
Hogwarts Castle from Lego and the Levitating Challenge game from Mattel are both linked to the Harry Potter movie and are selling like hotcakes. Professor Snape's Potions Class, a kit by Mattel for making drinkable "potions" with ingredients that fizz, foam, smoke and change colors, is also expected to do well.
Toy industry watchers warn that Harry Potter merchandise may be in especially short supply this season. Harry Potter products introduced a year ago did not sell well, so retailers ordered cautiously this year. "Then the excitement with the movie started three weeks ago," said Jim Silver, publisher of Toy Wishes magazine, "and the only way to describe what's happened with Harry Potter toys is that it's like a light switch suddenly got flipped on."
Those looking for educational toys are likely to gravitate to products from Leap Frog, Mr. Silver and others said. The company introduced the Imagination Desk this season, an interactive desktop, but its Leap Pad products are also expected to do well.
Among robotic toys, the brightly colored Rumble Robots from Trendmasters, introduced in May, continue to sell well, according to retailers.
But a radio-controlled skateboard toy based on Tony Hawk, the skateboarding star, has been slow to take off, they say, contrary to expectations. "I'm on a 20-city tour," said Mr. Byrne, the independent consultant, "and the only place it has been sold out is Orange County, which is where he's from."
At a list price of $60, that toy is also fairly expensive. But price has not dampened enthusiasm for e-kara, a karaoke toy, imported from Japan by Hasbro, that plugs into the television. It also has a list price of $60. 
Toy stores are particularly interested in e-kara and other karaoke toys, as well as music-related toys like the HitClips toys from Hasbro's Tiger Electronics, which appeal to the hard-to-reach girls who are preteens or young teenagers. Girls that age tend to prefer money, music-related products and clothes to toys. 
But all the debate over what's hot and what's not in the toy business may be for naught, at least when it comes to children old enough to participate in a survey. According to an online survey of 636 children 6 to 15 years old by C & R Research, a market research firm based in Chicago, clothes and sports equipment -- like bikes, scooters and skateboards -- beat out video game systems on wish lists.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Some Wonder Where Pataki Has Been During Uphill Fight for Billions

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
One New York politician after another spoke up last week as the White House and Congress tried to clamp down on federal aid to help New York recover from the recent terror attack. But through it all, one prominent New York politician remained curiously silent: Gov. George E. Pataki.
 Mr. Pataki's office says that nothing should be read into this, that he is a low-key politician who prefers to get things done through back channels. "He's been on the phone every day with the administration and Congressional leaders from both parties and will continue working hard to make sure New York gets the assistance it needs," said Joseph Conway, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki. "The governor has his own style." 
 But predictably enough, some Democrats have seized this as an opportunity to attack the Republican governor, saying that he has been increasingly detached and that that could cost New York dearly in what is shaping up to be an uphill battle for the much-needed aid.
More striking, though, is that Republicans are also grumbling -- in private, at least. "It's pretty alarming that the governor has gone this far without saying much of anything," said one New York Republican official. "None of us can figure it out."
Dissatisfaction with the governor has been building for some time now. But it was kept largely behind the scenes until last week, when the governor did not take a public position on a bipartisan effort that took shape among New York House members. They tried unsuccessfully to push a measure that would have delivered $9.73 billion in aid to the state despite the president's threat of a veto.
Now, the question that Republicans and Democrats here are asking is a simple one: What gives with Mr. Pataki?
"I'm having a hard time figuring out what is going on with the governor," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat from Manhattan, adding: "I'm disappointed. I hope he changes his mind. We need the money."
Another Democrat put it this way: "He's been the most mysterious and hard to figure out person in this whole thing."
There are those who seem willing to give Mr. Pataki the benefit of the doubt. The governor, they say, appears to be engaged in what could be described as a good-cop, bad-cop strategy with the White House. According to this view, Mr. Pataki would prefer to let members of the state's Congressional delegation provoke confrontations with the White House, while he privately offers words of encouragement to move the Bush administration in New York's direction.
"In the past, the governor's office has encouraged us to fight hard for the money," said one Democratic Congressional aide from New York. "The governor's people figured they could get more things done by maintaining a positive relationship with the White House."
The problem with that approach is that it does not seem to be working, say some New York lawmakers and aides. That is why New York Republicans took the remarkable step of joining Democrats last week in pushing for more money for the state, in defiance of the White House and Republican leaders on the Hill.
Many New York lawmakers and their aides, including Republicans, say they think that Mr. Pataki could have been helpful by lending his voice to that effort. By doing so, these lawmakers said, he would have sent a strong signal to the White House and Congressional leaders that the matter was serious enough for him to expend political capital.
They also note that other prominent New York politicians jumped into the fray, for better or worse. Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg, for example, traveled to Washington and threw his support behind the efforts being waged by New York's Congressional delegation. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani got involved, too, though he attacked the effort as counterproductive.
Now, many members of the New York delegation are seriously beginning to doubt that Mr. Pataki's silence is part of a choreographed good-cop, bad-cop routine. "It seems as if the governor is making every move based on a political calculation to bolster and preserve his reputation within his party" and with President Bush, said another Democratic aide from New York.
This is not the first time that Mr. Pataki has kept silent on matters of great importance to the delegation. He recently assured the state's two Democratic senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, that he would actively support a $5 billion economic stimulus plan they introduced to revitalize Lower Manhattan in the wake of the terror attack, according to people who were familiar with the exchange. But he has said little if anything about that plan.
Another theory being offered to explain Mr. Pataki's low profile is that he is reeling from the reception he got over a $54 billion aid request he delivered to Washington a few weeks ago. That request sought money for, among other things, projects that have nothing to do with rebuilding from the attack, like a high-speed rail link to Schenectady. His plan was derided by Republicans and Democrats alike.
"I think he's shell-shocked," a Congressional aide said. "I think he got hit from so many different sides that he just went into hiding."

HEADLINE: Reports Suggest That Recovery Will Be Soon, But Not Robust 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The economy remains weak but recent reports suggest it is no longer becoming any worse, giving weight to the increasingly popular view that a recovery is only a few months away. Still, the number of people who lose their jobs will probably remain high in the near future, economists say.
 For a fourth consecutive week, the number of people filing new claims for unemployment insurance fell last week, the government said yesterday. Also yesterday, a closely followed measure of consumer confidence rose slightly. Those disclosures followed reports about home building and retail sales that were better than expected and have helped send stock prices higher and bond prices sharply lower in the last 10 days. 
 But even if the optimists are correct about the economy and stocks hold their recent gains next year, large job cuts are still likely for months, economists say. Any quick recovery is not shaping up to be robust, many analysts say, and history indicates that companies often continue to cut costs until they are confident a downturn has ended.
"The unemployment rate is guaranteed to rise much further," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., "but that will not prevent recovery." 
The University of Michigan reported yesterday that its index of consumer confidence, which is widely thought to predict retail spending, rose slightly in recent weeks. 
By themselves, the reports on unemployment and consumer confidence did little to alter investor opinion about the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.7 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,834.68, but remained more than 8 percent above its level at the start of the month. The 10-year Treasury note continued its decline yesterday, falling 22/32, to a price of 100 14/32.
The reports issued yesterday suggested that even if the worst might soon be over, the economy would probably not return to the 4 percent annual growth rates of the late 1990's anytime soon.
"That we would have a recovery soon would not be surprising," said Richard T. Curtin, the director for consumer surveys at Michigan, who oversees the index. "That it would be a strong recovery would be very surprising."
Mr. Curtin added that in the months before an economic recovery, the confidence index typically rises modestly once and then significantly the following month. This time, though, the index increased slightly in both October and November, reflecting continued uncertainty among consumers, he said.
The index rose to 83.9, from 82.7 last month and 81.8 in September. It had reached 112 in January 2000. The index is calculated from a monthly telephone survey that asks consumers about their personal finances and their impressions of current business conditions.
A minority of economists still think a recovery is many months away, and they note that forecasters usually err on the side of excessive optimism. Businesses show no sign of starting to increase their investment in new equipment, while the weakening job market will crimp household spending, these worried analysts say. 
That job losses remain severe, if not quite as drastic as those in the weeks immediately after Sept. 11, is hardly a harbinger of happy days, the pessimists add. "We're still in pretty bad shape here," Edward McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said.
Last week, 427,000 people filed new claims for jobless benefits, a level typically seen only during recessions. That number was down from 442,000 the previous week and from a peak in late September of 535,000, which was the highest weekly figure since 1992. But the current level of claims is still more than 100,000 above the numbers more typical in the late 1990's. 
The number of people filing for continuing benefits has also fallen in recent weeks, from 3.8 million to 3.7 million, but it remains higher than it was at any point in the 1990-91 downturn. 
Reflecting the concern about the strength of the recovery, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a research group for most of the big industrial nations, predicted this week that the United States economy would grow only 0.7 percent next year. 
The 1990-91 recession followed a path similar to what many forecasters envision for this one. It ended in March 1991 after nine months, analysts agreed. But the economy continued to grow only slowly for almost two years. Total employment did not exceed its June 1990 peak of 109.9 million until April 1993.
Earlier this month, a group of academic economists considered by their peers to be the arbiters of the business cycle said that a recession might have begun in March.
Employment peaked that month at 132.7 million jobs and has since fallen to 131.8 million, according to the government's October jobs report. The economy lost 415,000 jobs last month, the most since 1980.
But many investors and economists said the reports strengthened their belief that a turning point is near. "The biggest job losses are now over," Mr. Shepherdson said. As long as companies continue to cut jobs, however, the unemployment rate, which has already risen to 5.4 percent from 3.9 percent only 13 months earlier, will continue to rise.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Jobless Claims"Weekly number of people who have filed for unemployment benefits for the first time. Graph shows number of initial jobless claims, measured in thousands, from June through November highlighting 4 week moving average.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Market)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Remembrance In the Capital Of Resilience

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
WHAT is it like in New York now, people ask, and you try to tell them, but nothing quite conveys it.
 How to explain an aching but resolute city celebrating Thanksgiving today, 10 weeks after a brutal assault that shook the collective soul? How to explain this vast, diverse place where two neighborhoods mourned yet another tragedy last weekend even as joyous children mobbed a new Toys "R" Us? Where soup kitchens are overrun, but popular restaurants still don't take last-minute reservation? 
 New York today is a place of mixed emotions, images and realities. People go to work every day on packed subways, and tourists gape from the upper reaches of double-decker buses. But thousands are out of work. And the lower level of those buses has seats to spare. 
Perhaps the worst part of being in New York now is the eerie feeling of moving backward. Homelessness and hunger are growing, office space is going begging, budget deficits loom, tax increases and deferred salary increases seem inevitable, the White House is balking about money. The headlines shout about brutal child abuse, the killings of innocent bystanders, subway violence -- crimes that New Yorkers almost believed were in the past.
Yes, the parallels are uneven. Major crimes, including murder, are still significantly lower than last year, profoundly lower than eight years ago. The city is solvent. President Bush is not Gerald R. Ford.
But it feels bad and sad, even frightening. For people who were around in the crime-ridden 1980's and near-bankrupt 1970's, the echoes of those benighted times are unsettling. It is tough not to fear a return of those trying days, tough not to worry that the city, so recently prosperous, could collapse into urban decay once again.
So much of what happens in this city is, after all, beyond its control, from the vicissitudes of the national economy to the twisted agendas of terrorists.
But New Yorkers do control their distinct spirit. When people say they love New York, they really mean they love its energy and resilience, its agile ability to reinvent itself just when things look bleakest.
The city is well-practiced in the art of renewal. In 1977, when a nationally scorned New York was struggling back from the brink of bankruptcy, The New York Times published a lead editorial about, of all things, the operetta "Show Boat." That piece, written by Roger Starr, an author and editorial board member who died on Sept. 10 at the age of 83, exhorted New Yorkers to draw on the best of themselves. Their spirit.
The editorial, called "Smile, Nola, Smile," reminded readers that "Show Boat" is about Magnolia Hawks Ravenal, daughter of Cap'n Andy Hawks, the showboat's impresario.
Magnolia eloped with the leading man of the showboat company, an incurable gambler named Gaylord Ravenal, prone to losing streaks. Magnolia ultimately realized she had to make her own living and returned to the stage and made her debut in a Chicago restaurant on New Year's Eve.
MAGNOLIA, or Nola to friends and family, did not have an auspicious beginning. She could not be heard above a mocking audience of inebriated revelers.
"As her career lay in ashes about her, and starvation at the hands of her wastrel husband loomed ahead, Cap'n Andy unexpectedly rose to his feet and called to his daughter above the chaos of the room: 'Smile, Nola, Smile!' " wrote Mr. Starr.
"This precious advice carried the day," continued the editorial. Magnolia gathered up her confidence. "As the onstage audience gradually controlled its raucousness, her physical stature grew, her voice swelled, her presence asserted itself and her independence from Ravenal was established. Her future career was assured. At the brink of the New Year, certain defeat was turned into gallant victory."
Follow Cap'n Andy's lead, Mr. Starr advised New Yorkers. 
"We do not suggest that smiling will carry the day, but rather that the confidence to draw on past strengths and traditions provides, as did Cap'n Andy for Magnolia, the emotional basis for successful exploitation of New York skills.
" 'Smile, Nola, Smile!' calls on New Yorkers to remember their proven capacity for achievement, the better to prepare for the hard work, the bitter choices, the probably unequal sacrifices that lie ahead."
So, what is New York like on this Thanksgiving? Fundamentally, it is as it has ever been. Cap'n Andy would have liked the place.

HEADLINE: Replacement For TV Tower Lost on Sept. 11 Is in Doubt 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Plans to build an enormous television tower to replace the one atop the World Trade Center are in doubt. The efforts have stalled despite growing pressure from television executives concerned about losing millions of viewers and the advertising dollars they attract.
 The plan, proposed after the terrorist attack, calls for building a 2,000-foot tower to replace the trade center's antenna mast, which served all but one of the 11 television stations in the New York region. 
 Four possible locations were floated to replace the antennas. Their loss knocked out reception to viewers without cable or satellite service in large slices of the city, shrinking the audience size just as advertising revenues were dropping because of the weakening economy. 
Even with the support of Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer, however, the plans to build the tower seem to have stalled for many reasons, including concerns about radiation, bird migratory paths, airline flight patterns, electricity and other cities' broadcast needs. Such issues have eliminated three of the four proposed sites for the tower: the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island, the Brooklyn Navy Yard and the Empire State Building.
The remaining proposed site, Governors Island, is facing opposition from preservationists, environmentalists and state legislators, who are unwilling to approve crucial exemptions to environmental and zoning regulations that Governor Pataki has advocated. In addition, Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg has other plans for the island. 
The bill Governor Pataki introduced in late September that would exempt the tower -- wherever it is built -- from environmental review, height restrictions, zoning regulations and other local laws has not gone over well in Albany, legislative leaders say.
The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said in an interview that Democrats would not even consider the bill in its current form. "I am not prepared to give a blank check," he said. "Even with the site picked, I am not sure why we would avoid every local law designed to protect the public and give the public a say."
Those objections are threatening to derail plans to restore signals to the entire New York region, a prospect that so concerns television executives that the chairman of one media conglomerate brought the issue up in a recent lunch meeting with Vice President Dick Cheney.
The site for the tower proposed by the Metropolitan Television Association, a group of 11 New York region stations formed after the attack to address the issue, could take up to 30 acres. The tower itself would be 2,000 feet tall, about 300 feet higher than the mast that was on top of the trade center's north tower. The cost is estimated at $40 million, to be shared among the stations.
Unlike the other sites, Governors Island would not interfere with airplane paths, nor has it yet posed any similar safety issues, but legislators say other concerns about the environment and development of the island would get in the way.
The battle is commanding attention at the highest levels of each of the major networks -- ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox -- because hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising are at stake. "A third of the population does not have cable," said Mitchell Stern, the chairman of Fox Television Stations, which owns WNYW (Channel 5) and WWOR (Channel 9) in New York. Cable and satellite viewers are unaffected.
According to a draft position paper that has not yet been released, television executives estimate that about one million households, or roughly three million people, are without one or more channels. The numbers are the worst in Brooklyn, where 240,000 homes are without one or more stations, officials said. In each neighborhood, the lowest cable penetration rates are among the poor, the elderly and minority populations.
One station, WNJU (Channel 47), which has set up a temporary antenna on a 900-foot tower in Alpine, N.J., estimates that it has lost about 30 percent of its audience since the attack.
"There is a lot of cable coverage with the Hispanic audience, but the two boroughs that suffer the most in terms of cable penetration are Queens and Brooklyn, and those boroughs are very ethnic," said Ramon J. Pineda, vice president and general manager of WNJU, a Spanish-language station. 
Bill Baker, the president of WNET (Channel 13) and the chairman of the Metropolitan Television Association, said the issue was also economic. "One of the things that concerns us the most is that we serve everyone in this community, the richest and the poorest, and that we be available to everyone free of charge," he said. 
Every station in the New York area except WXTV (Channel 41) had an antenna on the trade center. WCBS (Channel 2) has a backup antenna at the Empire State Building, and WWOR and WNYW were able to quickly install high power transmitters on that building after Sept. 11.
The short-term plan is for each station to get some kind of antenna on top of the Empire State Building. But in the long term it is unlikely that the building would be a feasible site. "Expensive reconstruction would be necessary that would be extremely costly and take too long to complete," the draft of the position paper reads. "Radiation at the site, which is already a concern to tenants, would be exacerbated."
Station engineers estimate that more electrical power would have to be piped up more than 100 floors from the ground to serve all stations. Reinforcing the roof and reconfiguring it for broadcast transmitters, including newly configured digital transmitters, could take years, officials said.
Fresh Kills was ruled out because it is close enough to Philadelphia to interfere with television signals in that area. A Brooklyn Navy Yard tower would violate Federal Aviation Administration regulations because it would be in the flight path of planes using La Guardia Airport. 
Governors Island would also have problems. Mr. Bloomberg said in October that he wanted to put high schools on the island. Aides to Mr. Bloomberg said this week that no television executives or officials in the Pataki administration had contacted him about a plan to build a tower there. 
The federal government would still have to sell the island or give it away for the tower to be built. Congressional Republicans and the Bush administration have said that they would like to sell the island to the highest bidder.
In Albany, the New York State Broadcasters Association has hired William D. Powers, the former chairman of the State Republican Party, as a lobbyist to work with the administration and the Legislature. Joe Reilly, the president of the association, said, "The Senate and Assembly don't want to give a blank check without some specificity as to where it is going to be because, as one guy put it to me, 'It would be a political nightmare if they put it by homes in my district.' "
To that end, lobbyists for NBC, CBS, ABC and Fox in Washington, as well as executives of the companies, have taken the issue of using Governors Island up with Congressional leaders and senior Bush officials. 
If the plan for Governors Island does not work, station executives said, some of the channels will probably break off from Metropolitan Television Association and begin looking for smaller, less cumbersome sites on their own.
"There may be other locations, without damaging the environment and without asking every government agency, whining and crying and screaming, to 'please help me,' " one senior network executive said. "That theme is a real hard sell when you are part of a multibillion-dollar media company."

HEADLINE: Educating the World 

BYLINE:  By Gene Sperling; Gene Sperling, director of the Forum on Universal Education at the Brookings Institution, was Bill Clinton's national economic adviser from 1997 to 2001.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Beyond being horrified by stories of Taliban militants beating a 6-year-old girl for carrying a notebook, as reported by Newhouse News Service, and warning a classroom of girls in an underground school that they would be burned alive if they returned the next day, as related in U.S. News & World Report, Americans are pained by the simple reality that any government would ban school for girls.
 Afghanistan is moving beyond the Taliban, but schooling may remain inaccessible not only to many of its girls, but to their brothers. Around the world, 125 million children 6 to 11 years old are out of school, most because of a lack of school buildings, textbooks and qualified teachers as well as inability to pay for school fees, uniforms and transportation. Girls, who make up two-thirds of the unschooled children, are also held back by cultural pressures, parental fear for their security, and a lack of female teachers and bathroom facilities. 
 In Afghanistan, education was hard to get even before the Taliban regime: in 1996, 90 percent of girls and nearly two-thirds of boys were not going to school. In Pakistan, the all-male madrassas, fundamentalist Islamic schools, prosper because less than 2 percent of the nation's gross domestic product is devoted to public education. In 12 nations in sub-Saharan Africa, fewer than half of 8-year-olds are enrolled in school.
If the world really wants Afghanistan to reinvent itself as a stable and functional nation, it must help Afghans assure education for their children. And at the same time, the United States and other wealthy nations should seize the moment to get all of the world's children into school.
The goal of universal education is not solely a Western aspiration. In Dakar, Senegal, in 2000, 180 nations committed to the goal of universal education by 2015 for boys and girls. They included Iran, Iraq, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Indonesia and most of the other nations of Africa, South Asia and Latin America. Leaders trying to develop their nations' economies know the advantages. Not only does each year of schooling in the poorest nations raise people's earning power by 10 to 20 percent, but recent research also demonstrates that girls' education leads to smaller, healthier families.
The cause of universal education is stunningly neglected. The United Nations Children's Fund estimates that an additional $9.1 billion would be needed each year to reach the goal set for 2015. That is probably understated. Total American spending on education in poor countries is only $150 million to $200 million a year.
Congress and the president should raise our commitment to basic education to $1 billion a year and challenge the rest of the world to match us proportionally. This help would be most effective if it was accompanied by more American and international financing to reduce hunger, poverty and the spread of AIDS. We should also call on the World Bank and the United Nations to work with the rich and poor countries on a coordinated global program for basic education. It should lay out responsibilities for all countries in promoting basic education. It should introduce peer review boards to evaluate the education plans of the nations receiving aid.
We cannot count on education to end the threat of terrorism; indeed, many of the suicide hijackers of Sept. 11 were highly educated. However, a major American commitment to achieving universal education would give millions of poor children more hope and greater opportunities for choosing constructive futures. It would also be a profound demonstration of our heart and humanity at a time when we are so confounded by those who cheer acts of violence against us.

HEADLINE: After Danish Vote, Anxiety Over the Rightists 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
A big swing to the right in Denmark's election on Tuesday has caused concern that the new center-right government may become a hostage to strongly anti-immigrant forces on the far right.
 The Liberal Party, led by Anders Fogh Rasmussen, 48, eclipsed the Social Democrats, led by the departing prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, in the election for the first time since the 1920's. (The Rasmussens are not related.) 
 Prime Minister Rasmussen formally handed his resignation to Queen Margrethe today. 
But the next prime minister, though dealing a fresh blow to Scandinavia's once-mighty Social Democrats, will have to depend on support from the anti-immigration Danish People's Party for a parliamentary majority.
The People's Party leader, Pia Kjaersgaard, has exploited fears about Muslims since the attacks on the United States on Sept. 11. She has urged far stricter limits on immigration and once said she crossed the street to avoid meeting a Muslim.
"It's clear I'm worried," said Goran Persson, Sweden's prime minister, a Social Democrat. "We now see a center-right government which will be forced to prop itself up with anti-foreigner ideas."
Mr. Fogh Rasmussen, a former economy minister in Denmark, promised stricter immigration laws, a cap on taxation and improved hospitals. He rebuffed expressions of concern from some fellow Liberals abroad. Immigrants in Copenhagen are distressed.
"I often get called names when I go out on the town for a beer, and the ugly remarks increased after Sept. 11," said Wallid el-Amrani, a 24-year-old student from Jordan who said he might try to move to "a less hostile country."
"I fear things could get worse with this new government," said Zarah Ahmed, a 36-year-old shopkeeper from Syria who said immigrants had been made scapegoats for the failings of Denmark's welfare system.
In Sweden, the daily newspaper Dagens Nyheter was blunt. "It is difficult to point to any winner in the Danish election, but the losers are easier to identify," it said. "They are all those with dark skin, humanism and decency. Goodnight Denmark."
The amount of Danish aid to developing nations is the largest in the world as a percentage of gross domestic product, and for the first time, two immigrants won seats in parliament in Tuesday's election.
Fewer than 5 percent of Denmark's 5.3 million people are foreigners, a smaller proportion than in many European countries.
Danish newspapers welcomed the landslide upset of the Social Democrats, saying it showed that Danes were fed up after nine years under Mr. Nyrup Rasmussen, the European Union's longest-serving prime minister. "It is clear that a basic desire for change played a role," Politiken said.
Mr. Fogh Rasmussen's center-right bloc won 98 seats in Parliament, against 77 for Mr. Nyrup Rasmussen's bloc.
Mr. Fogh Rasmussen's Liberals have 56 seats and are likely to form a minority coalition with the 16 seats of the Conservatives and the 4 of the Christian People's Party.
It will depend on informal support from the 22 members of the Danish People's Party, but Mr. Fogh Rasmussen has ruled out giving them seats in his cabinet. Thus Denmark will not swing as far right as Austria, where the Freedom Party of Jorg Haider has seats in government.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE UNEMPLOYED; 
Ground Zero Cleanup Jobs Prove Slow to Materialize

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
A city-financed program seeking work for welfare recipients and dislocated workers has recruited at least 150 people for $9-an-hour cleanup jobs at or near the World Trade Center site.
 Recruiters at the program, Training Solutions Inc., said that they had told the people who signed up that they should be willing to work 12-hour shifts in the rubble and amid toxic fumes. 
 But the jobs those recruiters were hired to fill have not yet materialized, and the exact nature of the work is unclear. 
The company that placed the order, Adecco, an international temporary staffing business, insisted that the jobs would be safe and only involve work cleaning the interiors of buildings affected by the collapse of the trade center. 
Executives at Adecco confirmed that in late September it had placed the job order for at least 200 workers -- on behalf of a prospective client it would not identify -- with more than one welfare-to-work organization in the city.
But Bob Kovalsky, a regional vice president at Adecco, a publicly traded corporation with world headquarters in Switzerland, said that the client, "a private enterprise located outside of New York," had told Adecco on Friday not to proceed with hiring. 
"At this point, the prospective client has put us on hold," Mr. Kovalsky said. "I'm not sure of the reasons why."
The recruiters at Training Solutions said that the job offers were repeatedly delayed because of recurrent safety questions, fears of union opposition and the politics at ground zero. 
"It was supposed to start about two weeks ago," said one recruiter, Robert L. Tucker, a consultant for Training Solutions who said he had signed up 150 would-be workers at Adecco's request. "The mayor was supposed to give clearance."
Instead, Mr. Tucker said, an Adecco representative kept delaying the start date. 
Several telephone calls seeking comment from city officials, including Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles, were not returned. 
The recruitment has taken place in the shadow of a series of politically volatile disputes over the number and safety of firefighters at ground zero, and against a backdrop of looming federal welfare time limits. 
By any definition, cleaning up the World Trade Center area represents the biggest public works project in the city. Earlier this month, the Giuliani administration told contractors now removing debris that it would soon hire the Bechtel Group, a politically connected construction giant based in San Francisco, to oversee the $1 billion project. 
Union leaders said they feared that Bechtel would turn to nonunion labor and outside contractors to complete the work.
As recently as early November, one faction within the city's Human Resources Administration was advocating that welfare recipients be offered temporary jobs tied to the World Trade Center cleanup, said an expert on welfare policy who had been briefed on some of the discussions. 
The city agency is trying hard to further reduce the already shrunken welfare rolls before the end of the Giuliani administration. About 32,800 recipients are facing the five-year federal time limit on Dec. 2. In recent weeks, the city has offered $9-an-hour jobs in the parks to hundreds of them. Some, too, have been referred through the city's privatized welfare-to-work contractors, called Employment Services Programs, to large temporary staffing companies like Adecco. 
At Training Solutions, a shabby warren of classrooms in an old Hunter College building near the Port Authority terminal, an ungrammatical sign warns, "All ESP client's who refuse a job that is offered to them risk getting sanction for non compliance." Under state law, recipients who run out the federal welfare clock are still eligible to apply for a state aid program known as Safety Net Assistance, financed without federal money. But any able-bodied person who refuses a specific job without good cause is to be denied aid. 
On Monday morning, half a dozen men were waiting at Training Solutions to speak to Mr. Tucker and his partner, the consultants who had registered them for World Trade Center cleanup. The men's complaint was that the jobs kept being postponed, not that the work might be dangerous. 
"They told me about it -- a lot of debris, chemicals and stuff," said Ricardo Andino, 25, who said he was impatient to begin work after responding a month ago to an advertisement about the World Trade Center jobs posted in a Bronx public school. "It's really hazardous, but I need a job." 
John Harris, 51, who has a ninth-grade education and was laid off in June from a maintenance job he had held since 1994, echoed the sentiment. 
"I got to feed my family some kind of way," he said after anxiously recalling news reports about cancer-causing fumes near ground zero. "I can't worry about 20 years down the road -- I need a job now."
The director of Training Solutions, Henry M. Stern, said the recession added to the desperation of people seeking work, and to the intense financial pressure felt by city-contract agencies like his own. 
The agency, which specializes in training dislocated workers in electronics repair, has been operating without any city money since September, he said.
"The city's attitude is, 'We'll only pay you when you place them,' " Mr. Stern said. "Is the city interested in training? Not one bit. The city is only interested in job placement." 
He added, "We've spent weeks on this thing."
Starting in 1999, state and federal grants previously given to the city's Department of Employment were transferred by the Giuliani administration to the Human Resources Administration, which then signed contracts with companies that would be paid, with some small exceptions, only if they succeeded in placing welfare recipients in jobs. 
Mr. Tucker said he had been director of job development for the Wildcat Service Corporation, a large nonprofit training and employment agency with many city contracts, before going into business for himself as Urban Placement Brokers Inc. this year. He said that he and his partner would not be paid unless their recruits were actually hired. 
"What's in it for me," Mr. Tucker asked. "To recruit people to sell them a dream?"
