HEADLINE: Essay; 
Welcome Back, Politics!

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Come the spring, the White House chief of staff, Andrew Card, will move to Massachusetts to compete for the Republican nomination for governor. (The race is not always to the Swift.) This is Card's lifelong ambition, and maybe the entry of a fresh face will stop the slide of G.O.P.-held statehouses into Democratic hands. 
 He will be replaced in that top political power slot by Tom Ridge, the former Pennsylvania governor who is now grimly trying to run "homeland security" from the president's side without the needed muscle to knock departmental heads together. 
 That move up will make Ridge happy and productive, but who can Bush get with the reputation -- and the go-for-the-jugular political moxie -- to take on the job of protecting us from any new terror attacks after we blow up the Cave Man? 
Answer: Rudy Giuliani, of course, provided the refugee from Gracie Mansion gets the bureaucratic power to hire and fire, urge and merge, recommended months ago by the Hart-Rudman commission. In three months as a private citizen, Rudy can make three million bucks and then get back into politics and into the running for vice president against Rummy and Condi when Bush names non-lawyer Dick Cheney to the next open seat on the Supreme Court. 
You, as a paying reader (unless you're one of those Internet freeloaders), must wonder: How does he get all this exclusive inside information? How can he be so certain of things to come -- when other journalists equivocate and hide behind attributions to rumor and gossip? 
Let me break all the rules of punditry and reveal the single source for this stunning report of musical chairs: It's my thumb, on which I suck while I stare at the wall and dream up this stuff. 
Here is the trick in the political prognostication dodge: Take what you know to be true and then play fast and loose with the possible. 
I know that Card wants to run in Massachusetts, and today Acting Gov. Jane Swift does look like a loser. I know from the look on his face at news conferences that Ridge is unhappy to be on the firing line with no troops of his own, and presume he would make a fine chief of staff because Bush trusts him. And I know that Giuliani will be miserable following Bill Clinton around on the big-fee lecture circuit, and will soon lust for a return to power's center stage. 
String these possibilities together, and voila! a nifty scenario that will cause hushed huzzahs in West Wing hallways half-empty on Thanksgiving. (If none of this happens, I can pull an Ashcroft, explaining that only my alert to the world of its credible possibility prevented it from happening. And if I do get lucky and win the trifecta, you'll never hear the end of it.) 
All the above is "talkin' politics," which is fun, but some have been quietly "doin' politics," which is work: 
1. An education bill this year looks good as Ted Kennedy squeezes in a little more spending, but a prescription drug bill is pushed off to next year. 
2. Bush and Kennedy are in a lazily foolish wrangle over appointments to the F.D.A. and the N.I.H., frustrating the nation's scientists, but Bill Frist will push the bioterrorism bill through the Senate to signature with billions for public health facilities. 
3. Tax-cut prospects look bad because the House's Bill Thomas won't go in the room with big-spender Bobby Byrd, to the point where the Democrat Max Baucus is begging Bush to lean on Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, for help. No bill means no $80 billion stimulus and therefore a half-point drop in G.D.P. 
4. Campaign reform is dead this year, and there is little public demand for a vote-counting bill, despite the early hoo-hah. 
5. Fast-track trade promotion will be decided next week, with Bush pushing hard to get 40 House Democrats to buck organized labor and Charlie Rangel. 
6. New York gets half of its promised $20 billion now, with the other half maybe later in the fast-disappearing stimulus package, the bioterror bill and supplementals. New building is stymied by trial lawyers' opposition to caps on liability in government-backed "terror insurance." 
Daschle, in the dumps, is digging in his heels. Bush, at 90 percent, is disinclined to mix it up. Now back to all war, allatime.

HEADLINE: Mixed Signals From Russia On Prospects for Oil Cutbacks 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Russia sent mixed signals today but no definitive word on whether it would cooperate with other oil exporters outside OPEC in cutting production.
 As a result, petroleum prices bounced around on each nuance, finishing the day somewhat lower after an early upward spike. The benchmark price for January delivery of light crude fell 19 cents, to $18.96 a barrel in New York trading today; it rose 72 cents a barrel on Tuesday on word that Mexico and Norway, the No. 2 and No. 3 non-OPEC exporters after Russia, had agreed to make much larger cuts if Russia would do the same. 
 Today, Russia's intentions were no clearer. Viktor Khristenko, Russia's deputy prime minister in charge of energy, said again that his government might be willing to reconsider its previous offer of a token cutback of 30,000 barrels a day in exports.
"The adoption of more serious measures aimed at stabilizing oil price levels is possible," the Russian news service Interfax quoted Mr. Khristenko as saying.
But the finance minister, Alexei L. Kudrin, told parliamentary leaders today that the government would reduce its projections for economic growth and government revenue from oil sales, a sign that the country was digging in for an extended period of lower prices. And Russia's biggest oil company, Lukoil, said it was planning its own budget for 2002 based on a $16-a-barrel oil price.
Perhaps most tellingly, the economic adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin came out strongly against acceding to requests by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce shipments.
"Question -- what should we do with OPEC?" the adviser, Andrei N. Illarionov, said at a news conference. "Answer -- nothing, because OPEC is an unreliable partner; because OPEC is a historically doomed organization; because, in the price war declared against us, Russia is in a much more advantageous position than OPEC."
Analysts here tried to sense whether the recent slump in oil prices had begun to squeeze Russia's economy enough to eventually lead the country to go along with OPEC. Russia's treasury relies heavily on oil and gas revenue, and investment in the energy sector has helped jump-start the nation's economic growth.
Economists said Russia's reserves of foreign currency -- now about $36 billion -- and a budget surplus this year of some $3.5 billion would cushion the government against much damage to next year's budget.
"Budget-wise, they are in a very strong position," said Willem H. Buiter, chief economist for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development at a news conference in Moscow. "Russia has conducted its macroeconomic policy exceptionally well. Even oil prices at $12 could be managed."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Trump Begins Negotiations On $1.3 Billion in Bond Debt
Donald J. Trump has begun talks with bondholders to adjust the terms of $1.3 billion in debt and is now expected to pay $73 million in interest past due on those bonds within days, a lawyer for Mr. Trump said.
 Mr. Trump announced the day before the interest was due that he would not make the payment, even though he had the cash to do so. Some bondholders considered the missed payment a negotiating tactic by Mr. Trump, who could use a decline in the securities to put pressure on them to come to the table. Page C2. 

No Decision From Russia on Oil Cuts
Russia sent mixed signals on whether it would cooperate with other oil exporters outside OPEC in cutting back production, causing prices to fall. In New York, crude oil for January delivery fell 19 cents, to $18.96 a barrel. It rose 72 cents a barrel on Tuesday when Mexico and Norway, the No. 2 and No. 3 non-OPEC exporters after Russia, agreed to make much larger cuts if Russia would do the same. C4.

Drugs Said to Forestall Alzheimer's
Middle-aged and elderly people who took anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen or naproxen for at least two years were apparently protected from Alzheimer's disease, according to a new study. A24.

Chairman of ABB Steps Down
Percy Barnevik, the chairman of ABB, Europe's biggest electrical engineering group, unexpectedly stepped down, saying he was taking his share of responsibility for sagging profits. World Business, Section W.

Vitamin Producers Fined in Europe
The European Commission fined eight vitamin producers a total of about $752 million for their involvement in cartels that fixed prices and market shares of vitamin products in the 1990's. World Business, Section W.

Stocks Retreat From Bull Market
Stocks retreated further from bull-market territory. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 66.70 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,834.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 5.63 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,137.03, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 5.46 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,875.05. C5.

Microsoft Lawyer Plans to Retire
William H. Neukom, 60, the legal field general in Microsoft's antitrust conflicts, said that he would retire next year. His announcement came on the heels of two major settlements engineered this month by Mr. Neukom and his team -- both regarded as victories for Microsoft -- and as the company's antitrust problems appear to be finally receding. C3.

PepsiCo Settles Advertising Dispute
PepsiCo and the world's largest advertising agency company, the Interpublic Group, settled a legal battle stemming from PepsiCo's efforts to restrict an Interpublic agency in working for its main competitor, Coca-Cola, after PepsiCo dismissed the agency. C3.

Usinor Sweetens Offer for Rivals
Usinor of France breathed new life into its $2.76 billion bid for two rivals -- Aceralia of Spain and Arbed of Luxembourg -- by sweetening the takeover terms and winning regulatory approval. World Business, Section W.

Finding Ways to Lend in Poor Nations
The high interest rates charged by moneylenders in developing countries suggest that marginal investment opportunities there are much more profitable than in advanced industrial nations. One model has managed to overcome the local barriers that have prevented Western banks from exploiting such opportunities. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

U.S. Financial Markets Are Closed
United States government offices, banks and financial markets are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. Foreign markets are open. Most United States markets will reopen tomorrow, but stock markets will close at 1 p.m. and the bond markets will close at 2 p.m.
